column2: name:"Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations"
column4: description:"The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions. The use of inconsistent implementations can cause changes in behavior when the code is ported or built under a different environment than the programmer expects
column5: which can lead to security problems in some cases. The implementation of many functions varies by platform
column7: even by different versions of the same platform. Implementation differences can include: Slight differences in the way parameters are interpreted leading to inconsistent results. Some implementations of the function carry significant security risks. The function might not be defined on all platforms. The function might change which return codes it can provide
column8: or change the meaning of its return codes."
column11: name:"Undefined Behavior for Input to API"
column13: description:"The behavior of this function is undefined unless its control parameter is set to a specific value. "
column15: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code uses the deprecated function getpw() to verify that a plaintext password matches a user's encrypted password. If the password is valid
column16: the function sets result to 1; otherwise it is set to 0.\nAlthough the code often behaves correctly
column17: using the getpw() function can be problematic from a security standpoint
column18: because it can overflow the buffer passed to its second parameter. Because of this vulnerability
column19: getpw() has been supplanted by getpwuid()
column20: which performs the same lookup as getpw() but returns a pointer to a statically-allocated structure to mitigate the risk. Not all functions are deprecated or replaced because they pose a security risk. However
column21: the presence of an obsolete function often indicates that the surrounding code has been neglected and may be in a state of disrepair. Software security has not been a priority
column23: for very long. If the program uses deprecated or obsolete functions
column24: it raises the probability that there are security problems lurking nearby.\nExample 2\nIn the following code
column25: the programmer assumes that the system always has a property named \"cmd\" defined. If an attacker can control the program's environment so that \"cmd\" is not defined
column26:
the program throws a null pointer exception when it attempts to call the "Trim()" method.
Example 3
The following code constructs a string object from an array of bytes and a value that specifies the top 8 bits of each 16-bit Unicode character.
In this example
column27: the constructor may not correctly convert bytes to characters depending upon which charset is used to encode the string represented by nameBytes. Due to the evolution of the charsets used to encode strings
column28: this constructor was deprecated and replaced by a constructor that accepts as one of its parameters the name of the charset used to encode the bytes for conversion.\n"
column31: description:"The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions
column32: which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained. As programming languages evolve
column33: functions occasionally become obsolete due to: Advances in the language Improved understanding of how operations should be performed effectively and securely Changes in the conventions that govern certain operations Functions that are removed are usually replaced by newer counterparts that perform the same task in some different and hopefully improved way."
column38: description:"The product uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the product is supposed to operate. The use of low-level functionality can violate the specification in unexpected ways that effectively disable built-in protection mechanisms
column40: or otherwise expose the functionality to attack."

column56: description:"The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors
column57: but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted. This weakness can lead to a wide variety of resultant weaknesses

column62: and so on. The exposure can occur in a few different ways: The function\/method was never intended to be exposed to outside actors. The function\/method was only intended to be accessible to a limited set of actors
column63: such as Internet-based access from a single web site."

column112: it is important that logging levels be set appropriately before a product ships so that sensitive user data and system information are not accidentally exposed to potential attackers. Different log files may be produced and stored for: Server log files (e.g. server.log). This can give information on whatever application left the file. Usually this can give full path names and system information
column113: and sometimes usernames and passwords. log files that are used for debugging"
column115: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe example below shows a configuration for the service security audit feature in the Windows Communication Foundation (WCF).\nThe previous configuration file has effectively disabled the recording of security-critical events

If the login fails a retry is made. Proper restrictions on the number of login attempts are of course part of the retry functionality. Unfortunately
column120: the failed login is not recorded and there would be no record of an adversary attempting to brute force the program.\nIt is recommended to log the failed login action. Note that unneutralized usernames should not be part of the log message
column121: and passwords should never be part of the log message.\nExample 3\nConsider this command for updating Azure's Storage Logging for Blob service

column123: the argument does not include the logging of writes and reads. Adding the \"rw\" arguments to the -log parameter will fix the issue:\nTo enable Azure's storage analytic logs programmatically using PowerShell:\nNotice that here
column124: the retention has been limited to 5 days.\n"
column132: the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it. When security-critical events are not logged properly
column133: such as a failed login attempt
column134: this can make malicious behavior more difficult to detect and may hinder forensic analysis after an attack succeeds. As organizations adopt cloud storage resources
column135: these technologies often require configuration changes to enable detailed logging information
column136: since detailed logging can incur additional costs. This could lead to telemetry gaps in critical audit logs. For example
column138: the default value for logging is disabled."
column144: description:"The product logs too much information
column145: making log files hard to process and possibly hindering recovery efforts or forensic analysis after an attack. While logging is a good practice in general
column146: and very high levels of logging are appropriate for debugging stages of development
column147: too much logging in a production environment might hinder a system administrator's ability to detect anomalous conditions. This can provide cover for an attacker while attempting to penetrate a system
column148: clutter the audit trail for forensic analysis
column149: or make it more difficult to debug problems in a production environment."

column163: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code authenticates users.\nThe authentication mechanism implemented relies on an IP address for source validation. If an attacker is able to spoof the IP
column164:
they may be able to bypass the authentication mechanism.
Example 2
Both of these examples check if a request is from a trusted address before responding to the request.
The code only verifies the address as stored in the request packet. An attacker can spoof this address
column165: thus impersonating a trusted client.\nExample 3\nThe following code samples use a DNS lookup in order to decide whether or not an inbound request is from a trusted host. If an attacker can poison the DNS cache
column166: they can gain trusted status.\nIP addresses are more reliable than DNS names
column167: but they can also be spoofed. Attackers can easily forge the source IP address of the packets they send
column168: but response packets will return to the forged IP address. To see the response packets
column169: the attacker has to sniff the traffic between the victim machine and the forged IP address. In order to accomplish the required sniffing
column170: attackers typically attempt to locate themselves on the same subnet as the victim machine. Attackers may be able to circumvent this requirement by using source routing
column171: but source routing is disabled across much of the Internet today. In summary
column172: IP address verification can be a useful part of an authentication scheme
column173: but it should not be the single factor required for authentication.\n"
column176: description:"This attack-focused weakness is caused by incorrectly implemented authentication schemes that are subject to spoofing attacks. "
column182: description:"A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes). Capture-replay attacks are common and can be difficult to defeat without cryptography. They are a subset of network injection attacks that rely on observing previously-sent valid commands
column183: then changing them slightly if necessary and resending the same commands to the server."
column185: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis code checks the certificate of a connected peer.\nIn this case

e.g. by poisoning the DNS cache or using an Adversary-in-the-Middle (AITM) attack to modify the traffic from server to client.
Example 2
The following OpenSSL code obtains a certificate and verifies it.
Even though the "verify" step returns X509_V_OK
column189: this step does not include checking the Common Name against the name of the host. That is

there is no guarantee that the certificate is for the desired host. The SSL connection could have been established with a malicious host that provided a valid certificate.
Example 3
The following OpenSSL code ensures that there is a certificate and allows the use of expired certificates.
If the call to SSL_get_verify_result() returns X509_V_ERR_CERT_HAS_EXPIRED

column192:
there is an increasing chance for attackers to compromise the certificate.

Because this code does not use SSL_get_verify_results() to check the certificate

it could accept certificates that have been revoked (X509_V_ERR_CERT_REVOKED). The software could be communicating with a malicious host.
Example 5

Note that the code does not call SSL_get_verify_result(ssl)
column194: which effectively disables the validation step that checks the certificate.\n"

column226: name:"Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust"
column237: the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate
column238: resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate. If a system does not follow the chain of trust of a certificate to a root server
column239: the certificate loses all usefulness as a metric of trust. Essentially
column240: the trust gained from a certificate is derived from a chain of trust -- with a reputable trusted entity at the end of that list. The end user must trust that reputable source
column241: and this reputable source must vouch for the resource in question through the medium of the certificate. In some cases
column242: this trust traverses several entities who vouch for one another. The entity trusted by the end user is at one end of this trust chain
column243: while the certificate-wielding resource is at the other end of the chain. If the user receives a certificate at the end of one of these trust chains and then proceeds to check only that the first link in the chain
column244: no real trust has been derived
column245: since the entire chain must be traversed back to a trusted source to verify the certificate. There are several ways in which the chain of trust might be broken
column246: including but not limited to: Any certificate in the chain is self-signed
column247: unless it the root. Not every intermediate certificate is checked
column248: starting from the original certificate all the way up to the root certificate. An intermediate
column249: CA-signed certificate does not have the expected Basic Constraints or other important extensions. The root certificate has been compromised or authorized to the wrong party."
column251: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following OpenSSL code ensures that there is a certificate before continuing execution.\nBecause this code does not use SSL_get_verify_results() to check the certificate
column252: it could accept certificates that have been revoked (X509_V_ERR_CERT_REVOKED). The product could be communicating with a malicious host.\n"
column266: description:"The product does not check or incorrectly checks the revocation status of a certificate
column267: which may cause it to use a certificate that has been compromised. An improper check for certificate revocation is a far more serious flaw than related certificate failures. This is because the use of any revoked certificate is almost certainly malicious. The most common reason for certificate revocation is compromise of the system in question
column268: with the result that no legitimate servers will be using a revoked certificate
column269: unless they are sorely out of sync."

column280: description:"The product implements an authentication technique

column292: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nIn the following Java example the method createBankAccount is used to create a BankAccount object for a bank management application.\nHowever

there is no authentication mechanism to ensure that the user creating this bank account object has the authority to create new bank accounts. Some authentication mechanisms should be used to verify that the user has the authority to create bank account objects.
The following Java code includes a boolean variable and method for authenticating a user. If the user has not been authenticated then the createBankAccount will not create the bank account object.
Example 2
In 2022
column294: the OT:ICEFALL study examined products by 10 different Operational Technology (OT) vendors. The researchers reported 56 vulnerabilities and said that the products were \"insecure by design\" [REF-1283]. If exploited
column295: these vulnerabilities often allowed adversaries to change how the products operated
column296: ranging from denial of service to changing the code that the products executed. Since these products were often used in industries such as power

there could even be safety implications.
Multiple vendors did not use any authentication for critical functionality in their OT products.
Example 3
In 2021
column301: a web site operated by PeopleGIS stored data of US municipalities in Amazon Web Service (AWS) Simple Storage Service (S3) buckets.\nWhile it was not publicly disclosed how the data was protected after discovery
column302: multiple options could have been considered.\n"

column322: an attacker was able to gain administrator access to a Twitter server because the server did not restrict the number of login attempts [REF-236]. The attacker targeted a member of Twitter's support team and was able to successfully guess the member's password using a brute force attack by guessing a large number of common words. After gaining access as the member of the support staff

column324: fake Twitter messages were sent that appeared to come from the compromised accounts.\nExample 2\nThe following code
column325: extracted from a servlet's doPost() method
column326: performs an authentication lookup every time the servlet is invoked.\nHowever
column327:
the software makes no attempt to restrict excessive authentication attempts.
Example 3
This code attempts to limit the number of login attempts by causing the process to sleep before completing the authentication.
However
column328: there is no limit on parallel connections
column329: so this does not increase the amount of time an attacker needs to complete an attack.\nExample 4\nIn the following C\/C++ example the validateUser method opens a socket connection
column330:
reads a username and password from the socket and attempts to authenticate the username and password.
The validateUser method will continuously check for a valid username and password without any restriction on the number of authentication attempts made. The method should limit the number of authentication attempts made to prevent brute force attacks as in the following example code.
Example 5
Consider this example from a real-world attack against the iPhone [REF-1218]. An attacker can use brute force methods; each time there is a failed guess
column331: the attacker quickly cuts the power before the failed entry is recorded
column332: effectively bypassing the intended limit on the number of failed authentication attempts. Note that this attack requires removal of the cell phone battery and connecting directly to the phone's power source
column333: and the brute force attack is still time-consuming.\n"

column343: making it more susceptible to brute force attacks. "

column351: description:"The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication
column352: it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak
column354: and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes
column355: a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason
column356: if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use
column357: they should be implemented and required."

column363: name:"Use of Password System for Primary Authentication"
column365: description:"The use of password systems as the primary means of authentication may be subject to several flaws or shortcomings
column366: each reducing the effectiveness of the mechanism. "
column368: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nMany systems have used Diffie-Hellman key exchange without authenticating the entities exchanging keys
column369: allowing attackers to influence communications by redirecting or interfering with the communication path. Many people using SSL\/TLS skip the authentication (often unknowingly).\n"
column372: description:"The product performs a key exchange with an actor without verifying the identity of that actor. Performing a key exchange will preserve the integrity of the information sent between two entities
column373: but this will not guarantee that the entities are who they claim they are. This may enable an attacker to impersonate an actor by modifying traffic between the two entities. Typically
column374: this involves a victim client that contacts a malicious server that is impersonating a trusted server. If the client skips authentication or ignores an authentication failure
column375: the malicious server may request authentication information from the user. The malicious server can then use this authentication information to log in to the trusted server using the victim's credentials
column376: sniff traffic between the victim and trusted server

column381: these vulnerabilities often allowed adversaries to change how the products operated
column382: ranging from denial of service to changing the code that the products executed. Since these products were often used in industries such as power

column390: description:"A client\/server product performs authentication within client code but not in server code
column391: allowing server-side authentication to be bypassed via a modified client that omits the authentication check. Client-side authentication is extremely weak and may be breached easily. Any attacker may read the source code and reverse-engineer the authentication mechanism to access parts of the application which would otherwise be protected."
column393: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA famous example of this type of weakness being exploited is the eBay attack. eBay always displays the user id of the highest bidder. In the final minutes of the auction
column394: one of the bidders could try to log in as the highest bidder three times. After three incorrect log in attempts
column395: eBay password throttling would kick in and lock out the highest bidder's account for some time. An attacker could then make their own bid and their victim would not have a chance to place the counter bid because they would be locked out. Thus an attacker could win the auction.\n"
column398: description:"The product contains an account lockout protection mechanism
column399: but the mechanism is too restrictive and can be triggered too easily
column400: which allows attackers to deny service to legitimate users by causing their accounts to be locked out. Account lockout is a security feature often present in applications as a countermeasure to the brute force attack on the password based authentication mechanism of the system. After a certain number of failed login attempts
column401: the users' account may be disabled for a certain period of time or until it is unlocked by an administrator. Other security events may also possibly trigger account lockout. However
column402: an attacker may use this very security feature to deny service to legitimate system users. It is therefore important to ensure that the account lockout security mechanism is not overly restrictive."
column407: description:"The product uses a CAPTCHA challenge
column408: but the challenge can be guessed or automatically recognized by a non-human actor. An automated attacker could bypass the intended protection of the CAPTCHA challenge and perform actions at a higher frequency than humanly possible
column409: such as launching spam attacks. There can be several different causes of a guessable CAPTCHA: An audio or visual image that does not have sufficient distortion from the unobfuscated source image. A question is generated with a format that can be automatically recognized
column410: such as a math question. A question for which the number of possible answers is limited
column411: such as birth years or favorite sports teams. A general-knowledge or trivia question for which the answer can be accessed using a data base
column412: such as country capitals or popular entertainers. Other data associated with the CAPTCHA may provide hints about its contents
column413: such as an image whose filename contains the word that is used in the CAPTCHA."
column416: name:"Use of Password Hash Instead of Password for Authentication"
column418: Product performs authentication with user-supplied password hashes that can be obtained from a separate SQL injection vulnerability (CVE-2009-1282).
column420: description:"The product records password hashes in a data store
column421: receives a hash of a password from a client
column422: and compares the supplied hash to the hash obtained from the data store. Some authentication mechanisms rely on the client to generate the hash for a password
column423: possibly to reduce load on the server or avoid sending the password across the network. However
column424: when the client is used to generate the hash
column425: an attacker can bypass the authentication by obtaining a copy of the hash
column426: e.g. by using SQL injection to compromise a database of authentication credentials
column427: or by exploiting an information exposure. The attacker could then use a modified client to replay the stolen hash without having knowledge of the original password. As a result
column428: the server-side comparison against a client-side hash does not provide any more security than the use of passwords without hashing."
column431: an attacker may be able to directly access a sensitive page by entering a URL similar to the following.\n"
column446: description:"The web application does not adequately enforce appropriate authorization on all restricted URLs
column448: or files. Web applications susceptible to direct request attacks often make the false assumption that such resources can only be reached through a given navigation path and so only apply authorization at certain points in the path."
column451: name:"Incorrect Behavior Order: Authorization Before Parsing and Canonicalization"
column453: description:"If a web server does not fully parse requested URLs before it examines them for authorization
column454: it may be possible for an attacker to bypass authorization protection. For instance
column455: the character strings \/.\/ and \/ both mean current directory. If \/SomeDirectory is a protected directory and an attacker requests \/.\/SomeDirectory
column456: the attacker may be able to gain access to the resource if \/.\/ is not converted to \/ before the authorization check is performed."
column459: name:"Improper Authorization of Index Containing Sensitive Information"
column461: description:"The product creates a search index of private or sensitive documents
column462: but it does not properly limit index access to actors who are authorized to see the original information. Web sites and other document repositories may apply an indexing routine against a group of private documents to facilitate search. If the index's results are available to parties who do not have access to the documents being indexed
column463: then attackers could obtain portions of the documents by conducting targeted searches and reading the results. The risk is especially dangerous if search results include surrounding text that was not part of the search query. This issue can appear in search engines that are not configured (or implemented) to ignore critical files that should remain hidden; even without permissions to download these files directly
column464: the remote user could read them."
column469: description:"The system's authorization functionality does not prevent one user from gaining access to another user's data or record by modifying the key value identifying the data. Retrieval of a user record occurs in the system based on some key value that is under user control. The key would typically identify a user-related record stored in the system and would be used to lookup that record for presentation to the user. It is likely that an attacker would have to be an authenticated user in the system. However
column470: the authorization process would not properly check the data access operation to ensure that the authenticated user performing the operation has sufficient entitlements to perform the requested data access
column471: hence bypassing any other authorization checks present in the system. For example
column472: attackers can look at places where user specific data is retrieved (e.g. search screens) and determine whether the key for the item being looked up is controllable externally. The key may be a hidden field in the HTML form field
column473: might be passed as a URL parameter or as an unencrypted cookie variable
column474: then in each of these cases it will be possible to tamper with the key value. One manifestation of this weakness is when a system uses sequential or otherwise easily-guessable session IDs that would allow one user to easily switch to another user's session and read\/modify their data."
column477: name:"Placement of User into Incorrect Group"
column484: description:"The product or the administrator places a user into an incorrect group. If the incorrect group has more access or privileges than the intended group
column485: the user might be able to bypass intended security policy to access unexpected resources or perform unexpected actions. The access-control system might not be able to detect malicious usage of this group membership."
column487: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\n\nConsider a system with a register for storing AES key for encryption or decryption. The key is 128 bits
column488: implemented as a set of four 32-bit registers. The key registers are assets and registers
column490: and are defined to provide necessary access controls.\nThe read-policy register defines which agents can read the AES-key registers
column491: and write-policy register defines which agents can program or write to those registers. Each register is a 32-bit register
column492: and it can support access control for a maximum of 32 agents. The number of the bit when set (i.e.
column493: \"1\") allows respective action from an agent whose identity matches the number of the bit and
column496: disallows the respective action to that corresponding agent.\n\nIn the above example
column497: there is only one policy register that controls access to both read and write accesses to the AES-key registers
column498: and thus the design is not granular enough to separate read and writes access for different agents. Here
column499:
agent with identities "1" and "2" can both read and write.
A good design should be granular enough to provide separate access controls to separate actions. Access control for reads should be separate from writes. Below is an example of such implementation where two policy registers are defined for each of these actions. The policy is defined such that: the AES-key registers can only be read or used by a crypto agent with identity "1" when bit #1 is set. The AES-key registers can only be programmed by a trusted firmware with identity "2" when bit #2 is set.
Example 2
Consider the following SoC design. The sram in HRoT has an address range that is readable and writable by unprivileged software and it has an area that is only readable by unprivileged software. The tbus interconnect enforces access control for slaves on the bus but uses only one bit to control both read and write access. Address 0xA0000000 - 0xA000FFFF is readable and writable by the untrusted cores core{0-N} and address 0xA0010000 - 0xA001FFFF is only readable by the untrusted cores core{0-N}.

The security policy access control is not granular enough
column500:
as it uses one bit to enable both read and write access. This gives write access to an area that should only be readable by unprivileged agents.
Access control logic should differentiate between read and write access and to have sufficient address granularity.

"
column503: description:"The product implements access controls via a policy or other feature with the intention to disable or restrict accesses (reads and\/or writes) to assets in a system from untrusted agents. However
column504: implemented access controls lack required granularity
column505: which renders the control policy too broad because it allows accesses from unauthorized agents to the security-sensitive assets. Integrated circuits and hardware engines can expose accesses to assets (device configuration
column507: etc.) to trusted firmware or a software module (commonly set by BIOS\/bootloader). This access is typically access-controlled. Upon a power reset
column508: the hardware or system usually starts with default values in registers
column509: and the trusted firmware (Boot firmware) configures the necessary access-control protection. A common weakness that can exist in such protection schemes is that access controls or policies are not granular enough. This condition allows agents beyond trusted agents to access assets and could lead to a loss of functionality or the ability to set up the device securely. This further results in security risks from leaked
column511: key material to modification of device configuration."

column526: name:"Missing Default Case in Multiple Condition Expression"
column528: description:"The code does not have a default case in an expression with multiple conditions
column529: such as a switch statement. If a multiple-condition expression (such as a switch in C) omits the default case but does not consider or handle all possible values that could occur
column530: then this might lead to complex logical errors and resultant weaknesses. Because of this
column531: further decisions are made based on poor information
column532: and cascading failure results. This cascading failure may result in any number of security issues
column533: and constitutes a significant failure in the system."
column538: description:"Java packages are not inherently closed; therefore
column539: relying on them for code security is not a good practice. The purpose of package scope is to prevent accidental access by other parts of a program. This is an ease-of-software-development feature but not a security feature."

column552: description:"The product is deployed to unauthorized actors with debugging code still enabled or active
column553: which can create unintended entry points or expose sensitive information. A common development practice is to add \"back door\" code specifically designed for debugging or testing purposes that is not intended to be shipped or deployed with the product. These back door entry points create security risks because they are not considered during design or testing and fall outside of the expected operating conditions of the product."

column605: name:"Object Model Violation: Just One of Equals and Hashcode Defined"
column607: description:"The product does not maintain equal hashcodes for equal objects. Java objects are expected to obey a number of invariants related to equality. One of these invariants is that equal objects must have equal hashcodes. In other words
column608: if a.equals(b) == true then a.hashCode() == b.hashCode()."
column610: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code fragment calls finalize() explicitly:\n"
column613: description:"The product makes an explicit call to the finalize() method from outside the finalizer. While the Java Language Specification allows an object's finalize() method to be called from outside the finalizer
column614: doing so is usually a bad idea. For example
column615: calling finalize() explicitly means that finalize() will be called more than once: the first time will be the explicit call and the last time will be the call that is made after the object is garbage collected."
column617: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis code binds a server socket to port 21
column618: allowing the server to listen for traffic on that port.\nThis code may result in two servers binding a socket to same port
column619: thus receiving each other's traffic. This could be used by an attacker to steal packets meant for another process
column620: such as a secure FTP server.\n"
column621: name:"Multiple Binds to the Same Port"
column623: description:"When multiple sockets are allowed to bind to the same port
column624: other services on that port may be stolen or spoofed. On most systems
column625: a combination of setting the SO_REUSEADDR socket option
column626: and a call to bind() allows any process to bind to a port to which a previous process has bound with INADDR_ANY. This allows a user to bind to the specific address of a server bound to INADDR_ANY on an unprivileged port
column627: and steal its UDP packets\/TCP connection."

column635: name:"Function Call with Incorrectly Specified Arguments"
column639: or routine with arguments that are not correctly specified
column640: leading to always-incorrect behavior and resultant weaknesses. There are multiple ways in which this weakness can be introduced
column641: including: the wrong variable or reference; an incorrect number of arguments; incorrect order of arguments; wrong type of arguments; or wrong value."
column644: name:"Use of Multiple Resources with Duplicate Identifier"
column646: description:"The product uses multiple resources that can have the same identifier
column647: in a context in which unique identifiers are required. If the product assumes that each resource has a unique identifier
column648: the product could operate on the wrong resource if attackers can cause multiple resources to be associated with the same identifier."

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
In the following Java example the code performs some complex math when specific test conditions are met. The math is the same in each case and the equations are repeated within the code. Unfortunately if a future change needs to be made then that change needs to be made in all locations. This opens the door to mistakes being made and the changes not being made in the same way in each instance.
It is recommended to place the complex math into its own function and then call that function whenever necessary.
"

column663: name:"Data Element Aggregating an Excessively Large Number of Non-Primitive Elements"
column665: description:"The product uses a data element that has an excessively large number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column666: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"excessively large\" may vary for each product or developer
column667: CISQ recommends a default of 5 sub-elements."
column670: name:"Architecture with Number of Horizontal Layers Outside of Expected Range"
column672: description:"The product's architecture contains too many - or too few - horizontal layers. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column673: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. While the interpretation of \"expected range\" may vary for each product or developer
column674: CISQ recommends a default minimum of 4 layers and maximum of 8 layers."
column677: name:"Parent Class with a Virtual Destructor and a Child Class without a Virtual Destructor"
column679: description:"A parent class has a virtual destructor method
column680: but the parent has a child class that does not have a virtual destructor. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably
column681: since the child might not perform essential destruction operations. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column682: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability
column686: name:"Creation of Immutable Text Using String Concatenation"
column688: description:"The product creates an immutable text string using string concatenation operations. When building a string via a looping feature (e.g.
column690: the use of += to append to the existing string will result in the creation of a new object with each iteration. This programming pattern can be inefficient in comparison with use of text buffer data elements. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column691: then this could be influenced to create performance problem."
column694: name:"Invokable Control Element with Large Number of Outward Calls"
column696: description:"The code contains callable control elements that contain an excessively large number of references to other application objects external to the context of the callable
column697: i.e. a Fan-Out value that is excessively large. While the interpretation of \"excessively large Fan-Out value\" may vary for each product or developer
column698: CISQ recommends a default of 5 referenced objects. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column699: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities."
column702: name:"Excessive Data Query Operations in a Large Data Table"
column704: description:"The product performs a data query with a large number of joins and sub-queries on a large data table. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column705: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"large data table\" and \"large number of joins or sub-queries\" may vary for each product or developer
column706: CISQ recommends a default of 1 million rows for a \"large\" data table
column708: and a default minimum of 3 sub-queries."
column711: name:"Excessive Platform Resource Consumption within a Loop"
column713: description:"The product has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or indirectly consumes platform resources
column717: or file descriptors. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If an attacker can influence the number of iterations in the loop
column718: then this performance problem might allow a denial of service by consuming more platform resources than intended."
column721: name:"Creation of Class Instance within a Static Code Block"
column723: description:"A static code block creates an instance of a class. This pattern identifies situations where a storable data element or member data element is initialized with a value in a block of code which is declared as static. This issue can make the product perform more slowly by performing initialization before it is needed. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column724: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column727: name:"Runtime Resource Management Control Element in a Component Built to Run on Application Servers"
column729: description:"The product uses deployed components from application servers
column730: but it also uses low-level functions\/methods for management of resources
column731: instead of the API provided by the application server. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column732: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column737: description:"The product contains a serializable data element that does not have an associated serialization method. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably
column738: e.g. by triggering an exception. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column739: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability. As examples
column740: the serializable nature of a data element comes from a serializable SerializableAttribute attribute in .NET and the inheritance from the java.io.Serializable interface in Java."
column743: name:"Excessive Execution of Sequential Searches of Data Resource"
column745: description:"The product contains a data query against an SQL table or view that is configured in a way that does not utilize an index and may cause sequential searches to be performed. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column746: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability."

column754: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability. As examples

column760: description:"The source code contains a block that does not contain any code
column762: the block is empty. Empty code blocks can occur in the bodies of conditionals
column765: etc. While an empty code block might be intentional
column766: it might also indicate incomplete implementation
column769: etc. For some programming languages and constructs

column774: name:"Data Resource Access without Use of Connection Pooling"
column776: description:"The product accesses a data resource through a database without using a connection pooling capability. This issue can make the product perform more slowly
column777: as connection pools allow connections to be reused without the overhead and time consumption of opening and closing a new connection. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column778: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column781: name:"Non-SQL Invokable Control Element with Excessive Number of Data Resource Accesses"
column783: description:"The product contains a client with a function or method that contains a large number of data accesses\/queries that are sent through a data manager
column785: does not use efficient database capabilities. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column786: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"large number of data accesses\/queries\" may vary for each product or developer
column787: CISQ recommends a default maximum of 2 data accesses per function\/method."
column790: name:"Parent Class without Virtual Destructor Method"
column792: description:"A parent class contains one or more child classes
column793: but the parent class does not have a virtual destructor method. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably due to undefined or unexpected behaviors. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column794: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column797: name:"Class Instance Self Destruction Control Element"
column799: description:"The code contains a class instance that calls the method or function to delete or destroy itself. For example
column801: \"delete this\" will cause the object to delete itself. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column802: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column805: name:"Invokable Control Element with Excessive File or Data Access Operations"
column807: description:"A function or method contains too many operations that utilize a data manager or file resource. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column808: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. While the interpretation of \"too many operations\" may vary for each product or developer
column809: CISQ recommends a default maximum of 7 operations for the same data manager or file."
column812: name:"Invokable Control Element with Excessive Volume of Commented-out Code"
column817: etc. contains an excessive amount of code that has been commented out within its body. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column818: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. While the interpretation of \"excessive volume\" may vary for each product or developer
column819: CISQ recommends a default threshold of 2% of commented code."
column822: name:"Class with Virtual Method without a Virtual Destructor"
column824: description:"A class contains a virtual method
column825: but the method does not have an associated virtual destructor. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably
column826: e.g. due to undefined behavior. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column827: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column830: name:"Large Data Table with Excessive Number of Indices"
column832: description:"The product uses a large data table that contains an excessively large number of indices. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker

column837: name:"Use of Object without Invoking Destructor Method"
column839: description:"The product contains a method that accesses an object but does not later invoke the element's associated finalize\/destructor method. This issue can make the product perform more slowly by retaining memory and\/or other resources longer than necessary. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column840: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column843: name:"Use of Same Invokable Control Element in Multiple Architectural Layers"
column845: description:"The product uses the same control element across multiple architectural layers. This issue makes it more difficult to understand and maintain the product
column846: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities."
column849: name:"Excessive Index Range Scan for a Data Resource"
column851: description:"The product contains an index range scan for a large data table
column852: but the scan can cover a large number of rows. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column853: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"large data table\" and \"excessive index range\" may vary for each product or developer
column854: CISQ recommends a threshold of 1000000 table rows and a threshold of 10 for the index range."
column857: name:"Persistent Storable Data Element without Associated Comparison Control Element"
column859: description:"The product uses a storable data element that does not have all of the associated functions or methods that are necessary to support comparison. For example
column861: a class that is made persistent requires both hashCode() and equals() methods to be defined. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably
column862: due to incorrect or unexpected comparison results. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column863: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column866: name:"Data Element containing Pointer Item without Proper Copy Control Element"
column868: description:"The code contains a data element with a pointer that does not have an associated copy or constructor method. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column869: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability."

column1003: name:"Incorrect Use of Autoboxing and Unboxing for Performance Critical Operations"
column1006: which may introduce inefficiencies into performance-critical operations. Languages such as Java and C# support automatic conversion through their respective compilers from primitive types into objects of the corresponding wrapper classes
column1008: a compiler might convert an int to Integer (called autoboxing) or an Integer to int (called unboxing). This eliminates forcing the programmer to perform these conversions manually
column1009: which makes the code cleaner. However
column1010: this feature comes at a cost of performance and can lead to resource exhaustion and impact availability when used with generic collections. Therefore
column1011: they should not be used for scientific computing or other performance critical operations. They are only suited to support \"impedance mismatch\" between reference types and primitives."

column1075: a malformed HTTP request is sent to a website that includes a proxy server and a web server with the intent of poisoning the cache to associate one webpage with another malicious webpage.\nWhen this request is sent to the proxy server
column1076: the proxy server parses the first four lines of the POST request and encounters the two \"Content-Length\" headers. The proxy server ignores the first header
column1077: so it assumes the request has a body of length 54 bytes. Therefore
column1078: it treats the data in the next three lines that contain exactly 54 bytes as the first request's body:\nThe proxy then parses the remaining bytes
column1079: which it treats as the client's second request:\nThe original request is forwarded by the proxy server to the web server. Unlike the proxy
column1080: the web server uses the first \"Content-Length\" header and considers that the first POST request has no body.\nBecause the web server has assumed the original POST request was length 0
column1081: it parses the second request that follows
column1082: i.e. for GET \/poison.html:\nNote that the \"Bla:\" header is treated as a regular header
column1083: so it is not parsed as a separate GET request.\nThe requests the web server sees are \"POST \/foobar.html\" and \"GET \/poison.html\"
column1084: so it sends back two responses with the contents of the \"foobar.html\" page and the \"poison.html\" page
column1085: respectively. The proxy matches these responses to the two requests it thinks were sent by the client - \"POST \/foobar.html\" and \"GET \/page_to_poison.html\". If the response is cacheable
column1086: the proxy caches the contents of \"poison.html\" under the URL \"page_to_poison.html\"
column1087: and the cache is poisoned! Any client requesting \"page_to_poison.html\" from the proxy would receive the \"poison.html\" page.\nWhen a website includes both a proxy server and a web server
column1088: some protection against this type of attack can be achieved by installing a web application firewall
column1089: or using a web server that includes a stricter HTTP parsing procedure or make all webpages non-cacheable.\nAdditionally
column1090: if a web application includes a Java servlet for processing requests
column1091: the servlet can check for multiple \"Content-Length\" headers and if they are found the servlet can return an error response thereby preventing the poison page to be cached
column1092: as shown below.\nExample 2\nIn the following example

column1096: and the firewall treats the line with 49
column1097: 152 copies of \"z\" and the lines with an additional lines with 71 bytes as its body (49
column1099: 223). The firewall then continues to parse what it thinks is the second request starting with the line with the third POST request.\nNote that there is no CRLF after the \"Bla: \" header so the POST in the line is parsed as the value of the \"Bla:\" header. Although the line contains the pattern identified with a worm (\"cmd.exe\")

column1102: \"cmd.exe\" is smuggled through the firewall.\nWhen the request is passed through the firewall the web server the first request is ignored because the web server does not find an expected \"Content-Type: application\/x-www-form-urlencoded\" header
column1103: and starts parsing the second request.\nThis second request has a content-length of 30 bytes

the web server processes the final POST as a separate third request and the "cmd.exe" worm is smuggled through the firewall to the web server.
To avoid this attack a Web server firewall product must be used that is designed to prevent this type of attack.

The interpretation of HTTP responses can be manipulated if response headers include a space between the header name and colon

column1107: allowing for HTTP response smuggling. This can be exploited in web browsers and other applications when used in combination with various proxy servers. For instance

column1109: notice the extra space after the Content-Length and Set-Cookie headers.\n"
column1110: name:"Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request\/Response Smuggling')"
column1117: description:"The product acts as an intermediary HTTP agent (such as a proxy or firewall) in the data flow between two entities such as a client and server
column1118: but it does not interpret malformed HTTP requests or responses in ways that are consistent with how the messages will be processed by those entities that are at the ultimate destination. HTTP requests or responses (\"messages\") can be malformed or unexpected in ways that cause web servers or clients to interpret the messages in different ways than intermediary HTTP agents such as load balancers
column1123: an adversary may be able to add duplicate or different header fields that a client or server might interpret as one set of messages
column1124: whereas the intermediary might interpret the same sequence of bytes as a different set of messages. For example
column1125: discrepancies can arise in how to handle duplicate headers like two Transfer-encoding (TE) or two Content-length (CL)
column1126: or the malicious HTTP message will have different headers for TE and CL. The inconsistent parsing and interpretation of messages can allow the adversary to \"smuggle\" a message to the client\/server without the intermediary being aware of it. This weakness is usually the result of the usage of outdated or incompatible HTTP protocol versions in the HTTP agents."

column1303: description:"The system's authorization functionality does not prevent one user from gaining access to another user's data or record by modifying the key value identifying the data. Retrieval of a user record occurs in the system based on some key value that is under user control. The key would typically identify a user-related record stored in the system and would be used to lookup that record for presentation to the user. It is likely that an attacker would have to be an authenticated user in the system. However
column1304: the authorization process would not properly check the data access operation to ensure that the authenticated user performing the operation has sufficient entitlements to perform the requested data access
column1305: hence bypassing any other authorization checks present in the system. For example
column1306: attackers can look at places where user specific data is retrieved (e.g. search screens) and determine whether the key for the item being looked up is controllable externally. The key may be a hidden field in the HTML form field
column1307: might be passed as a URL parameter or as an unencrypted cookie variable
column1308: then in each of these cases it will be possible to tamper with the key value. One manifestation of this weakness is when a system uses sequential or otherwise easily-guessable session IDs that would allow one user to easily switch to another user's session and read\/modify their data."
column1310: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA famous example of this type of weakness being exploited is the eBay attack. eBay always displays the user id of the highest bidder. In the final minutes of the auction
column1311: one of the bidders could try to log in as the highest bidder three times. After three incorrect log in attempts
column1312: eBay password throttling would kick in and lock out the highest bidder's account for some time. An attacker could then make their own bid and their victim would not have a chance to place the counter bid because they would be locked out. Thus an attacker could win the auction.\n"
column1313: name:"Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password"
column1315: description:"The product contains a mechanism for users to recover or change their passwords without knowing the original password
column1316: but the mechanism is weak. It is common for an application to have a mechanism that provides a means for a user to gain access to their account in the event they forget their password. Very often the password recovery mechanism is weak
column1317: which has the effect of making it more likely that it would be possible for a person other than the legitimate system user to gain access to that user's account. Weak password recovery schemes completely undermine a strong password authentication scheme. This weakness may be that the security question is too easy to guess or find an answer to (e.g. because the question is too common
column1318: or the answers can be found using social media). Or there might be an implementation weakness in the password recovery mechanism code that may for instance trick the system into e-mailing the new password to an e-mail account other than that of the user. There might be no throttling done on the rate of password resets so that a legitimate user can be denied service by an attacker if an attacker tries to recover their password in a rapid succession. The system may send the original password to the user rather than generating a new temporary password. In summary
column1320: if not carefully designed and implemented can often become the system's weakest link that can be misused in a way that would allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access to the system."

a server object creates a server socket and accepts client connections to the socket. For every client connection to the socket a separate thread object is generated using the ClientSocketThread class that handles request made by the client through the socket.
In this example there is no limit to the number of client connections and client threads that are created. Allowing an unlimited number of client connections and threads could potentially overwhelm the system and system resources.

column1482: description:"Covert timing channels convey information by modulating some aspect of system behavior over time
column1483: so that the program receiving the information can observe system behavior and infer protected information. In some instances
column1484: knowing when data is transmitted between parties can provide a malicious user with privileged information. Also
column1485: externally monitoring the timing of operations can potentially reveal sensitive data. For example
column1486: a cryptographic operation can expose its internal state if the time it takes to perform the operation varies
column1487: based on the state. Covert channels are frequently classified as either storage or timing channels. Some examples of covert timing channels are the system's paging rate
column1488: the time a certain transaction requires to execute
column1489: and the time it takes to gain access to a shared bus."

column1528: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nAn excellent example of covert storage channels in a well known application is the ICMP error message echoing functionality. Due to ambiguities in the ICMP RFC
column1529: many IP implementations use the memory within the packet for storage or calculation. For this reason
column1530: certain fields of certain packets -- such as ICMP error packets which echo back parts of received messages -- may contain flaws or extra information which betrays information about the identity of the target operating system. This information is then used to build up evidence to decide the environment of the target. This is the first crucial step in determining if a given system is vulnerable to a particular flaw and what changes must be made to malicious code to mount a successful attack.\n"
column1533: description:"A covert storage channel transfers information through the setting of bits by one program and the reading of those bits by another. What distinguishes this case from that of ordinary operation is that the bits are used to convey encoded information. Covert storage channels occur when out-of-band data is stored in messages for the purpose of memory reuse. Covert channels are frequently classified as either storage or timing channels. Examples would include using a file intended to hold only audit information to convey user passwords--using the name of a file or perhaps status bits associated with it that can be read by all users to signal the contents of the file. Steganography
column1534: concealing information in such a manner that no one but the intended recipient knows of the existence of the message
column1535: is a good example of a covert storage channel."
column1538: name:"Improper Enforcement of Message Integrity During Transmission in a Communication Channel"
column1540: description:"The product establishes a communication channel with an endpoint and receives a message from that endpoint
column1541: but it does not sufficiently ensure that the message was not modified during transmission. Attackers might be able to modify the message and spoof the endpoint by interfering with the data as it crosses the network or by redirecting the connection to a system under their control."

column1556: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis code listens on a port for DNS requests and sends the result to the requesting address.\nThis code sends a DNS record to a requesting IP address. UDP allows the source IP address to be easily changed ('spoofed')

column1559: name:"Incorrectly Specified Destination in a Communication Channel"
column1563: description:"The product creates a communication channel to initiate an outgoing request to an actor
column1564: but it does not correctly specify the intended destination for that actor. Attackers at the destination may be able to spoof trusted servers to steal data or cause a denial of service. There are at least two distinct weaknesses that can cause the product to communicate with an unintended destination: If the product allows an attacker to control which destination is specified
column1565: then the attacker can cause it to connect to an untrusted or malicious destination. For example
column1566: because UDP is a connectionless protocol
column1567: UDP packets can be spoofed by specifying a false source address in the packet; when the server receives the packet and sends a reply
column1568: it will specify a destination by using the source of the incoming packet - i.e.
column1569: the false source. The server can then be tricked into sending traffic to the wrong host
column1570: which is effective for hiding the real source of an attack and for conducting a distributed denial of service (DDoS). As another example
column1571: server-side request forgery (SSRF) and XML External Entity (XXE) can be used to trick a server into making outgoing requests to hosts that cannot be directly accessed by the attacker due to firewall restrictions. If the product incorrectly specifies the destination
column1572: then an attacker who can control this destination might be able to spoof trusted servers. While the most common occurrence is likely due to misconfiguration by an administrator
column1573: this can be resultant from other weaknesses. For example
column1574: the product might incorrectly parse an e-mail or IP address and send sensitive data to an unintended destination. As another example
column1575: an Android application may use a \"sticky broadcast\" to communicate with a receiver for a particular application
column1576: but since sticky broadcasts can be processed by *any* receiver
column1577: this can allow a malicious application to access restricted data that was only intended for a different application."
column1580: name:"Data Element Aggregating an Excessively Large Number of Non-Primitive Elements"
column1582: description:"The product uses a data element that has an excessively large number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column1583: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"excessively large\" may vary for each product or developer
column1584: CISQ recommends a default of 5 sub-elements."
column1589: description:"The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself

column1594: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker

column1600: description:"The product contains a class with inheritance from more than one concrete class. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product

column1604: name:"Invokable Control Element with Variadic Parameters"
column1606: description:"A named-callable or method control element has a signature that supports a variable (variadic) number of parameters or arguments. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column1607: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability. With variadic arguments
column1608: it can be difficult or inefficient for manual analysis to be certain of which function\/method is being invoked."

column1614: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"too many data queries\" may vary for each product or developer

column1744: description:"The product checks the state of a resource before using that resource

column1781: name:"Unsynchronized Access to Shared Data in a Multithreaded Context"
column1783: description:"The product does not properly synchronize shared data
column1784: such as static variables across threads
column1785: which can lead to undefined behavior and unpredictable data changes. Within servlets
column1786: shared static variables are not protected from concurrent access
column1787: but servlets are multithreaded. This is a typical programming mistake in J2EE applications
column1788: since the multithreading is handled by the framework. When a shared variable can be influenced by an attacker
column1789: one thread could wind up modifying the variable to contain data that is not valid for a different thread that is also using the data within the variable. Note that this weakness is not unique to servlets."
column1791: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code attempts to synchronize on an object
column1792: but does not execute anything in the synchronized block. This does not actually accomplish anything and may be a sign that a programmer is wrestling with synchronization but has not yet achieved the result they intend.\nInstead
column1794: the synchronized statement should contain procedures that access or modify data that is exposed to multiple threads. For example
column1795: consider a scenario in which several threads are accessing student records at the same time. The method which sets the student ID to a new value will need to make sure that nobody else is accessing this data at the same time and will require synchronization.\n"
column1798: description:"The product contains an empty synchronized block. An empty synchronized block does not actually accomplish any synchronization and may indicate a troubled section of code. column1890: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA system does not enforce the changing of passwords every certain period.\n"
column1893: description:"The product does not have a mechanism in place for managing password aging. Password aging (or password rotation) is a policy that forces users to change their passwords after a defined time period passes

column1919: name:"Use of a Key Past its Expiration Date"
column1921: description:"The product uses a cryptographic key or password past its expiration date
column1922: which diminishes its safety significantly by increasing the timing window for cracking attacks against that key. While the expiration of keys does not necessarily ensure that they are compromised
column1923: it is a significant concern that keys which remain in use for prolonged periods of time have a decreasing probability of integrity. For this reason
column1924: it is important to replace keys within a period of time proportional to their strength."
column1929: description:"The product does not require that users should have strong passwords
column1930: which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism."
column1935: description:"Login pages do not use adequate measures to protect the user name and password while they are in transit from the client to the server. "
column1940: description:"The product does not mask passwords during entry
column1941: increasing the potential for attackers to observe and capture passwords. "

column1953: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA famous example of this type of weakness being exploited is the eBay attack. eBay always displays the user id of the highest bidder. In the final minutes of the auction
column1954: one of the bidders could try to log in as the highest bidder three times. After three incorrect log in attempts
column1955: eBay password throttling would kick in and lock out the highest bidder's account for some time. An attacker could then make their own bid and their victim would not have a chance to place the counter bid because they would be locked out. Thus an attacker could win the auction.\n"
column1956: name:"Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password"
column1958: description:"The product contains a mechanism for users to recover or change their passwords without knowing the original password
column1959: but the mechanism is weak. It is common for an application to have a mechanism that provides a means for a user to gain access to their account in the event they forget their password. Very often the password recovery mechanism is weak
column1960: which has the effect of making it more likely that it would be possible for a person other than the legitimate system user to gain access to that user's account. Weak password recovery schemes completely undermine a strong password authentication scheme. This weakness may be that the security question is too easy to guess or find an answer to (e.g. because the question is too common
column1961: or the answers can be found using social media). Or there might be an implementation weakness in the password recovery mechanism code that may for instance trick the system into e-mailing the new password to an e-mail account other than that of the user. There might be no throttling done on the rate of password resets so that a legitimate user can be denied service by an attacker if an attacker tries to recover their password in a rapid succession. The system may send the original password to the user rather than generating a new temporary password. In summary
column1963: if not carefully designed and implemented can often become the system's weakest link that can be misused in a way that would allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access to the system."

column1974: these vulnerabilities often allowed adversaries to change how the products operated

column2000: such as a password or cryptographic key
column2001: which it uses for its own inbound authentication
column2003: or encryption of internal data. Hard-coded credentials typically create a significant hole that allows an attacker to bypass the authentication that has been configured by the product administrator. This hole might be difficult for the system administrator to detect. Even if detected
column2004: it can be difficult to fix
column2005: so the administrator may be forced into disabling the product entirely. There are two main variations: Inbound: the product contains an authentication mechanism that checks the input credentials against a hard-coded set of credentials. Outbound: the product connects to another system or component
column2006: and it contains hard-coded credentials for connecting to that component. In the Inbound variant
column2007: a default administration account is created
column2008: and a simple password is hard-coded into the product and associated with that account. This hard-coded password is the same for each installation of the product
column2009: and it usually cannot be changed or disabled by system administrators without manually modifying the program
column2010: or otherwise patching the product. If the password is ever discovered or published (a common occurrence on the Internet)
column2011: then anybody with knowledge of this password can access the product. Finally
column2012: since all installations of the product will have the same password
column2014: this enables massive attacks such as worms to take place. The Outbound variant applies to front-end systems that authenticate with a back-end service. The back-end service may require a fixed password which can be easily discovered. The programmer may simply hard-code those back-end credentials into the front-end product. Any user of that program may be able to extract the password. Client-side systems with hard-coded passwords pose even more of a threat
column2015: since the extraction of a password from a binary is usually very simple."
column2018: name:"Use of Password Hash With Insufficient Computational Effort"
column2025: description:"The product generates a hash for a password
column2026: but it uses a scheme that does not provide a sufficient level of computational effort that would make password cracking attacks infeasible or expensive. Many password storage mechanisms compute a hash and store the hash
column2027: instead of storing the original password in plaintext. In this design
column2028: authentication involves accepting an incoming password
column2030: and comparing it to the stored hash. Many hash algorithms are designed to execute quickly with minimal overhead
column2032: this efficiency is a problem for password storage
column2033: because it can reduce an attacker's workload for brute-force password cracking. If an attacker can obtain the hashes through some other method (such as SQL injection on a database that stores hashes)
column2034: then the attacker can store the hashes offline and use various techniques to crack the passwords by computing hashes efficiently. Without a built-in workload
column2035: modern attacks can compute large numbers of hashes
column2036: or even exhaust the entire space of all possible passwords
column2037: within a very short amount of time
column2038: using massively-parallel computing (such as cloud computing) and GPU
column2040: or FPGA hardware. In such a scenario
column2041: an efficient hash algorithm helps the attacker. There are several properties of a hash scheme that are relevant to its strength against an offline
column2042: massively-parallel attack: The amount of CPU time required to compute the hash (\"stretching\") The amount of memory required to compute the hash (\"memory-hard\" operations) Including a random value
column2044: as input to the hash computation (\"salting\") Given a hash
column2045: there is no known way of determining an input (e.g.
column2046: a password) that produces this hash value
column2047: other than by guessing possible inputs (\"one-way\" hashing) Relative to the number of all possible hashes that can be generated by the scheme
column2048: there is a low likelihood of producing the same hash for multiple different inputs (\"collision resistance\") Note that the security requirements for the product may vary depending on the environment and the value of the passwords. Different schemes might not provide all of these properties
column2049: yet may still provide sufficient security for the environment. Conversely
column2050: a solution might be very strong in preserving one property
column2051: which still being very weak for an attack against another property
column2052: or it might not be able to significantly reduce the efficiency of a massively-parallel attack."
