column2100: description:"The product uses an algorithm that produces a digest (output value) that does not meet security expectations for a hash function that allows an adversary to reasonably determine the original input (preimage attack)
column2101: find another input that can produce the same hash (2nd preimage attack)
column2102: or find multiple inputs that evaluate to the same hash (birthday attack). A hash function is defined as an algorithm that maps arbitrarily sized data into a fixed-sized digest (output) such that the following properties hold: 1. The algorithm is not invertible (also called \"one-way\" or \"not reversible\") 2. The algorithm is deterministic; the same input produces the same digest every time Building on this definition
column2103: a cryptographic hash function must also ensure that a malicious actor cannot leverage the hash function to have a reasonable chance of success at determining any of the following: 1. the original input (preimage attack)
column2104: given only the digest 2. another input that can produce the same digest (2nd preimage attack)
column2105: given the original input 3. a set of two or more inputs that evaluate to the same digest (birthday attack)
column2106: given the actor can arbitrarily choose the inputs to be hashed and can do so a reasonable amount of times What is regarded as \"reasonable\" varies by context and threat model
column2108: \"reasonable\" could cover any attack that is more efficient than brute force (i.e.
column2110: attempting half of all possible combinations). Note that some attacks might be more efficient than brute force but are still not regarded as achievable in the real world. Any algorithm does not meet the above conditions will generally be considered weak for general use in hashing. In addition to algorithmic weaknesses
column2111: a hash function can be made weak by using the hash in a security context that breaks its security guarantees. For example
column2112: using a hash function without a salt for storing passwords (that are sufficiently short) could enable an adversary to create a \"rainbow table\" [REF-637] to recover the password under certain conditions; this attack works against such hash functions as MD5

column2119: it would be more secure if it used a random number generator that did not produce predictable receipt identifiers

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
The following XML example code is a deployment descriptor for a Java web application deployed on a Sun Java Application Server. This deployment descriptor includes a session configuration property for configuring the session ID length.
This deployment descriptor has set the session ID length for this Java web application to 8 bytes (or 64 bits). The session ID length for Java web applications should be set to 16 bytes (128 bits) to prevent attackers from guessing and/or stealing a session ID and taking over a user's session.
Note for most application servers including the Sun Java Application Server the session ID length is by default set to 128 bits and should not be changed. And for many application servers the session ID length cannot be changed from this default setting. Check your application server documentation for the session ID length default setting and configuration options to ensure that the session ID length is set to 128 bits.
"

column2137: name:"Incorrect Usage of Seeds in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)"
column2142: description:"The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) but does not correctly manage seeds. PRNGs are deterministic and
column2144: they cannot actually create entropy. They rely on cryptographically secure and unique seeds for entropy so proper seeding is critical to the secure operation of the PRNG. Management of seeds could be broken down into two main areas: (1) protecting seeds as cryptographic material (such as a cryptographic key); (2) whenever possible
column2145: using a uniquely generated seed from a cryptographically secure source PRNGs require a seed as input to generate a stream of numbers that are functionally indistinguishable from random numbers. While the output is
column2148: the output of any PRNG is directly determined by the seed provided as input. If the seed can be ascertained by a third party
column2149: the entire output of the PRNG can be made known to them. As such
column2150: the seed should be kept secret and should ideally not be able to be guessed. For example
column2151: the current time may be a poor seed. Knowing the approximate time the PRNG was seeded greatly reduces the possible key space. Seeds do not necessarily need to be unique
column2152: but reusing seeds may open up attacks if the seed is discovered."

column2221: name:"Use of a Cryptographic Primitive with a Risky Implementation"
column2234: description:"To fulfill the need for a cryptographic primitive
column2235: the product implements a cryptographic algorithm using a non-standard
column2237: or disallowed\/non-compliant cryptographic implementation. Cryptographic protocols and systems depend on cryptographic primitives (and associated algorithms) as their basic building blocks. Some common examples of primitives are digital signatures
column2241: the notion of \"primitive\" can vary depending on point of view. See \"Terminology Notes\" for further explanation of some concepts. Cryptographic primitives are defined to accomplish one very specific task in a precisely defined and mathematically reliable fashion. For example
column2242: suppose that for a specific cryptographic primitive (such as an encryption routine)
column2243: the consensus is that the primitive can only be broken after trying out N different inputs (where the larger the value of N
column2244: the stronger the cryptography). For an encryption scheme like AES-256
column2245: one would expect N to be so large as to be infeasible to execute in a reasonable amount of time. If a vulnerability is ever found that shows that one can break a cryptographic primitive in significantly less than the expected number of attempts
column2246: then that primitive is considered weakened (or sometimes in extreme cases
column2247: colloquially it is \"broken\"). As a result
column2248: anything using this cryptographic primitive would now be considered insecure or risky. Thus
column2249: even breaking or weakening a seemingly small cryptographic primitive has the potential to render the whole system vulnerable
column2250: due to its reliance on the primitive. A historical example can be found in TLS when using DES. One would colloquially call DES the cryptographic primitive for transport encryption in this version of TLS. In the past
column2252: because no weaknesses were found in it; importantly
column2253: DES has a key length of 56 bits. Trying N=2^56 keys was considered impractical for most actors. Unfortunately
column2254: attacking a system with 56-bit keys is now practical via brute force
column2255: which makes defeating DES encryption practical. It is now practical for an adversary to read any information sent under this version of TLS and use this information to attack the system. As a result
column2256: it can be claimed that this use of TLS is weak
column2257: and that any system depending on TLS with DES could potentially render the entire system vulnerable to attack. Cryptographic primitives and associated algorithms are only considered safe after extensive research and review from experienced cryptographers from academia
column2259: and government entities looking for any possible flaws. Furthermore
column2260: cryptographic primitives and associated algorithms are frequently reevaluated for safety when new mathematical and attack techniques are discovered. As a result and over time
column2261: even well-known cryptographic primitives can lose their compliance status with the discovery of novel attacks that might either defeat the algorithm or reduce its robustness significantly. If ad-hoc cryptographic primitives are implemented
column2262: it is almost certain that the implementation will be vulnerable to attacks that are well understood by cryptographers
column2263: resulting in the exposure of sensitive information and other consequences. This weakness is even more difficult to manage for hardware-implemented deployment of cryptographic algorithms. First
column2264: because hardware is not patchable as easily as software
column2265: any flaw discovered after release and production typically cannot be fixed without a recall of the product. Secondly
column2266: the hardware product is often expected to work for years
column2267: during which time computation power available to the attacker only increases. Therefore
column2268: for hardware implementations of cryptographic primitives
column2269: it is absolutely essential that only strong

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
This code attempts to limit the access of a page to certain IP Addresses. It checks the 'HTTP_X_FORWARDED_FOR' header in case an authorized user is sending the request through a proxy.
The 'HTTP_X_FORWARDED_FOR' header can be user controlled and so should never be trusted. An attacker can falsify the header to gain access to the page.
This fixed code only trusts the 'REMOTE_ADDR' header and so avoids the issue:
Be aware that 'REMOTE_ADDR' can still be spoofed. This may seem useless because the server will send the response to the fake address and not the attacker
column2356: but this may still be enough to conduct an attack. For example
column2357: if the generatePage() function in this code is resource intensive
column2358: an attacker could flood the server with fake requests using an authorized IP and consume significant resources. This could be a serious DoS attack even though the attacker would never see the page's sensitive content.\n"

column2391: description:"The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission
column2392: such as a checksum. If integrity check values or \"checksums\" are omitted from a protocol
column2393: there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications
column2394: the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum
column2395: since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages
column2399: name:"Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value"
column2401: description:"The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or \"checksums\" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences."

column2687: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code obtains a URL from the query string and then redirects the user to that URL.\nThe problem with the above code is that an attacker could use this page as part of a phishing scam by redirecting users to a malicious site. For example
column2688:
assume the above code is in the file example.php. An attacker could supply a user with the following link:
The user sees the link pointing to the original trusted site (example.com) and does not realize the redirection that could take place.
Example 2
The following code is a Java servlet that will receive a GET request with a url parameter in the request to redirect the browser to the address specified in the url parameter. The servlet will retrieve the url parameter value from the request and send a response to redirect the browser to the url address.
The problem with this Java servlet code is that an attacker could use the RedirectServlet as part of a e-mail phishing scam to redirect users to a malicious site. An attacker could send an HTML formatted e-mail directing the user to log into their account by including in the e-mail the following link:
The user may assume that the link is safe since the URL starts with their trusted bank
column2690: the user will then be redirected to the attacker's web site (attacker.example.net) which the attacker may have made to appear very similar to bank.example.com. The user may then unwittingly enter credentials into the attacker's web page and compromise their bank account. A Java servlet should never redirect a user to a URL without verifying that the redirect address is a trusted site.\n"

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
This example code intends to take the name of a user and list the contents of that user's home directory. It is subject to the first variant of OS command injection.
The $userName variable is not checked for malicious input. An attacker could set the $userName variable to an arbitrary OS command such as:
Which would result in $command being:

column2731:
deleting the entire file system.
Also note that this example code is vulnerable to Path Traversal (CWE-22) and Untrusted Search Path (CWE-426) attacks.
Example 2
The following simple program accepts a filename as a command line argument and displays the contents of the file back to the user. The program is installed setuid root because it is intended for use as a learning tool to allow system administrators in-training to inspect privileged system files without giving them the ability to modify them or damage the system.
Because the program runs with root privileges
column2732: the call to system() also executes with root privileges. If a user specifies a standard filename
column2733: the call works as expected. However
column2734: if an attacker passes a string of the form \";rm -rf \/\"
column2735: then the call to system() fails to execute cat due to a lack of arguments and then plows on to recursively delete the contents of the root partition.\nNote that if argv[1] is a very long argument
column2736:
then this issue might also be subject to a buffer overflow (CWE-120).
Example 3
This example is a web application that intends to perform a DNS lookup of a user-supplied domain name. It is subject to the first variant of OS command injection.
Suppose an attacker provides a domain name like this:
The "%3B" sequence decodes to the ";" character
column2737: and the %20 decodes to a space. The open() statement would then process a string like this:\nAs a result
column2738: the attacker executes the \"\/bin\/ls -l\" command and gets a list of all the files in the program's working directory. The input could be replaced with much more dangerous commands
column2739:
such as installing a malicious program on the server.
Example 4
The example below reads the name of a shell script to execute from the system properties. It is subject to the second variant of OS command injection.
If an attacker has control over this property
column2740: then they could modify the property to point to a dangerous program.\nExample 5\nIn the example below
column2741: a method is used to transform geographic coordinates from latitude and longitude format to UTM format. The method gets the input coordinates from a user through a HTTP request and executes a program local to the application server that performs the transformation. The method passes the latitude and longitude coordinates as a command-line option to the external program and will perform some processing to retrieve the results of the transformation and return the resulting UTM coordinates.\nHowever
column2742: the method does not verify that the contents of the coordinates input parameter includes only correctly-formatted latitude and longitude coordinates. If the input coordinates were not validated prior to the call to this method
column2743: a malicious user could execute another program local to the application server by appending '&' followed by the command for another program to the end of the coordinate string. The '&' instructs the Windows operating system to execute another program.\nExample 6\nThe following code is from an administrative web application designed to allow users to kick off a backup of an Oracle database using a batch-file wrapper around the rman utility and then run a cleanup.bat script to delete some temporary files. The script rmanDB.bat accepts a single command line parameter
column2744: which specifies what type of backup to perform. Because access to the database is restricted
column2745: the application runs the backup as a privileged user.\nThe problem here is that the program does not do any validation on the backuptype parameter read from the user. Typically the Runtime.exec() function will not execute multiple commands
column2746: but in this case the program first runs the cmd.exe shell in order to run multiple commands with a single call to Runtime.exec(). Once the shell is invoked
column2747: it will happily execute multiple commands separated by two ampersands. If an attacker passes a string of the form \"& del c:\\\\dbms\\\\*.*\"
column2748: then the application will execute this command along with the others specified by the program. Because of the nature of the application
column2749: it runs with the privileges necessary to interact with the database
column2750: which means whatever command the attacker injects will run with those privileges as well.\n"
column2751: name:"Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')"
column2765: description:"The product constructs all or part of an OS command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component
column2766: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended OS command when it is sent to a downstream component. This could allow attackers to execute unexpected
column2767: dangerous commands directly on the operating system. This weakness can lead to a vulnerability in environments in which the attacker does not have direct access to the operating system
column2768: such as in web applications. Alternately
column2769: if the weakness occurs in a privileged program
column2770: it could allow the attacker to specify commands that normally would not be accessible
column2771: or to call alternate commands with privileges that the attacker does not have. The problem is exacerbated if the compromised process does not follow the principle of least privilege
column2772: because the attacker-controlled commands may run with special system privileges that increases the amount of damage. There are at least two subtypes of OS command injection: The application intends to execute a single
column2773: fixed program that is under its own control. It intends to use externally-supplied inputs as arguments to that program. For example
column2774: the program might use system(\"nslookup [HOSTNAME]\") to run nslookup and allow the user to supply a HOSTNAME
column2775: which is used as an argument. Attackers cannot prevent nslookup from executing. However
column2776: if the program does not remove command separators from the HOSTNAME argument
column2777: attackers could place the separators into the arguments
column2778: which allows them to execute their own program after nslookup has finished executing. The application accepts an input that it uses to fully select which program to run
column2779: as well as which commands to use. The application simply redirects this entire command to the operating system. For example
column2780: the program might use \"exec([COMMAND])\" to execute the [COMMAND] that was supplied by the user. If the COMMAND is under attacker control
column2781: then the attacker can execute arbitrary commands or programs. If the command is being executed using functions like exec() and CreateProcess()
column2782: the attacker might not be able to combine multiple commands together in the same line. From a weakness standpoint
column2783: these variants represent distinct programmer errors. In the first variant
column2784: the programmer clearly intends that input from untrusted parties will be part of the arguments in the command to be executed. In the second variant
column2785: the programmer does not intend for the command to be accessible to any untrusted party
column2786: but the programmer probably has not accounted for alternate ways in which malicious attackers can provide input."

column2812: name:"Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')"
column2831: description:"The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users. Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities occur when: Untrusted data enters a web application
column2832: typically from a web request. The web application dynamically generates a web page that contains this untrusted data. During page generation
column2833: the application does not prevent the data from containing content that is executable by a web browser
column2840: etc. A victim visits the generated web page through a web browser
column2841: which contains malicious script that was injected using the untrusted data. Since the script comes from a web page that was sent by the web server
column2842: the victim's web browser executes the malicious script in the context of the web server's domain. This effectively violates the intention of the web browser's same-origin policy
column2843: which states that scripts in one domain should not be able to access resources or run code in a different domain. There are three main kinds of XSS: Type 1: Reflected XSS (or Non-Persistent) - The server reads data directly from the HTTP request and reflects it back in the HTTP response. Reflected XSS exploits occur when an attacker causes a victim to supply dangerous content to a vulnerable web application
column2844: which is then reflected back to the victim and executed by the web browser. The most common mechanism for delivering malicious content is to include it as a parameter in a URL that is posted publicly or e-mailed directly to the victim. URLs constructed in this manner constitute the core of many phishing schemes
column2845: whereby an attacker convinces a victim to visit a URL that refers to a vulnerable site. After the site reflects the attacker's content back to the victim
column2846: the content is executed by the victim's browser. Type 2: Stored XSS (or Persistent) - The application stores dangerous data in a database
column2849: or other trusted data store. At a later time
column2850: the dangerous data is subsequently read back into the application and included in dynamic content. From an attacker's perspective
column2851: the optimal place to inject malicious content is in an area that is displayed to either many users or particularly interesting users. Interesting users typically have elevated privileges in the application or interact with sensitive data that is valuable to the attacker. If one of these users executes malicious content
column2852: the attacker may be able to perform privileged operations on behalf of the user or gain access to sensitive data belonging to the user. For example
column2853: the attacker might inject XSS into a log message
column2854: which might not be handled properly when an administrator views the logs. Type 0: DOM-Based XSS - In DOM-based XSS
column2855: the client performs the injection of XSS into the page; in the other types
column2856: the server performs the injection. DOM-based XSS generally involves server-controlled
column2857: trusted script that is sent to the client
column2858: such as Javascript that performs sanity checks on a form before the user submits it. If the server-supplied script processes user-supplied data and then injects it back into the web page (such as with dynamic HTML)
column2859: then DOM-based XSS is possible. Once the malicious script is injected
column2860: the attacker can perform a variety of malicious activities. The attacker could transfer private information
column2861: such as cookies that may include session information
column2862: from the victim's machine to the attacker. The attacker could send malicious requests to a web site on behalf of the victim
column2863: which could be especially dangerous to the site if the victim has administrator privileges to manage that site. Phishing attacks could be used to emulate trusted web sites and trick the victim into entering a password
column2864: allowing the attacker to compromise the victim's account on that web site. Finally
column2865: the script could exploit a vulnerability in the web browser itself possibly taking over the victim's machine
column2866: sometimes referred to as \"drive-by hacking.\" In many cases
column2867: the attack can be launched without the victim even being aware of it. Even with careful users
column2868: attackers frequently use a variety of methods to encode the malicious portion of the attack
column2869: such as URL encoding or Unicode
column2870: so the request looks less suspicious."

column4224: description:"The product does not properly prevent a person's private
column4225: personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected. There are many types of sensitive information that products must protect from attackers
column4231: and an individual's personal (private) information. Private personal information may include a password
column4236: etc. Private information is important to consider whether the person is a user of the product
column4237: or part of a data set that is processed by the product. An exposure of private information does not necessarily prevent the product from working properly
column4238: and in fact the exposure might be intended by the developer
column4239: e.g. as part of data sharing with other organizations. However
column4240: the exposure of personal private information can still be undesirable or explicitly prohibited by law or regulation. Some types of private information include: Government identifiers
column4241: such as Social Security Numbers Contact information
column4242: such as home addresses and telephone numbers Geographic location - where the user is (or was) Employment history Financial data - such as credit card numbers
column4247: or audio Behavioral patterns - such as web surfing history
column4249: etc. Relationships (and types of relationships) with others - family
column4258: prescription records Account passwords and other credentials Some of this information may be characterized as PII (Personally Identifiable Information)
column4260: etc. Categories of private information may overlap or vary based on the intended usage or the policies and practices of a particular industry. Sometimes data that is not labeled as private can have a privacy implication in a different context. For example
column4261: student identification numbers are usually not considered private because there is no explicit and publicly-available mapping to an individual student's personal information. However
column4262: if a school generates identification numbers based on student social security numbers
column4263: then the identification numbers should be considered private."

column4286: name:"Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere"
column4288: description:"The product does not properly prevent sensitive system-level information from being accessed by unauthorized actors who do not have the same level of access to the underlying system as the product does. Network-based products
column4290: often run on top of an operating system or similar environment. When the product communicates with outside parties
column4291: details about the underlying system are expected to remain hidden
column4292: such as path names for data files
column4296: etc. This system information may be provided by the product itself
column4297: or buried within diagnostic or debugging messages. Debugging information helps an adversary learn about the system and form an attack plan. An information exposure occurs when system data or debugging information leaves the program through an output stream or logging function that makes it accessible to unauthorized parties. Using other weaknesses
column4298: an attacker could cause errors to occur; the response to these errors can reveal detailed system information
column4299: along with other impacts. An attacker can use messages that reveal technologies
column4301: and product versions to tune the attack against known vulnerabilities in these technologies. A product may use diagnostic methods that provide significant implementation details such as stack traces as part of its error handling mechanism."
column4304: name:"Use of Cache Containing Sensitive Information"
column4306: description:"The code uses a cache that contains sensitive information
column4307: but the cache can be read by an actor outside of the intended control sphere. Applications may use caches to improve efficiency when communicating with remote entities or performing intensive calculations. A cache maintains a pool of objects
column4313: or other resources to minimize the time it takes to initialize and access these resources. If the cache is accessible to unauthorized actors
column4314: attackers can read the cache and obtain this sensitive information."

column4323: name:"Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File"
column4326: description:"Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information. While logging all information may be helpful during development stages
column4327: it is important that logging levels be set appropriately before a product ships so that sensitive user data and system information are not accidentally exposed to potential attackers. Different log files may be produced and stored for: Server log files (e.g. server.log). This can give information on whatever application left the file. Usually this can give full path names and system information
column4328: and sometimes usernames and passwords. log files that are used for debugging"
column4331: name:"Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code"
column4333: description:"Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example
column4334: obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords."
column4337: name:"Storage of Sensitive Data in a Mechanism without Access Control"
column4339: description:"The product stores sensitive information in a file system or device that does not have built-in access control. While many modern file systems or devices utilize some form of access control in order to restrict access to data
column4340: not all storage mechanisms have this capability. For example
column4344: and USB devices are typically made accessible to any user within the system. This can become a problem when sensitive data is stored in these mechanisms in a multi-user environment
column4345: because anybody on the system can read or write this data. On Android devices
column4346: external storage is typically globally readable and writable by other applications on the device. External storage may also be easily accessible through the mobile device's USB connection or physically accessible through the device's memory card port."
column4349: name:"Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Metadata"
column4351: description:"The product prevents direct access to a resource containing sensitive information
column4352: but it does not sufficiently limit access to metadata that is derived from the original
column4353: sensitive information. Developers might correctly prevent unauthorized access to a database or other resource containing sensitive information
column4354: but they might not consider that portions of the original information might also be recorded in metadata
column4357: or other resources. If these resources are not also restricted
column4358: then attackers might be able to extract some or all of the original information
column4359: or otherwise infer some details. For example
column4360: an attacker could specify search terms that are known to be unique to a particular person
column4361: or view metadata such as activity or creation dates in order to identify usage patterns."

column4373: name:"Sensitive Information in Resource Not Removed Before Reuse"
column4381: description:"The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse
column4382: but it does not clear or \"zeroize\" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities. When resources are released
column4383: they can be made available for reuse. For example
column4385: an operating system may make the memory available to another process
column4386: or disk space may be reallocated when a file is deleted. As removing information requires time and additional resources
column4387: operating systems do not usually clear the previously written information. Even when the resource is reused by the same process
column4388: this weakness can arise when new data is not as large as the old data
column4389: which leaves portions of the old data still available. Equivalent errors can occur in other situations where the length of data is variable but the associated data structure is not. If memory is not cleared after use
column4390: the information may be read by less trustworthy parties when the memory is reallocated. This weakness can apply in hardware
column4391: such as when a device or system switches between power
column4393: or debug states during normal operation
column4394: or when execution changes to different users or privilege levels."

column4401: name:"External Initialization of Trusted Variables or Data Stores"
column4406: description:"The product initializes critical internal variables or data stores using inputs that can be modified by untrusted actors. A product system should be reluctant to trust variables that have been initialized outside of its trust boundary
column4407: especially if they are initialized by users. The variables may have been initialized incorrectly. If an attacker can initialize the variable
column4408: then they can influence what the vulnerable system will do."

column4445: name:"Initialization with Hard-Coded Network Resource Configuration Data"
column4447: description:"The product initializes data using hard-coded values that act as network resource identifiers. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably
column4448: e.g. if it runs in an environment does not use the hard-coded network resource identifiers. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker

column4452: name:"Excessive Use of Hard-Coded Literals in Initialization"
column4454: description:"The product initializes a data element using a hard-coded literal that is not a simple integer or static constant element. This issue makes it more difficult to modify or maintain the product

column4460: description:"The product initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator

column4462: under the assumption that the administrator can (or should) change the default value. However
column4463: this ease-of-use comes at a cost when the default is insecure and the administrator does not change it."

column4863: name:"Insufficient Precision or Accuracy of a Real Number"
column4869: description:"The product processes a real number with an implementation in which the number's representation does not preserve required accuracy and precision in its fractional part
column4870: causing an incorrect result. When a security decision or calculation requires highly precise
column4871: accurate numbers such as financial calculations or prices
column4872: then small variations in the number could be exploited by an attacker. There are multiple ways to store the fractional part of a real number in a computer. In all of these cases
column4873: there is a limit to the accuracy of recording a fraction. If the fraction can be represented in a fixed number of digits (binary or decimal)
column4874: there might not be enough digits assigned to represent the number. In other cases the number cannot be represented in a fixed number of digits due to repeating in decimal or binary notation (e.g. 0.333333...) or due to a transcendental number such as  or 2. Rounding of numbers can lead to situations where the computer results do not adequately match the result of sufficiently accurate math."

column4908: description:"The product parses numeric input assuming base 10 (decimal) values
column4909: but it does not account for inputs that use a different base number (radix). Frequently
column4910: a numeric input that begins with \"0\" is treated as octal
column4911: or \"0x\" causes it to be treated as hexadecimal
column4912: e.g. by the inet_addr() function. For example
column4914: or \"0x31\" is 49 decimal. Other bases may be used as well. If the developer assumes decimal-only inputs
column4915: the code could produce incorrect numbers when the inputs are parsed using a different base. This can result in unexpected and\/or dangerous behavior. For example
column4916: a \"0127.0.0.1\" IP address is parsed as octal due to the leading \"0\"
column4917: whose numeric value would be the same as 87.0.0.1 (decimal)
column4918: where the developer likely expected to use 127.0.0.1. The consequences vary depending on the surrounding code in which this weakness occurs
column4919: but they can include bypassing network-based access control using unexpected IP addresses or netmasks
column4920: or causing apparently-symbolic identifiers to be processed as if they are numbers. In web applications
column4921: this can enable bypassing of SSRF restrictions."

column5097: description:"The product obtains a value from an untrusted source
column5098: converts this value to a pointer
column5099: and dereferences the resulting pointer. An attacker can supply a pointer for memory locations that the product is not expecting. If the pointer is dereferenced for a write operation
column5100: the attack might allow modification of critical state variables
column5102: or execute code. If the dereferencing operation is for a read
column5103: then the attack might allow reading of sensitive data
column5105: or set a variable to an unexpected value (since the value will be read from an unexpected memory location). There are several variants of this weakness
column5106: including but not necessarily limited to: The untrusted value is directly invoked as a function call. In OS kernels or drivers where there is a boundary between \"userland\" and privileged memory spaces
column5107: an untrusted pointer might enter through an API or system call (see CWE-781 for one such example). Inadvertently accepting the value from an untrusted control sphere when it did not have to be accepted as input at all. This might occur when the code was originally developed to be run by a single user in a non-networked environment
column5108: and the code is then ported to or otherwise exposed to a networked environment."
column5129: description:"The product performs pointer arithmetic on a valid pointer
column5130: but it uses an offset that can point outside of the intended range of valid memory locations for the resulting pointer. While a pointer can contain a reference to any arbitrary memory location
column5131: a program typically only intends to use the pointer to access limited portions of memory
column5132: such as contiguous memory used to access an individual array. Programs may use offsets in order to access fields or sub-elements stored within structured data. The offset might be out-of-range if it comes from an untrusted source
column5133: is the result of an incorrect calculation
column5134: or occurs because of another error. If an attacker can control or influence the offset so that it points outside of the intended boundaries of the structure
column5135: then the attacker may be able to read or write to memory locations that are used elsewhere in the product. As a result
column5136: the attack might change the state of the product as accessed through program variables
column5137: cause a crash or instable behavior
column5138: and possibly lead to code execution."
column5158: description:"The product accesses or uses a pointer that has not been initialized. If the pointer contains an uninitialized value

column5160: leading to a denial of service. If the uninitialized pointer is used as a function call
column5161: then arbitrary functions could be invoked. If an attacker can influence the portion of uninitialized memory that is contained in the pointer
column5162: this weakness could be leveraged to execute code or perform other attacks. Depending on memory layout

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
The following XML example code is a deployment descriptor for a Java web application deployed on a Sun Java Application Server. This deployment descriptor includes a session configuration property for configuring the session ID length.
This deployment descriptor has set the session ID length for this Java web application to 8 bytes (or 64 bits). The session ID length for Java web applications should be set to 16 bytes (128 bits) to prevent attackers from guessing and/or stealing a session ID and taking over a user's session.
Note for most application servers including the Sun Java Application Server the session ID length is by default set to 128 bits and should not be changed. And for many application servers the session ID length cannot be changed from this default setting. Check your application server documentation for the session ID length default setting and configuration options to ensure that the session ID length is set to 128 bits.
"

column5353: name:"Incorrect Usage of Seeds in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)"
column5358: description:"The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) but does not correctly manage seeds. PRNGs are deterministic and
column5360: they cannot actually create entropy. They rely on cryptographically secure and unique seeds for entropy so proper seeding is critical to the secure operation of the PRNG. Management of seeds could be broken down into two main areas: (1) protecting seeds as cryptographic material (such as a cryptographic key); (2) whenever possible
column5361: using a uniquely generated seed from a cryptographically secure source PRNGs require a seed as input to generate a stream of numbers that are functionally indistinguishable from random numbers. While the output is
column5364: the output of any PRNG is directly determined by the seed provided as input. If the seed can be ascertained by a third party
column5365: the entire output of the PRNG can be made known to them. As such
column5366: the seed should be kept secret and should ideally not be able to be guessed. For example
column5367: the current time may be a poor seed. Knowing the approximate time the PRNG was seeded greatly reduces the possible key space. Seeds do not necessarily need to be unique
column5368: but reusing seeds may open up attacks if the seed is discovered."

column5378: description:"The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) in a security context

column5380: it can expose the cryptography to certain types of attacks. Often a pseudo-random number generator (PRNG) is not designed for cryptography. column5382: entropy sources on a system. While such PRNGs might have very useful features
column5383: these same features could be used to break the cryptography."

column5663: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis code allocates a socket and forks each time it receives a new connection.\nThe program does not track how many connections have been made
column5664: and it does not limit the number of connections. Because forking is a relatively expensive operation
column5665: an attacker would be able to cause the system to run out of CPU
column5667: or memory by making a large number of connections. Alternatively
column5668: an attacker could consume all available connections
column5669: preventing others from accessing the system remotely.\nExample 2\nIn the following example a server socket connection is used to accept a request to store data on the local file system using a specified filename. The method openSocketConnection establishes a server socket to accept requests from a client. When a client establishes a connection to this service the getNextMessage method is first used to retrieve from the socket the name of the file to store the data
column5670:
the openFileToWrite method will validate the filename and open a file to write to on the local file system. The getNextMessage is then used within a while loop to continuously read data from the socket and output the data to the file until there is no longer any data from the socket.
This example creates a situation where data can be dumped to a file on the local file system without any limits on the size of the file. This could potentially exhaust file or disk resources and/or limit other clients' ability to access the service.
Example 3
In the following example
column5671: the processMessage method receives a two dimensional character array containing the message to be processed. The two-dimensional character array contains the length of the message in the first character array and the message body in the second character array. The getMessageLength method retrieves the integer value of the length from the first character array. After validating that the message length is greater than zero
column5672: the body character array pointer points to the start of the second character array of the two-dimensional character array and memory is allocated for the new body character array.\nThis example creates a situation where the length of the body character array can be very large and will consume excessive memory
column5673: exhausting system resources. This can be avoided by restricting the length of the second character array with a maximum length check\nAlso
column5674: consider changing the type from 'int' to 'unsigned int'
column5675: so that you are always guaranteed that the number is positive. This might not be possible if the protocol specifically requires allowing negative values
column5676: or if you cannot control the return value from getMessageLength()
column5677: but it could simplify the check to ensure the input is positive
column5678: and eliminate other errors such as signed-to-unsigned conversion errors (CWE-195) that may occur elsewhere in the code.\nExample 4\nIn the following example
column5679:
a server object creates a server socket and accepts client connections to the socket. For every client connection to the socket a separate thread object is generated using the ClientSocketThread class that handles request made by the client through the socket.
In this example there is no limit to the number of client connections and client threads that are created. Allowing an unlimited number of client connections and threads could potentially overwhelm the system and system resources.
The server should limit the number of client connections and the client threads that are created. This can be easily done by creating a thread pool object that limits the number of threads that are generated.

column5802: description:"The product does not initialize a critical resource. Many resources require initialization before they can be properly used. If a resource is not initialized
column5803: it could contain unpredictable or expired data
column5804: or it could be initialized to defaults that are invalid. This can have security implications when the resource is expected to have certain properties or values."
column5809: description:"The product uses or accesses a file descriptor after it has been closed. After a file descriptor for a particular file or device has been released
column5810: it can be reused. The code might not write to the original file
column5811: since the reused file descriptor might reference a different file or device."
column5832: description:"The product uses a reference count to manage a resource
column5833: but it does not update or incorrectly updates the reference count. Reference counts can be used when tracking how many objects contain a reference to a particular resource
column5834: such as in memory management or garbage collection. When the reference count reaches zero
column5835: the resource can be de-allocated or reused because there are no more objects that use it. If the reference count accidentally reaches zero
column5836: then the resource might be released too soon
column5837: even though it is still in use. If all objects no longer use the resource
column5838: but the reference count is not zero
column5839: then the resource might not ever be released."

column5909: name:"Dangerous Signal Handler not Disabled During Sensitive Operations"
column5911: description:"The product uses a signal handler that shares state with other signal handlers
column5912: but it does not properly mask or prevent those signal handlers from being invoked while the original signal handler is still running. During the execution of a signal handler
column5913: it can be interrupted by another handler when a different signal is sent. If the two handlers share state - such as global variables - then an attacker can corrupt the state by sending another signal before the first handler has completed execution."

column5928: name:"Signal Handler with Functionality that is not Asynchronous-Safe"
column5935: description:"The product defines a signal handler that contains code sequences that are not asynchronous-safe
column5938: or it can be interrupted. This can lead to an unexpected system state with a variety of potential consequences depending on context
column5939: including denial of service and code execution. Signal handlers are typically intended to interrupt normal functionality of a program
column5941: in order to notify the process of an event. When a signal handler uses global or static variables
column5942: or invokes functions that ultimately depend on such state or its associated metadata
column5943: then it could corrupt system state that is being used by normal functionality. This could subject the program to race conditions or other weaknesses that allow an attacker to cause the program state to be corrupted. While denial of service is frequently the consequence
column5944: in some cases this weakness could be leveraged for code execution. There are several different scenarios that introduce this issue: Invocation of non-reentrant functions from within the handler. One example is malloc()
column5945: which modifies internal global variables as it manages memory. Very few functions are actually reentrant. Code sequences (not necessarily function calls) contain non-atomic use of global variables
column5947: that can be accessed by other functionality of the program
column5949: the same function is registered to handle multiple signals. The signal handler function is intended to run at most one time
column5950: but instead it can be invoked multiple times. This could happen by repeated delivery of the same signal
column5951: or by delivery of different signals that have the same handler function (CWE-831). Note that in some environments or contexts
column5952: it might be possible for the signal handler to be interrupted itself. If both a signal handler and the normal behavior of the product have to operate on the same set of state variables
column5953: and a signal is received in the middle of the normal execution's modifications of those variables
column5954: the variables may be in an incorrect or corrupt state during signal handler execution
column5955: and possibly still incorrect or corrupt upon return."

column5967: name:"Signal Handler Function Associated with Multiple Signals"
column5969: description:"The product defines a function that is used as a handler for more than one signal. While sometimes intentional and safe
column5970: when the same function is used to handle multiple signals
column5971: a race condition could occur if the function uses any state outside of its local declaration
column5972: such as global variables or non-reentrant functions
column5973: or has any side effects. An attacker could send one signal that invokes the handler function; in many OSes
column5974: this will typically prevent the same signal from invoking the handler again
column5975: at least until the handler function has completed execution. However
column5976: the attacker could then send a different signal that is associated with the same handler function. This could interrupt the original handler function while it is still executing. If there is shared state
column5977: then the state could be corrupted. This can lead to a variety of potential consequences depending on context
column5978: including denial of service and code execution. Another rarely-explored possibility arises when the signal handler is only designed to be executed once (if at all). By sending multiple signals
column5979: an attacker could invoke the function more than once. This may generate extra
column5980: unintended side effects. A race condition might not even be necessary; the attacker could send one signal

column5991: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following example demonstrates the weakness.\nIn this example
column5992: bar and baz will be passed by reference to doOtherStuff() which may change them.\nExample 2\nIn the following Java example
column5993: the BookStore class manages the sale of books in a bookstore
column5994: this class includes the member objects for the bookstore inventory and sales database manager classes. The BookStore class includes a method for updating the sales database and inventory when a book is sold. This method retrieves a Book object from the bookstore inventory object using the supplied ISBN number for the book class
column5995: then calls a method for the sales object to update the sales information and then calls a method for the inventory object to update inventory for the BookStore.\nHowever
column5996: in this example the Book object that is retrieved and passed to the method of the sales object could have its contents modified by the method. This could cause unexpected results when the book object is sent to the method for the inventory object to update the inventory.\nIn the Java programming language arguments to methods are passed by value
column5997: however in the case of objects a reference to the object is passed by value to the method. When an object reference is passed as a method argument a copy of the object reference is made within the method and therefore both references point to the same object. This allows the contents of the object to be modified by the method that holds the copy of the object reference. [REF-374]\nIn this case the contents of the Book object could be modified by the method of the sales object prior to the call to update the inventory.\nTo prevent the contents of the Book object from being modified
column5998: a copy of the Book object should be made before the method call to the sales object. In the following example a copy of the Book object is made using the clone() method and the copy of the Book object is passed to the method of the sales object. This will prevent any changes being made to the original Book object.\n"

column6030: name:"Unintended Reentrant Invocation of Non-reentrant Code Via Nested Calls"
column6033: This CVE covers several vulnerable scenarios enabled by abuse of the Class_Terminate feature in Microsoft VBScript. In one scenario, Class_Terminate is used to produce an undesirable re-entrance of ScriptingDictionary during execution of that object's destructor. In another scenario, a vulnerable condition results from a recursive entrance of a property setter method. This recursive invocation produces a second, spurious call to the Release method of a reference-counted object, causing a UAF when that object is freed prematurely. This vulnerability pattern has been popularized as \Double Kill\". [REF-1099]"]
column6035: the product performs a call that unintentionally produces a nested invocation of the non-reentrant code. In a complex product
column6036: a single function call may lead to many different possible code paths
column6037: some of which may involve deeply nested calls. It may be difficult to foresee all possible code paths that could emanate from a given function call. In some systems
column6038: an external actor can manipulate inputs to the system and thereby achieve a wide range of possible control flows. This is frequently a concern in products that execute scripts from untrusted sources. Examples of such products are web browsers and PDF readers. A weakness is present when one of the possible code paths resulting from a function call alters program state that the original caller assumes to be unchanged during the call."

column6067: name:"Use of Wrong Operator in String Comparison"
column6069: description:"The product uses the wrong operator when comparing a string
column6070: such as using \"==\" when the .equals() method should be used instead. In Java
column6071: using == or != to compare two strings for equality actually compares two objects for equality rather than their string values for equality. Chances are good that the two references will never be equal. While this weakness often only affects program correctness
column6072: if the equality is used for a security decision
column6073: the unintended comparison result could be leveraged to affect program security."

column6107: name:"Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in GUI"
column6109: description:"The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within the GUI. An attacker can often obtain data from a GUI
column6111: by using an API to directly access GUI objects such as windows and menus. Even if the information is encoded in a way that is not human-readable

column6116: name:"Product UI does not Warn User of Unsafe Actions"
column6123: description:"The product's user interface does not warn the user before undertaking an unsafe action on behalf of that user. This makes it easier for attackers to trick users into inflicting damage to their system. Product systems should warn users that a potentially dangerous action may occur if the user proceeds. For example
column6124: if the user downloads a file from an unknown source and attempts to execute the file on their machine
column6125: then the application's GUI can indicate that the file is unsafe."
column6128: name:"Insufficient UI Warning of Dangerous Operations"
column6130: description:"The user interface provides a warning to a user regarding dangerous or sensitive operations
column6131: but the warning is not noticeable enough to warrant attention. "
column6134: name:"Unimplemented or Unsupported Feature in UI"
column6139: description:"A UI function for a security feature appears to be supported and gives feedback to the user that suggests that it is supported
column6140: but the underlying functionality is not implemented. "
column6145: description:"A UI function is obsolete and the product does not warn the user. "
column6148: name:"The UI Performs the Wrong Action"
column6152: description:"The UI performs the wrong action with respect to the user's request. "
column6157: description:"The UI has multiple interpretations of user input but does not prompt the user when it selects the less secure interpretation. "
column6162: description:"The product does not mask passwords during entry
column6163: increasing the potential for attackers to observe and capture passwords. "

This results in most users not being able to distinguish between the two and assuming that the above URL is trusted and safe. The \"e\" is actually the \"CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER IE\" which is represented in HTML as the character &#x435

and "o" are also Cyrillic characters in this example. Viewing the source reveals a URL of "http://www.еxаmрlе.соm". An adversary can utilize this approach to perform an attack such as a phishing attack in order to drive traffic to a malicious website.
Example 2
The following displays an example of how creating usernames containing homoglyphs can lead to log forgery.
Assume an adversary visits a legitimate
column6171: trusted domain and creates an account named \"admin\"
column6172: except the 'a' and 'i' characters are Cyrillic characters instead of the expected ASCII. Any actions the adversary performs will be saved to the log file and look like they came from a legitimate administrator account.\nUpon closer inspection
column6173: the account that generated three of these log entries is \"аdmіn\". Only the third log entry is by the legitimate admin account. This makes it more difficult to determine which actions were performed by the adversary and which actions were executed by the legitimate \"admin\" account.\n"
column6174: name:"Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User"
column6182: description:"The product displays information or identifiers to a user
column6183: but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs)
column6184: which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended
column6187: or icons can be semantically distinct to a program
column6188: while appearing very similar or identical to a human user. These are referred to as homoglyphs. For example
column6189: the lowercase \"l\" (ell) and uppercase \"I\" (eye) have different character codes
column6190: but these characters can be displayed in exactly the same way to a user
column6191: depending on the font. This can also occur between different character sets. For example
column6192: the Latin capital letter \"A\" and the Greek capital letter \"\" (Alpha) are treated as distinct by programs
column6193: but may be displayed in exactly the same way to a user. Accent marks may also cause letters to appear very similar
column6194: such as the Latin capital letter grave mark \"?\" and its equivalent \"?\" with the acute accent. Adversaries can exploit this visual similarity for attacks such as phishing
column6195: e.g. by providing a link to an attacker-controlled hostname that looks like a hostname that the victim trusts. In a different use of homoglyphs
column6196: an adversary may create a back door username that is visually similar to the username of a regular user
column6197: which then makes it more difficult for a system administrator to detect the malicious username while reviewing logs."

column6200: if two users access the Servlet at approximately the same time
column6201: it is possible for the two request handler threads to interleave in the following way: Thread 1: assign \"Dick\" to name Thread 2: assign \"Jane\" to name Thread 1: print \"Jane
column6203: thanks for visiting!\" Thereby showing the first user the second user's name.\n"
column6204: name:"Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session"
column6206: description:"The product does not sufficiently enforce boundaries between the states of different sessions
column6207: causing data to be provided to
column6209: the wrong session. Data can \"bleed\" from one session to another through member variables of singleton objects
column6211: and objects from a shared pool. In the case of Servlets
column6212: developers sometimes do not understand that
column6213: unless a Servlet implements the SingleThreadModel interface
column6214: the Servlet is a singleton; there is only one instance of the Servlet
column6215: and that single instance is used and re-used to handle multiple requests that are processed simultaneously by different threads. A common result is that developers use Servlet member fields in such a way that one user may inadvertently see another user's data. In other words
column6216: storing user data in Servlet member fields introduces a data access race condition."

column6238: description:"The product supports a session in which more than one behavior must be performed by an actor
column6239: but it does not properly ensure that the actor performs the behaviors in the required sequence. By performing actions in an unexpected order
column6241: an attacker could manipulate the business logic of the product or cause it to enter an invalid state. In some cases
column6242: this can also expose resultant weaknesses. For example
column6243: a file-sharing protocol might require that an actor perform separate steps to provide a username
column6245: before being able to transfer files. If the file-sharing server accepts a password command followed by a transfer command
column6247: the product might still perform the transfer. Note that this is different than CWE-696
column6248: which focuses on when the product performs actions in the wrong sequence; this entry is closely related
column6249: but it is focused on ensuring that the actor performs actions in the correct sequence. Workflow-related behaviors include: Steps are performed in the expected order. Required steps are not omitted. Steps are not interrupted. Steps are performed in a timely fashion."
column6254: description:"The product does not contain sufficient technical or engineering documentation (whether on paper or in electronic form) that contains descriptions of all the relevant software\/hardware elements of the product
column6263: etc. When technical documentation is limited or lacking
column6264: products are more difficult to maintain. This indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. When using time-limited or labor-limited third-party\/in-house security consulting services (such as threat modeling
column6267: insufficient documentation can force those consultants to invest unnecessary time in learning how the product is organized
column6268: instead of focusing their expertise on finding the flaws or suggesting effective mitigations. With respect to hardware design
column6270: final manufacturer reference can make it difficult or impossible to evaluate the final product
column6271: including post-manufacture verification. One cannot ensure that design functionality or operation is within acceptable tolerances
column6273: and is free from unexpected behavior. Hardware-related documentation may include engineering artifacts such as hardware description language (HDLs)

column6281: name:"Semiconductor Defects in Hardware Logic with Security-Sensitive Implications"
column6283: description:"The security-sensitive hardware module contains semiconductor defects. A semiconductor device can fail for various reasons. While some are manufacturing and packaging defects
column6284: the rest are due to prolonged use or usage under extreme conditions. Some mechanisms that lead to semiconductor defects include encapsulation failure
column6292: and thermal\/electrical stress. These defects manifest as faults on chip-internal signals or registers
column6295: or intermediate signals being always 0 or always 1
column6296: and do not switch as expected. If such faults occur in security-sensitive hardware modules
column6297: security guarantees offered by the device will be compromised."
column6300: name:"Improper Scrubbing of Sensitive Data from Decommissioned Device"
column6302: description:"The product does not properly provide a capability for the product administrator to remove sensitive data at the time the product is decommissioned. A scrubbing capability could be missing
column6304: or incorrect. When a product is decommissioned - i.e.
column6305: taken out of service - best practices or regulatory requirements may require the administrator to remove or overwrite sensitive data first
column6306: i.e. \"scrubbing.\" Improper scrubbing of sensitive data from a decommissioned device leaves that data vulnerable to acquisition by a malicious actor. Sensitive data may include
column6311: and other forms of sensitive data."
column6313: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following example shows how an attacker can take advantage of a piece of confidential information that has not been protected from the OSAT.\nSuppose the preproduction device contains NVM (a storage medium that by definition\/design can retain its data without power)
column6314:
and this NVM contains a key that can unlock all the parts for that generation. An OSAT facility accidentally leaks the key.
Compromising a key that can unlock all the parts of a generation can be devastating to a chipmaker.
The likelihood of such a compromise can be reduced by ensuring all memories on the preproduction device are properly scrubbed.
"
column6315: name:"Unprotected Confidential Information on Device is Accessible by OSAT Vendors"
column6317: description:"The product does not adequately protect confidential information on the device from being accessed by Outsourced Semiconductor Assembly and Test (OSAT) vendors. In contrast to complete vertical integration of architecting
column6321: and testing chips all within a single organization
column6322: an organization can choose to simply architect and design a chip before outsourcing the rest of the process to OSAT entities (e.g.
column6323: external foundries and test houses). In the latter example
column6324: the device enters an OSAT facility in a much more vulnerable pre-production stage where many debug and test modes are accessible. Therefore
column6325: the chipmaker must place a certain level of trust with the OSAT. To counter this
column6326: the chipmaker often requires the OSAT partner to enter into restrictive non-disclosure agreements (NDAs). Nonetheless
column6327: OSAT vendors likely have many customers
column6328: which increases the risk of accidental sharing of information. There may also be a security vulnerability in the information technology (IT) system of the OSAT facility. Alternatively
column6329: a malicious insider at the OSAT facility may carry out an insider attack. Considering these factors
column6330: it behooves the chipmaker to minimize any confidential information in the device that may be accessible to the OSAT vendor. Logic errors during design or synthesis could misconfigure the interconnection of the debug components
column6331: which could provide improper authorization to sensitive information."
column6334: name:"DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase"
column6336: description:"The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established
column6337: which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product. DMA is included in a number of devices because it allows data transfer between the computer and the connected device
column6338: using direct hardware access to read or write directly to main memory without any OS interaction. An attacker could exploit this to access secrets. Several virtualization-based mitigations have been introduced to thwart DMA attacks. These are usually configured\/setup during boot time. However
column6339: certain IPs that are powered up before boot is complete (known as early boot IPs) may be DMA capable. Such IPs
column6341: could launch DMA attacks and gain access to assets that should otherwise be protected."
column6344: name:"Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control"
column6346: description:"The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled. After initial reset
column6347: System-on-Chip (SoC) fabric access controls and other security features need to be programmed by trusted firmware as part of the boot sequence. If untrusted IPs or peripheral microcontrollers are enabled first
column6348: then the untrusted component can master transactions on the hardware bus and target memory or other assets to compromise the SoC boot firmware."
column6350: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThere are several standard on-chip bus protocols used in modern SoCs to allow communication between components. There are a wide variety of commercially available hardware IP implementing the interconnect logic for these protocols. A bus connects components which initiate\/request communications such as processors and DMA controllers (bus masters) with peripherals which respond to requests. In a typical system
column6351: the privilege level or security designation of the bus master along with the intended functionality of each peripheral determine the security policy specifying which specific bus masters can access specific peripherals. This security policy (commonly referred to as a bus firewall) can be enforced using separate IP\/logic from the actual interconnect responsible for the data routing.\n"
column6352: name:"Hardware Logic with Insecure De-Synchronization between Control and Data Channels"
column6354: description:"The hardware logic for error handling and security checks can incorrectly forward data before the security check is complete. Many high-performance on-chip bus protocols and processor data-paths employ separate channels for control and data to increase parallelism and maximize throughput. Bugs in the hardware logic that handle errors and security checks can make it possible for data to be forwarded before the completion of the security checks. If the data can propagate to a location in the hardware observable to an attacker
column6355: loss of data confidentiality can occur. 'Meltdown' is a concrete example of how de-synchronization between data and permissions checking logic can violate confidentiality requirements. Data loaded from a page marked as privileged was returned to the cpu regardless of current privilege level for performance reasons. The assumption was that the cpu could later remove all traces of this data during the handling of the illegal memory access exception
column6356: but this assumption was proven false as traces of the secret data were not removed from the microarchitectural state."

column6365: name:"Improper Access Control for Volatile Memory Containing Boot Code"
column6367: description:"The product conducts a secure-boot process that transfers bootloader code from Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) into Volatile Memory (VM)
column6368: but it does not have sufficient access control or other protections for the Volatile Memory. Adversaries could bypass the secure-boot process and execute their own untrusted
column6369: malicious boot code. As a part of a secure-boot process
column6370: the read-only-memory (ROM) code for a System-on-Chip (SoC) or other system fetches bootloader code from Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) and stores the code in Volatile Memory (VM)
column6373: random-access memory (SRAM). The NVM is usually external to the SoC
column6374: while the VM is internal to the SoC. As the code is transferred from NVM to VM
column6375: it is authenticated by the SoC's ROM code. If the volatile-memory-region protections or access controls are insufficient to prevent modifications from an adversary or untrusted agent
column6376: the secure boot may be bypassed or replaced with the execution of an adversary's code."
