column7398: allowing the adversary to masquerade as the legitimate user.\n"
column7399: name:"Improper Protection of Physical Side Channels"
column7404: description:"The device does not contain sufficient protection mechanisms to prevent physical side channels from exposing sensitive information due to patterns in physically observable phenomena such as variations in power consumption
column7406: or acoustic emissions. An adversary could monitor and measure physical phenomena to detect patterns and make inferences
column7407: even if it is not possible to extract the information in the digital domain. Physical side channels have been well-studied for decades in the context of breaking implementations of cryptographic algorithms or other attacks against security features. These side channels may be easily observed by an adversary with physical access to the device
column7408: or using a tool that is in close proximity. If the adversary can monitor hardware operation and correlate its data processing with power
column7411: the adversary might be able to recover of secret keys and data."
column7416: description:"The product does not implement a required step in a cryptographic algorithm
column7417: resulting in weaker encryption than advertised by the algorithm. "
column7419: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nRe-using random values may compromise security.\nWhile an LFSR may provide pseudo-random number generation service
column7420: the entropy (measure of randomness) of the resulting output may be less than that of an accepted DRNG (like that used in dev\/urandom). Thus
column7421: using an LFSR weakens the strength of the cryptographic system
column7422: because it may be possible for an attacker to guess the LFSR output and subsequently the encryption key.\n"
column7423: name:"Use of a Cryptographic Primitive with a Risky Implementation"
column7436: description:"To fulfill the need for a cryptographic primitive
column7437: the product implements a cryptographic algorithm using a non-standard
column7439: or disallowed\/non-compliant cryptographic implementation. Cryptographic protocols and systems depend on cryptographic primitives (and associated algorithms) as their basic building blocks. Some common examples of primitives are digital signatures
column7443: the notion of \"primitive\" can vary depending on point of view. See \"Terminology Notes\" for further explanation of some concepts. Cryptographic primitives are defined to accomplish one very specific task in a precisely defined and mathematically reliable fashion. For example
column7444: suppose that for a specific cryptographic primitive (such as an encryption routine)
column7445: the consensus is that the primitive can only be broken after trying out N different inputs (where the larger the value of N
column7446: the stronger the cryptography). For an encryption scheme like AES-256
column7447: one would expect N to be so large as to be infeasible to execute in a reasonable amount of time. If a vulnerability is ever found that shows that one can break a cryptographic primitive in significantly less than the expected number of attempts
column7448: then that primitive is considered weakened (or sometimes in extreme cases
column7449: colloquially it is \"broken\"). As a result
column7450: anything using this cryptographic primitive would now be considered insecure or risky. Thus
column7451: even breaking or weakening a seemingly small cryptographic primitive has the potential to render the whole system vulnerable
column7452: due to its reliance on the primitive. A historical example can be found in TLS when using DES. One would colloquially call DES the cryptographic primitive for transport encryption in this version of TLS. In the past
column7454: because no weaknesses were found in it; importantly
column7455: DES has a key length of 56 bits. Trying N=2^56 keys was considered impractical for most actors. Unfortunately
column7456: attacking a system with 56-bit keys is now practical via brute force
column7457: which makes defeating DES encryption practical. It is now practical for an adversary to read any information sent under this version of TLS and use this information to attack the system. As a result
column7458: it can be claimed that this use of TLS is weak
column7459: and that any system depending on TLS with DES could potentially render the entire system vulnerable to attack. Cryptographic primitives and associated algorithms are only considered safe after extensive research and review from experienced cryptographers from academia
column7461: and government entities looking for any possible flaws. Furthermore
column7462: cryptographic primitives and associated algorithms are frequently reevaluated for safety when new mathematical and attack techniques are discovered. As a result and over time
column7463: even well-known cryptographic primitives can lose their compliance status with the discovery of novel attacks that might either defeat the algorithm or reduce its robustness significantly. If ad-hoc cryptographic primitives are implemented
column7464: it is almost certain that the implementation will be vulnerable to attacks that are well understood by cryptographers
column7465: resulting in the exposure of sensitive information and other consequences. This weakness is even more difficult to manage for hardware-implemented deployment of cryptographic algorithms. First
column7466: because hardware is not patchable as easily as software
column7467: any flaw discovered after release and production typically cannot be fixed without a recall of the product. Secondly
column7468: the hardware product is often expected to work for years
column7469: during which time computation power available to the attacker only increases. Therefore
column7470: for hardware implementations of cryptographic primitives
column7471: it is absolutely essential that only strong
column7474: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following pseudocode illustrates the weak encryption resulting from the use of a pseudo-random-number generator output.\nIn the example above
column7475: first a check of RNG ready is performed. If the check fails
column7476: the RNG is ignored and a hard coded value is used instead. The hard coded value severely weakens the encrypted output.\n"
column7477: name:"Cryptographic Operations are run Before Supporting Units are Ready"
column7479: description:"Performing cryptographic operations without ensuring that the supporting inputs are ready to supply valid data may compromise the cryptographic result. Many cryptographic hardware units depend upon other hardware units to supply information to them to produce a securely encrypted result. For example
column7480: a cryptographic unit that depends on an external random-number-generator (RNG) unit for entropy must wait until the RNG unit is producing random numbers. If a cryptographic unit retrieves a private encryption key from a fuse unit
column7481: the fuse unit must be up and running before a key may be supplied."
column7484: name:"Improper Handling of Hardware Behavior in Exceptionally Cold Environments"
column7487: or the firmware running on it
column7488: is missing or has incorrect protection features to maintain goals of security primitives when the device is cooled below standard operating temperatures. The hardware designer may improperly anticipate hardware behavior when exposed to exceptionally cold conditions. As a result they may introduce a weakness by not accounting for the modified behavior of critical components when in extreme environments. An example of a change in behavior is that power loss won't clear\/reset any volatile state when cooled below standard operating temperatures. This may result in a weakness when the starting state of the volatile memory is being relied upon for a security decision. For example
column7489: a Physical Unclonable Function (PUF) may be supplied as a security primitive to improve confidentiality
column7492: when the PUF is paired with DRAM
column7494: or another temperature sensitive entropy source
column7495: the system designer may introduce weakness by failing to account for the chosen entropy source's behavior at exceptionally low temperatures. In the case of DRAM and SRAM
column7496: when power is cycled at low temperatures
column7497: the device will not contain the bitwise biasing caused by inconsistencies in manufacturing and will instead contain the data from previous boot. Should the PUF primitive be used in a cryptographic construction which does not account for full adversary control of PUF seed data
column7498: weakness would arise. This weakness does not cover \"Cold Boot Attacks\" wherein RAM or other external storage is super cooled and read externally by an attacker."

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1

Consider the memory configuration settings of a system that uses DDR3 DRAM memory. Protecting the DRAM memory configuration from modification by software is required to ensure that system memory access control protections cannot be bypassed. This can be done by using lock bit protection that locks all of the memory configuration registers. The memory configuration lock can be set by the BIOS during the boot process.
If such a system also supports a rapid power on mode like hibernate
column7501: the DRAM data must be saved to a disk before power is removed and restored back to the DRAM once the system powers back up and before the OS resumes operation after returning from hibernate.\n\nTo support the hibernate transition back to the operating state
column7502: the DRAM memory configuration must be reprogrammed even though it was locked previously. As the hibernate resume does a partial reboot
column7503: the memory configuration could be altered before the memory lock is set. Functionally the hibernate resume flow requires a bypass of the lock-based protection. The memory configuration must be securely stored and restored by trusted system firmware. Lock settings and system configuration must be restored to the same state it was in before the device entered into the hibernate mode.\n"
column7504: name:"Improper Lock Behavior After Power State Transition"
column7506: description:"Register lock bit protection disables changes to system configuration once the bit is set. Some of the protected registers or lock bits become programmable after power state transitions (e.g.
column7507: Entry and wake from low power sleep modes) causing the system configuration to be changeable. Devices may allow device configuration controls which need to be programmed after device power reset via a trusted firmware or software module (commonly set by BIOS\/bootloader) and then locked from any further modification. This action is commonly implemented using a programmable lock bit
column7510: disables writes to a protected set of registers or address regions. After a power state transition
column7511: the lock bit is set to unlocked. Some common weaknesses that can exist in such a protection scheme are that the lock gets cleared
column7512: the values of the protected registers get reset

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
This example considers the Rowhammer problem [REF-1083]. The Rowhammer issue was caused by a program in a tight loop writing repeatedly to a location to which the program was allowed to write but causing an adjacent memory location value to change.
Preventing the loop required to defeat the Rowhammer exploit is not always possible:
While the redesign may be possible for new devices
column7565: a redesign is not possible in existing devices. There is also the possibility that reducing capacitance with a relayout would impact the density of the device resulting in a less capable
column7566:
more costly device.
Example 2
Suppose a hardware design implements a set of software-accessible registers for scaling clock frequency and voltage but does not control access to these registers. Attackers may cause register and memory changes and race conditions by changing the clock or voltage of the device under their control.
Example 3
Consider the following SoC design. Security-critical settings for scaling clock frequency and voltage are available in a range of registers bounded by [PRIV_END_ADDR : PRIV_START_ADDR] in the tmcu.csr module in the HW Root of Trust. These values are writable based on the lock_bit register in the same module. The lock_bit is only writable by privileged software running on the tmcu.

We assume that untrusted software running on any of the Core{0-N} processors has access to the input and output ports of the hrot_iface. If untrusted software can clear the lock_bit or write the clock frequency and voltage registers due to inadequate protection
column7567: a fault injection attack could be performed.\n\n"
column7568: name:"Improper Restriction of Software Interfaces to Hardware Features"
column7574: description:"The product provides software-controllable device functionality for capabilities such as power and clock management
column7575: but it does not properly limit functionality that can lead to modification of hardware memory or register bits
column7576: or the ability to observe physical side channels. It is frequently assumed that physical attacks such as fault injection and side-channel analysis require an attacker to have physical access to the target device. This assumption may be false if the device has improperly secured power management features
column7577: or similar features. For mobile devices
column7579: but these devices run a wide variety of applications with different performance requirements. Software-controllable mechanisms to dynamically scale device voltage and frequency and monitor power consumption are common features in today's chipsets
column7580: but they also enable attackers to mount fault injection and side-channel attacks without having physical access to the device. Fault injection attacks involve strategic manipulation of bits in a device to achieve a desired effect such as skipping an authentication step
column7582: or altering the output of a cryptographic operation. Manipulation of the device clock and voltage supply is a well-known technique to inject faults and is cheap to implement with physical device access. Poorly protected power management features allow these attacks to be performed from software. Other features
column7583: such as the ability to write repeatedly to DRAM at a rapid rate from unprivileged software
column7584: can result in bit flips in other memory locations (Rowhammer
column7585: [REF-1083]). Side channel analysis requires gathering measurement traces of physical quantities such as power consumption. Modern processors often include power metering capabilities in the hardware itself (e.g.
column7586: Intel RAPL) which if not adequately protected enable attackers to gather measurements necessary for performing side-channel attacks from software."

column7618: description:"The device does not write-protect the parametric data values for sensors that scale the sensor value

Various sensors are used by hardware to detect any devices operating outside of the design limits. The threshold limit values are set by hardware fuses or trusted software such as the BIOS. These limits may be related to thermal
column7623: and frequency. Hardware mechanisms may be used to protect against alteration of the threshold limit values by untrusted software. The limit values are generally programmed in standard units for the type of value being read. However
column7624: the hardware-sensor blocks may report the settings in different units depending upon sensor design and operation. column7628: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\n\nConsider a platform design where a Digital-Thermal Sensor (DTS) is used to monitor temperature and compare that output against a threshold value. If the temperature output equals or exceeds the threshold value
column7629: the DTS unit sends an alert signal to the processor.\nThe processor
column7631:
input triggers system shutdown. The alert signal is handled as a General-Purpose-I/O (GPIO) pin in input mode.

Reprogramming the state of the GPIO pin allows malicious software to trigger spurious alerts or to set the alert pin to a zero value so that thermal sensor alerts are not received by the processor.

column7632: name:"Improper Protection for Outbound Error Messages and Alert Signals"
column7634: description:"Untrusted agents can disable alerts about signal conditions exceeding limits or the response mechanism that handles such alerts. Hardware sensors are used to detect whether a device is operating within design limits. The threshold values for these limits are set by hardware fuses or trusted software such as a BIOS. Modification of these limits may be protected by hardware mechanisms. When device sensors detect out of bound conditions
column7635: alert signals may be generated for remedial action
column7636: which may take the form of device shutdown or throttling. Warning signals that are not properly secured may be disabled or used to generate spurious alerts
column7637: causing degraded performance or denial-of-service (DoS). These alerts may be masked by untrusted software. Examples of these alerts involve thermal and power sensor alerts."

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
A smart card contains authentication credentials that are used as authorization to enter a building. The credentials are only accessible when a correct PIN is presented to the card.
There are several ways this weakness could be fixed.

column7640: name:"Improper Handling of Faults that Lead to Instruction Skips"
column7642: description:"The device is missing or incorrectly implements circuitry or sensors that detect and mitigate the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions when they occur. The operating conditions of hardware may change in ways that cause unexpected behavior to occur
column7643: including the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions. Generally
column7644: this can occur due to electrical disturbances or when the device operates outside of its expected conditions. In practice
column7645: application code may contain conditional branches that are security-sensitive (e.g.
column7646: accepting or rejecting a user-provided password). These conditional branches are typically implemented by a single conditional branch instruction in the program binary which
column7648: may lead to effectively flipping the branch condition - i.e.
column7649: causing the wrong security-sensitive branch to be taken. This affects processes such as firmware authentication
column7651: and other security-sensitive decision points. Attackers can use fault injection techniques to alter the operating conditions of hardware so that security-critical instructions are skipped more frequently or more reliably than they would in a \"natural\" setting."
column7653: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nMalicious software running on a core can execute instructions that consume maximum power or increase core frequency. Such a power-virus program could execute on the platform for an extended time to overheat the device
column7654: resulting in permanent damage.\nExecution core and platform do not support thermal sensors
column7656: or platform-cooling countermeasures to ensure that any software executing on the system cannot cause overheating past the maximum allowable temperature.\nThe platform and SoC should have failsafe thermal limits that are enforced by thermal sensors that trigger critical temperature alerts when high temperature is detected. Upon detection of high temperatures
column7657: the platform should trigger cooling or shutdown automatically.\n"
column7660: description:"A hardware device is missing or has inadequate protection features to prevent overheating. Hardware
column7662: and semiconductor silicon have thermal side effects
column7663: such that some of the energy consumed by the device gets dissipated as heat and increases the temperature of the device. For example
column7665: higher-operating frequency of silicon results in higher power dissipation and heat. The leakage current in CMOS circuits increases with temperature
column7666: and this creates positive feedback that can result in thermal runaway and damage the device permanently. Any device lacking protections such as thermal sensors
column7668: or thermal insulation is susceptible to attacks by malicious software that might deliberately operate the device in modes that result in overheating. This can be used as an effective denial of service (DoS) or permanent denial of service (PDoS) attack. Depending on the type of hardware device and its expected usage
column7669: such thermal overheating can also cause safety hazards and reliability issues. Note that battery failures can also cause device overheating but the mitigations and examples included in this submission cannot reliably protect against a battery failure. There can be similar weaknesses with lack of protection from attacks based on overvoltage or overcurrent conditions. However
column7670: thermal heat is generated by hardware operation and the device should implement protection from overheating."
column7673: WiFi-router device implements a login prompt which prevents an unauthorized user from issuing any commands on the device until appropriate credentials are provided. The credentials are protected on the device and are checked for strength against attack.\nIf the JTAG interface on this device is not hidden by the manufacturer

column7677: an unauthorized user is able to execute code and inspect and modify data in the device
column7678: even extracting all of the router's firmware. This allows the user to examine the router and potentially exploit it.\nJTAG is useful to chip and device manufacturers during design
column7680: and production and is included in nearly every product. Without proper authentication and authorization
column7681: the interface may allow tampering with a product.\n"
column7682: name:"On-Chip Debug and Test Interface With Improper Access Control"
column7684: description:"The chip does not implement or does not correctly perform access control to check whether users are authorized to access internal registers and test modes through the physical debug\/test interface. A device's internal information may be accessed through a scan chain of interconnected internal registers
column7685: usually through a JTAG interface. The JTAG interface provides access to these registers in a serial fashion in the form of a scan chain for the purposes of debugging programs running on a device. Since almost all information contained within a device may be accessed over this interface
column7686: device manufacturers typically insert some form of authentication and authorization to prevent unintended use of this sensitive information. This mechanism is implemented in addition to on-chip protections that are already present. If authorization
column7688: or some other form of access control is not implemented or not implemented correctly
column7689: a user may be able to bypass on-chip protection mechanisms through the debug interface. Sometimes
column7690: designers choose not to expose the debug pins on the motherboard. Instead
column7691: they choose to hide these pins in the intermediate layers of the board. This is primarily done to work around the lack of debug authorization inside the chip. In such a scenario (without debug authorization)
column7692: when the debug interface is exposed
column7693: chip internals are accessible to an attacker."
column7696: consider the example Locked_override_register example. This register module supports a lock mode that blocks any writes after lock is set to 1. However
column7697: it also allows override of the lock protection when scan_mode or debug_unlocked modes are active.\nIf either the scan_mode or the debug_unlocked modes can be triggered by software
column7698: then the lock protection may be bypassed.\n"
column7699: name:"Hardware Internal or Debug Modes Allow Override of Locks"
column7701: description:"System configuration protection may be bypassed during debug mode. Device configuration controls are commonly programmed after a device power reset by a trusted firmware or software module (e.g.
column7702: BIOS\/bootloader) and then locked from any further modification. This is commonly implemented using a trusted lock bit
column7704: disables writes to a protected set of registers or address regions. The lock protection is intended to prevent modification of certain system configuration (e.g.
column7705: memory\/memory protection unit configuration). If debug features supported by hardware or internal modes\/system states are supported in the hardware design
column7706: modification of the lock protection may be allowed allowing access and modification of configuration information."
column7708: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nSensitive manufacturing data (such as die information) are stored in fuses. When the chip powers on
column7709: these values are read from the fuses and stored in microarchitectural registers. These registers are only given read access to trusted software running on the core. Untrusted software running on the core is not allowed to access these registers.\n"
column7710: name:"Sensitive Non-Volatile Information Not Protected During Debug"
column7712: description:"Access to security-sensitive information stored in fuses is not limited during debug. Several security-sensitive values are programmed into fuses to be used during early-boot flows or later at runtime. Examples of these security-sensitive values include root keys
column7716: and original-equipment-manufacturer (OEM) data. After the chip is powered on
column7717: these values are sensed from fuses and stored in temporary locations such as registers and local memories. These locations are typically access-control protected from untrusted agents capable of accessing them. Even to trusted agents
column7719: these locations are not blocked during debug operations
column7720: allowing a user to access this sensitive information."
column7722: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe JTAG interface is used to perform debugging and provide CPU core access for developers. JTAG-access protection is implemented as part of the JTAG_SHIELD bit in the hw_digctl_ctrl register. This register has no default value at power up and is set only after the system boots from ROM and control is transferred to the user software.\nThis means that since the end user has access to JTAG at system reset and during ROM code execution before control is transferred to user software
column7723: a JTAG user can modify the boot flow and subsequently disclose all CPU information
column7725: name:"Internal Asset Exposed to Unsafe Debug Access Level or State"
column7727: description:"The product uses physical debug or test interfaces with support for multiple access levels
column7728: but it assigns the wrong debug access level to an internal asset
column7729: providing unintended access to the asset from untrusted debug agents. Debug authorization can have multiple levels of access
column7730: defined such that different system internal assets are accessible based on the current authorized debug level. Other than debugger authentication (e.g.
column7732: the authorization can also be based on the system state or boot stage. For example
column7733: full system debug access might only be allowed early in boot after a system reset to ensure that previous session data is not accessible to the authenticated debugger. If this protection mechanism does not ensure that internal assets have the correct debug access level during each boot stage or change in system state
column7734: an attacker could obtain sensitive information from the internal asset using a debugger."
column7736: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA cryptographic core in a System-On-a-Chip (SoC) is used for cryptographic acceleration and implements several cryptographic operations (e.g.
column7737: computation of AES encryption and decryption
column7740: etc.). The keys for these operations or the intermediate values are stored in registers internal to the cryptographic core. These internal registers are in the Memory Mapped Input Output (MMIO) space and are blocked from access by software and other untrusted agents on the SoC. These registers are accessible through the debug and test interface.\n"
column7741: name:"Exposure of Sensitive System Information Due to Uncleared Debug Information"
column7743: description:"The hardware does not fully clear security-sensitive values
column7744: such as keys and intermediate values in cryptographic operations
column7745: when debug mode is entered. Security sensitive values
column7748: etc. are stored in temporary registers in the hardware. If these values are not cleared when debug mode is entered they may be accessed by a debugger allowing sensitive information to be accessible by untrusted parties."
column7750: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis example illustrates the danger of using the same public key for debug and production.\nSuppose the product design requires frugality of silicon real estate. Assume that originally the architecture allows just enough storage for two 2048-bit RSA keys in the fuse: one to be used for debug and the other for production. However
column7752: a business decision is taken to make the security future-proof beyond 2030
column7753: which means the architecture needs to use the NIST-recommended 3072-bit keys instead of the originally-planned 2048-bit keys. This means that
column7755: one key can be fully stored in the fuses
column7756: not two. So the product design team decides to use the same public key for debug and production.\nIncrease the storage so that two different keys of the required size can be stored.\n"
column7757: name:"Public Key Re-Use for Signing both Debug and Production Code"
column7759: description:"The same public key is used for signing both debug and production code. A common usage of public-key cryptography is to verify the integrity and authenticity of another entity (for example a firmware binary). If a company wants to ensure that its firmware runs only on its own hardware
column7761: an encrypted hash of the firmware image will be decrypted with the public key and then verified against the now-computed hash of the firmware image. This means that the public key forms the root of trust
column7762: which necessitates that the public key itself must be protected and used properly. During the development phase
column7763: debug firmware enables many hardware debug hooks
column7765: and debug messages for testing. Those debug facilities provide significant
column7766: additional views about the firmware's capability and
column7768: additional capability into the chip or SoC. If compromised
column7769: these capabilities could be exploited by an attacker to take full control of the system. Once the product exits the manufacturing stage and enters production
column7770: it is good practice to use a different public key. Debug firmware images are known to leak. With the debug key being reused as the production key
column7771: the debug image will also work on the production image. Thus
column7772: it will open all the internal
column7773: debug capabilities to the attacker. If a different public key is used for the production image
column7774: even if the attacker gains access to the debug firmware image
column7775: they will not be able to run it on a production machine. Thus
column7776: damage will be limited to the intellectual property leakage resulting from the debug image."

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
This example here shows how an attacker can take advantage of unnecessary information in debug messages.
Example 1: Suppose in response to a Test Access Port (TAP) chaining request the debug message also reveals the current TAP hierarchy (the full topology) in addition to the success/failure message.
Example 2: In response to a password-filling request
column7780: instead of a simple Granted\/Denied response
column7782:
"The user-entered password does not match the actual password stored in <directory name>."
The result of the above examples is that the user is able to gather additional unauthorized information about the system from the debug messages.
The solution is to ensure that Debug messages do not reveal additional details.
"
column7785: description:"The product fails to adequately prevent the revealing of unnecessary and potentially sensitive system information within debugging messages. Debug messages are messages that help troubleshoot an issue by revealing the internal state of the system. For example
column7786: debug data in design can be exposed through internal memory array dumps or boot logs through interfaces like UART via TAP commands
column7789: the more information contained in a debug message
column7790: the easier it is to debug. However
column7791: there is also the risk of revealing information that could help an attacker either decipher a vulnerability
column7792: and\/or gain a better understanding of the system. Thus
column7793: this extra information could lower the \"security by obscurity\" factor. While \"security by obscurity\" alone is insufficient
column7794: it can help as a part of \"Defense-in-depth\"."
column7796: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following example shows how an attacker can take advantage of incorrect chaining or missing granularity of debug components.\nIn a System-on-Chip (SoC)
column7797: the user might be able to access the SoC-level TAP with a certain level of authorization. However
column7798: this access should not also grant access to all of the internal TAPs (e.g.
column7800: if any of the internal TAPs is also stitched to the TAP chain when it should not be because of a logic error
column7801: then an attacker can access the internal TAPs as well and execute commands there.\nAs a related example
column7802: suppose there is a hierarchy of TAPs (TAP_A is connected to TAP_B and TAP_C
column7803: then TAP_B is connected to TAP_D and TAP_E
column7804: then TAP_C is connected to TAP_F and TAP_G
column7805: etc.). Architecture mandates that the user have one set of credentials for just accessing TAP_A
column7806: another set of credentials for accessing TAP_B and TAP_C
column7810: the designer mistakenly implements a daisy-chained TAP where all the TAPs are connected in a single TAP chain without the hierarchical structure
column7811: the correct granularity of debug components is not implemented and the attacker can gain unauthorized access.\n"
column7812: name:"Incorrect Chaining or Granularity of Debug Components"
column7815: description:"The product's debug components contain incorrect chaining or granularity of debug components. For debugging and troubleshooting a chip
column7816: several hardware design elements are often implemented
column7817: including: Various Test Access Ports (TAPs) allow boundary scan commands to be executed. For scanning the internal components of a chip
column7818: there are scan cells that allow the chip to be used as a \"stimulus and response\" mechanism. Chipmakers might create custom methods to observe the internal components of their chips by placing various tracing hubs within their chip and creating hierarchical or interconnected structures among those hubs. Logic errors during design or synthesis could misconfigure the interconnection of the debug components

column7842: name:"Improper Management of Sensitive Trace Data"
column7844: description:"Trace data collected from several sources on the System-on-Chip (SoC) is stored in unprotected locations or transported to untrusted agents. To facilitate verification of complex System-on-Chip (SoC) designs
column7845: SoC integrators add specific IP blocks that trace the SoC's internal signals in real-time. This infrastructure enables observability of the SoC's internal behavior
column7847: and detection of hardware and software bugs. Such tracing IP blocks collect traces from several sources on the SoC including the CPU
column7849: and on-chip fabrics. Traces collected from these sources are then aggregated inside trace IP block and forwarded to trace sinks
column7850: such as debug-trace ports that facilitate debugging by external hardware and software debuggers. Since these traces are collected from several security-sensitive sources
column7851: they must be protected against untrusted debuggers. If they are stored in unprotected memory
column7852: an untrusted software debugger can access these traces and extract secret information. Additionally
column7853: if security-sensitive traces are not tagged as secure
column7854: an untrusted hardware debugger might access them to extract confidential information."

column7888: description:"The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors. Many communication channels can be \"sniffed\" (monitored) by adversaries during data transmission. For example
column7890: packets can traverse many intermediary nodes from the source to the destination
column7894: etc. Some actors might have privileged access to a network interface or any link along the channel
column7896: but they might not be authorized to collect the underlying data. As a result
column7897: network traffic could be sniffed by adversaries
column7898: spilling security-critical data. Applicable communication channels are not limited to software products. Applicable channels include hardware-specific technologies such as internal hardware networks and external debug channels
column7899: supporting remote JTAG debugging. When mitigations are not applied to combat adversaries within the product's threat model
column7900: this weakness significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by such adversaries. When full communications are recorded or logged
column7901: such as with a packet dump
column7902: an adversary could attempt to obtain the dump long after the transmission has occurred and try to \"sniff\" the cleartext from the recorded communications in the dump itself."

column7916: description:"The product does not have documentation that represents how it is designed. This issue can make it more difficult to understand and maintain the product. It can make it more difficult and time-consuming to detect and\/or fix vulnerabilities."
column7921: description:"The product does not contain sufficient technical or engineering documentation (whether on paper or in electronic form) that contains descriptions of all the relevant software\/hardware elements of the product
column7930: etc. When technical documentation is limited or lacking
column7931: products are more difficult to maintain. This indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. When using time-limited or labor-limited third-party\/in-house security consulting services (such as threat modeling
column7934: insufficient documentation can force those consultants to invest unnecessary time in learning how the product is organized
column7935: instead of focusing their expertise on finding the flaws or suggesting effective mitigations. With respect to hardware design
column7937: final manufacturer reference can make it difficult or impossible to evaluate the final product
column7938: including post-manufacture verification. One cannot ensure that design functionality or operation is within acceptable tolerances
column7940: and is free from unexpected behavior. Hardware-related documentation may include engineering artifacts such as hardware description language (HDLs)
column7950: description:"The product is designed with access restricted to certain information
column7951: but it does not sufficiently protect against an unauthorized actor with physical access to these areas. Sections of a product intended to have restricted access may be inadvertently or intentionally rendered accessible when the implemented physical protections are insufficient. The specific requirements around how robust the design of the physical protection mechanism needs to be depends on the type of product being protected. Selecting the correct physical protection mechanism and properly enforcing it through implementation and manufacturing are critical to the overall physical security of the product."
column7953: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA refrigerator has an Internet interface for the official purpose of alerting the manufacturer when that refrigerator detects a fault. Because the device is attached to the Internet
column7954: the refrigerator is a target for hackers who may wish to use the device other potentially more nefarious purposes.\n"
column7957: description:"The product does not provide its users with the ability to update or patch its firmware to address any vulnerabilities or weaknesses that may be present. Without the ability to patch or update firmware
column7958: consumers will be left vulnerable to exploitation of any known vulnerabilities
column7959: or any vulnerabilities that are discovered in the future. This can expose consumers to permanent risk throughout the entire lifetime of the device
column7960: which could be years or decades. Some external protective measures and mitigations might be employed to aid in preventing or reducing the risk of malicious attack
column7961: but the root weakness cannot be corrected."
column7964: name:"Insufficient or Incomplete Data Removal within Hardware Component"
column7966: description:"The product's data removal process does not completely delete all data and potentially sensitive information within hardware components. Physical properties of hardware devices
column7967: such as remanence of magnetic media
column7969: or screen burn-in may still retain sensitive data after a data removal process has taken place and power is removed. Recovering data after erasure or overwriting is possible due to a phenomenon called data remanence. For example
column7970: if the same value is written repeatedly to a memory location
column7971: the corresponding memory cells can become physically altered to a degree such that even after the original data is erased that data can still be recovered through physical characterization of the memory cells."
column7973: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a device that uses flash memory for non-volatile-data storage. To optimize flash-access performance or reliable-flash lifetime
column7974: the device might limit the number of flash writes\/erases by maintaining some state in internal SRAM and only committing changes to flash memory periodically.\nThe device also supports user reset to factory defaults with the expectation that all personal information is erased from the device after this operation. On factory reset
column7975: user files are erased using explicit
column7976: erase commands supported by the flash device.\nIn the given
column7978: the flash-file system can support performance-optimized erase such that only the file metadata are erased and not the content. If this optimized erase is used for files containing user data during factory-reset flow
column7980: flash memory can contain remanent data from these files.\nOn device-factory reset
column7981: the implementation might not erase these copies
column7982: since the file organization has changed and the flash file system does not have the metadata to track all previous copies.\nA flash-memory region that is used by a flash-file system should be fully erased as part of the factory-reset flow. This should include secure-erase flow for the flash media such as overwriting patterns multiple times followed by erase.\n"
column7983: name:"Remanent Data Readable after Memory Erase"
column7985: description:"Confidential information stored in memory circuits is readable or recoverable after being cleared or erased. Data remanence occurs when stored
column7986: memory content is not fully lost after a memory-clear or -erase operation. Confidential memory contents can still be readable through data remanence in the hardware. Data remanence can occur because of performance optimization or memory organization during 'clear' or 'erase' operations
column7987: like a design that allows the memory-organization metadata (e.g.
column7988: file pointers) to be erased without erasing the actual memory content. To protect against this weakness
column7989: memory devices will often support different commands for optimized memory erase and explicit secure erase. Data remanence can also happen because of the physical properties of memory circuits in use. For example
column7992: random-access-memory (DRAM) data retention is based on the charge retained in the memory cell
column7993: which depends on factors such as power supply
column7995: and temperature. Other than explicit erase commands
column7997: secure-memory devices can also support secure erase through cryptographic erase commands. In such designs
column7998: only the decryption keys for encrypted data stored on the device are erased. That is
column7999: the stored data are always remnant in the media after a cryptographic erase. However
column8000: only the encrypted data can be extracted. Thus
column8001: protection against data recovery in such designs relies on the strength of the encryption algorithm."

column8007: name:"Reliance on Component That is Not Updateable"
column8009: description:"The product contains a component that cannot be updated or patched in order to remove vulnerabilities or significant bugs. If the component is discovered to contain a vulnerability or critical bug
column8010: but the issue cannot be fixed using an update or patch
column8011: then the product's owner will not be able to protect against the issue. The only option might be replacement of the product
column8012: which could be too financially or operationally expensive for the product owner. As a result
column8013: the inability to patch or update can leave the product open to attacker exploitation or critical operation failures. This weakness can be especially difficult to manage when using ROM
column8015: or similar components that traditionally have had limited or no update capabilities. In industries such as healthcare
column8016: \"legacy\" devices can be operated for decades. As a US task force report [REF-1197] notes
column8017: \"the inability to update or replace equipment has both large and small health care delivery organizations struggle with numerous unsupported legacy systems that cannot easily be replaced (hardware
column8019: and operating systems) with large numbers of vulnerabilities and few modern countermeasures.\" While hardware can be prone to this weakness
column8020: software systems can also be affected
column8021: such as when a third-party driver or library is no longer actively maintained or supported but is still critical for the required functionality."
column8024: security related information is stored in fuses. These fuses are loaded into shadow registers at boot time. Disturbing this transfer phase with EM-FI can lead to the shadow registers storing erroneous values potentially resulting in reduced security.\nColin O'Flynn has demonstrated an attack scenario which uses electro-magnetic glitching during booting to bypass security and gain read access to flash
column8025: read and erase access to shadow memory area (where the private password is stored). Most devices in the MPC55xx and MPC56xx series that include the Boot Assist Module (BAM) (a serial or CAN bootloader mode) are susceptible to this attack. In this paper

column8028: the author showed that success can be achieved within 30-60 minutes from a cold start.\n"
column8029: name:"Improper Protection against Electromagnetic Fault Injection (EM-FI)"
column8031: description:"The device is susceptible to electromagnetic fault injection attacks
column8032: causing device internal information to be compromised or security mechanisms to be bypassed. Electromagnetic fault injection may allow an attacker to locally and dynamically modify the signals (both internal and external) of an integrated circuit. EM-FI attacks consist of producing a local
column8033: transient magnetic field near the device
column8034: inducing current in the device wires. A typical EMFI setup is made up of a pulse injection circuit that generates a high current transient in an EMI coil
column8035: producing an abrupt magnetic pulse which couples to the target producing faults in the device
column8036: which can lead to: Bypassing security mechanisms such as secure JTAG or Secure Boot Leaking device information Modifying program flow Perturbing secure hardware modules (e.g. random number generators)"

column8044: name:"Improper Protection Against Voltage and Clock Glitches"
column8046: description:"The device does not contain or contains incorrectly implemented circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate voltage and clock glitches and protect sensitive information or software contained on the device. A device might support features such as secure boot which are supplemented with hardware and firmware support. This involves establishing a chain of trust
column8047: starting with an immutable root of trust by checking the signature of the next stage (culminating with the OS and runtime software) against a golden value before transferring control. The intermediate stages typically set up the system in a secure state by configuring several access control settings. Similarly
column8048: security logic for exercising a debug or testing interface may be implemented in hardware
column8050: or both. A device needs to guard against fault attacks such as voltage glitches and clock glitches that an attacker may employ in an attempt to compromise the system."

column8060: name:"Improper Handling of Single Event Upsets"
column8062: description:"The hardware logic does not effectively handle when single-event upsets (SEUs) occur. Technology trends such as CMOS-transistor down-sizing
column8064: and system-on-chip architectures continue to increase the sensitivity of systems to soft errors. These errors are random
column8065: and their causes might be internal (e.g.
column8067: cosmic radiation). These soft errors are not permanent in nature and cause temporary bit flips known as single-event upsets (SEUs). SEUs are induced errors in circuits caused when charged particles lose energy by ionizing the medium through which they pass
column8068: leaving behind a wake of electron-hole pairs that cause temporary failures. If these failures occur in security-sensitive modules in a chip
column8069: it might compromise the security guarantees of the chip. For instance
column8070: these temporary failures could be bit flips that change the privilege of a regular user to root."

column8073: name:"Improper Handling of Faults that Lead to Instruction Skips"
column8075: description:"The device is missing or incorrectly implements circuitry or sensors that detect and mitigate the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions when they occur. The operating conditions of hardware may change in ways that cause unexpected behavior to occur
column8076: including the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions. Generally
column8077: this can occur due to electrical disturbances or when the device operates outside of its expected conditions. In practice
column8078: application code may contain conditional branches that are security-sensitive (e.g.
column8079: accepting or rejecting a user-provided password). These conditional branches are typically implemented by a single conditional branch instruction in the program binary which
column8081: may lead to effectively flipping the branch condition - i.e.
column8082: causing the wrong security-sensitive branch to be taken. This affects processes such as firmware authentication
column8084: and other security-sensitive decision points. Attackers can use fault injection techniques to alter the operating conditions of hardware so that security-critical instructions are skipped more frequently or more reliably than they would in a \"natural\" setting."
column8087: name:"Improper Handling of Hardware Behavior in Exceptionally Cold Environments"
column8090: or the firmware running on it
column8091: is missing or has incorrect protection features to maintain goals of security primitives when the device is cooled below standard operating temperatures. The hardware designer may improperly anticipate hardware behavior when exposed to exceptionally cold conditions. As a result they may introduce a weakness by not accounting for the modified behavior of critical components when in extreme environments. An example of a change in behavior is that power loss won't clear\/reset any volatile state when cooled below standard operating temperatures. This may result in a weakness when the starting state of the volatile memory is being relied upon for a security decision. For example
column8092: a Physical Unclonable Function (PUF) may be supplied as a security primitive to improve confidentiality
column8095: when the PUF is paired with DRAM
column8097: or another temperature sensitive entropy source
column8098: the system designer may introduce weakness by failing to account for the chosen entropy source's behavior at exceptionally low temperatures. In the case of DRAM and SRAM
column8099: when power is cycled at low temperatures
column8100: the device will not contain the bitwise biasing caused by inconsistencies in manufacturing and will instead contain the data from previous boot. Should the PUF primitive be used in a cryptographic construction which does not account for full adversary control of PUF seed data
column8101: weakness would arise. This weakness does not cover \"Cold Boot Attacks\" wherein RAM or other external storage is super cooled and read externally by an attacker."
column8103: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider an SoC design that embeds a secret key in read-only memory (ROM). The key is baked into the design logic and may not be modified after fabrication causing the key to be identical for all devices. An attacker in possession of the IC can decapsulate and delayer the device. After imaging the layers

column8105: name:"Missing Protection Against Hardware Reverse Engineering Using Integrated Circuit (IC) Imaging Techniques"
column8107: description:"Information stored in hardware may be recovered by an attacker with the capability to capture and analyze images of the integrated circuit using techniques such as scanning electron microscopy. The physical structure of a device
column8109: can reveal the information stored inside. Typical steps in IC reverse engineering involve removing the chip packaging (decapsulation) then using various imaging techniques ranging from high resolution x-ray microscopy to invasive techniques involving removing IC layers and imaging each layer using a scanning electron microscope. The goal of such activities is to recover secret keys
column8111: and proprietary code and circuit designs embedded in hardware that the attacker has been unsuccessful at accessing through other means. These secrets may be stored in non-volatile memory or in the circuit netlist. Memory technologies such as masked ROM allow easier to extraction of secrets than One-time Programmable (OTP) memory."

The user-provided password is compared against a stored value byte-by-byte.\nSince the algorithm uses a different number of 1's and 0's for password validation

Note that in this example
column8116: the initial change of the bit values could still provide power indication depending upon the hardware itself. This possibility needs to be measured for verification.\nSince the algorithm uses a different number of 1's and 0's for password validation
column8117: a different amount of power is consumed for the good byte versus the bad byte comparison. Using this information
column8118: an attacker may be able to guess the correct password for that byte-by-byte iteration with several repeated attempts by stopping the password evaluation before it completes.\nAn alternative to the previous example is simply comparing the whole password simultaneously.\nSince comparison is done atomically
column8119:
there is no indication which bytes fail forcing the attacker to brute force the whole password at once. Note that other mitigations may exist such as masking - causing a large current draw to mask individual bit flips.

column8129: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a device that checks a passcode to unlock the screen.\nPIN numbers used to unlock a cell phone should not exhibit any characteristics about themselves. This creates a side channel. An attacker could monitor the pulses using an oscilloscope or other method. Once the first character is correctly guessed (based on the oscilloscope readings)

column8135: name:"Improper Protection of Physical Side Channels"
column8140: description:"The device does not contain sufficient protection mechanisms to prevent physical side channels from exposing sensitive information due to patterns in physically observable phenomena such as variations in power consumption
column8142: or acoustic emissions. An adversary could monitor and measure physical phenomena to detect patterns and make inferences
column8143: even if it is not possible to extract the information in the digital domain. These side channels may be easily observed by an adversary with physical access to the device

column8150: name:"Semiconductor Defects in Hardware Logic with Security-Sensitive Implications"
column8152: description:"The security-sensitive hardware module contains semiconductor defects. A semiconductor device can fail for various reasons. While some are manufacturing and packaging defects
column8153: the rest are due to prolonged use or usage under extreme conditions. Some mechanisms that lead to semiconductor defects include encapsulation failure
column8161: and thermal\/electrical stress. These defects manifest as faults on chip-internal signals or registers
column8164: or intermediate signals being always 0 or always 1
column8165: and do not switch as expected. If such faults occur in security-sensitive hardware modules

The credentials are protected on the device and are checked for strength against attack.\nIf the JTAG interface on this device is not hidden by the manufacturer
column8170: the interface may be identified using tools such as JTAGulator. If it is hidden but not disabled

column8178: name:"On-Chip Debug and Test Interface With Improper Access Control"
column8180: description:"The chip does not implement or does not correctly perform access control to check whether users are authorized to access internal registers and test modes through the physical debug\/test interface. A device's internal information may be accessed through a scan chain of interconnected internal registers
column8181: usually through a JTAG interface. The JTAG interface provides access to these registers in a serial fashion in the form of a scan chain for the purposes of debugging programs running on a device. Since almost all information contained within a device may be accessed over this interface
column8182: device manufacturers typically insert some form of authentication and authorization to prevent unintended use of this sensitive information. This mechanism is implemented in addition to on-chip protections that are already present. If authorization
column8184: or some other form of access control is not implemented or not implemented correctly
column8185: a user may be able to bypass on-chip protection mechanisms through the debug interface. Sometimes
column8186: designers choose not to expose the debug pins on the motherboard. Instead
column8187: they choose to hide these pins in the intermediate layers of the board. This is primarily done to work around the lack of debug authorization inside the chip. In such a scenario (without debug authorization)
column8188: when the debug interface is exposed
column8189: chip internals are accessible to an attacker."
column8191: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\n\nConsider a system with a register for storing AES key for encryption or decryption. The key is 128 bits
column8192: implemented as a set of four 32-bit registers. The key registers are assets and registers
column8194: and are defined to provide necessary access controls.\nThe read-policy register defines which agents can read the AES-key registers
column8195: and write-policy register defines which agents can program or write to those registers. Each register is a 32-bit register
column8196: and it can support access control for a maximum of 32 agents. The number of the bit when set (i.e.
column8197: \"1\") allows respective action from an agent whose identity matches the number of the bit and
column8200: disallows the respective action to that corresponding agent.\n\nIn the above example
column8201: there is only one policy register that controls access to both read and write accesses to the AES-key registers
column8202: and thus the design is not granular enough to separate read and writes access for different agents. Here
column8203:
agent with identities "1" and "2" can both read and write.
A good design should be granular enough to provide separate access controls to separate actions. Access control for reads should be separate from writes. Below is an example of such implementation where two policy registers are defined for each of these actions. The policy is defined such that: the AES-key registers can only be read or used by a crypto agent with identity "1" when bit #1 is set. The AES-key registers can only be programmed by a trusted firmware with identity "2" when bit #2 is set.
Example 2
Consider the following SoC design. The sram in HRoT has an address range that is readable and writable by unprivileged software and it has an area that is only readable by unprivileged software. The tbus interconnect enforces access control for slaves on the bus but uses only one bit to control both read and write access. Address 0xA0000000 - 0xA000FFFF is readable and writable by the untrusted cores core{0-N} and address 0xA0010000 - 0xA001FFFF is only readable by the untrusted cores core{0-N}.

The security policy access control is not granular enough
column8204:
as it uses one bit to enable both read and write access. This gives write access to an area that should only be readable by unprivileged agents.
Access control logic should differentiate between read and write access and to have sufficient address granularity.

"
column8207: description:"The product implements access controls via a policy or other feature with the intention to disable or restrict accesses (reads and\/or writes) to assets in a system from untrusted agents. However
column8208: implemented access controls lack required granularity
column8209: which renders the control policy too broad because it allows accesses from unauthorized agents to the security-sensitive assets. Integrated circuits and hardware engines can expose accesses to assets (device configuration
column8211: etc.) to trusted firmware or a software module (commonly set by BIOS\/bootloader). This access is typically access-controlled. Upon a power reset
column8212: the hardware or system usually starts with default values in registers
column8213: and the trusted firmware (Boot firmware) configures the necessary access-control protection. A common weakness that can exist in such protection schemes is that access controls or policies are not granular enough. This condition allows agents beyond trusted agents to access assets and could lead to a loss of functionality or the ability to set up the device securely. This further results in security risks from leaked
column8215: key material to modification of device configuration."
column8218: consider a hardware unit with a 32 kilobyte configuration address space where the first 8 kilobyte address contains security sensitive controls that must only be writable by device bootloader. One way to protect the security configuration could be to define a 32 bit system configuration locking register (SYS_LOCK) where each bit lock locks the corresponding 1 kilobyte region.\nIf a register exists within the first kilobyte address range (e.g. SW_MODE
column8219: address 0x310) and needs to be software writable at runtime
column8220: then this register cannot be written in a securely configured system since SYS_LOCK register lock bit 0 must be set to protect other security settings (e.g. SECURITY_FEATURE_ENABLE
column8221: address 0x0004). The only fix would be to change the hardware logic or not set the security lock bit.\n"
column8222: name:"Insufficient Granularity of Address Regions Protected by Register Locks"
column8224: description:"The product defines a large address region protected from modification by the same register lock control bit. This results in a conflict between the functional requirement that some addresses need to be writable by software during operation and the security requirement that the system configuration lock bit must be set during the boot process. Integrated circuits and hardware IPs can expose the device configuration controls that need to be programmed after device power reset by a trusted firmware or software module (commonly set by BIOS\/bootloader) and then locked from any further modification. In hardware design
column8225: this is commonly implemented using a programmable lock bit which enables\/disables writing to a protected set of registers or address regions. When the programmable lock bit is set
column8226: the relevant address region can be implemented as a hardcoded value in hardware logic that cannot be changed later. A problem can arise wherein the protected region definition is not granular enough. After the programmable lock bit has been set
column8227: then this new functionality cannot be implemented without change to the hardware design."
column8229: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider the example design below for a digital thermal sensor that detects overheating of the silicon and triggers system shutdown. The system critical temperature limit (CRITICAL_TEMP_LIMIT) and thermal sensor calibration (TEMP_SENSOR_CALIB) data have to be programmed by firmware
column8230: and then the register needs to be locked (TEMP_SENSOR_LOCK).\nIn this example
column8231: note that if the system heats to critical temperature
column8232: the response of the system is controlled by the TEMP_HW_SHUTDOWN bit [1]
column8234: the intended security property of the critical temperature sensor cannot be fully protected
column8235: since software can misconfigure the TEMP_HW_SHUTDOWN register even after the lock bit is set to disable the shutdown response.\nTo fix this weakness
column8236: one could change the TEMP_HW_SHUTDOWN field to be locked by TEMP_SENSOR_LOCK.\n"
column8237: name:"Improper Prevention of Lock Bit Modification"
column8239: description:"The product uses a trusted lock bit for restricting access to registers
column8242: but the product does not prevent the value of the lock bit from being modified after it has been set. In integrated circuits and hardware intellectual property (IP) cores
column8243: device configuration controls are commonly programmed after a device power reset by a trusted firmware or software module (e.g.
column8244: BIOS\/bootloader) and then locked from any further modification. This behavior is commonly implemented using a trusted lock bit. When set
column8245: the lock bit disables writes to a protected set of registers or address regions. Design or coding errors in the implementation of the lock bit protection feature may allow the lock bit to be modified or cleared by software after it has been set. Attackers might be able to unlock the system and features that the bit is intended to protect."
column8247:
{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
Consider the example design below for a digital thermal sensor that detects overheating of the silicon and triggers system shutdown. The system critical temperature limit (CRITICAL_TEMP_LIMIT) and thermal sensor calibration (TEMP_SENSOR_CALIB) data have to be programmed by the firmware.

In this example note that only the CRITICAL_TEMP_LIMIT register is protected by the TEMP_SENSOR_LOCK bit
column8248: while the security design intent is to protect any modification of the critical temperature detection and response.\nThe response of the system
column8249: if the system heats to a critical temperature
column8252: the TEMP_SENSOR_CALIB register is not protected by the lock bit.\nBy modifying the temperature sensor calibration
column8253: the conversion of the sensor data to a degree centigrade can be changed
column8254: such that the current temperature will never be detected to exceed critical temperature value programmed by the protected lock.\nSimilarly
column8256:
the system response detection of the current temperature exceeding critical temperature can be disabled.

Change TEMP_HW_SHUTDOWN and TEMP_SENSOR_CALIB controls to be locked by TEMP_SENSOR_LOCK.

"
column8257: name:"Security-Sensitive Hardware Controls with Missing Lock Bit Protection"
column8260: description:"The product uses a register lock bit protection mechanism
column8261: but it does not ensure that the lock bit prevents modification of system registers or controls that perform changes to important hardware system configuration. Integrated circuits and hardware intellectual properties (IPs) might provide device configuration controls that need to be programmed after device power reset by a trusted firmware or software module
column8262: commonly set by BIOS\/bootloader. After reset
column8263: there can be an expectation that the controls cannot be used to perform any further modification. This behavior is commonly implemented using a trusted lock bit
column8264: which can be set to disable writes to a protected set of registers or address regions. The lock protection is intended to prevent modification of certain system configuration (e.g.
column8266: if the lock bit does not effectively write-protect all system registers or controls that could modify the protected system configuration
column8267: then an adversary may be able to use software to access the registers\/controls and modify the protected hardware configuration."
column8269: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a device that comes with various security measures
column8270: such as secure boot. The secure-boot process performs firmware-integrity verification at boot time
column8271: and this code is stored in a separate SPI-flash device. However
column8272: this code contains undocumented \"special access features\" intended to be used only for performing failure analysis and intended to only be unlocked by the device designer.\nRemove all chicken bits and hidden features that are exposed to attackers. Add authorization schemes that rely on cryptographic primitives to access any features that the manufacturer does not want to expose. Clearly document all interfaces.\n"
column8273: name:"Inclusion of Undocumented Features or Chicken Bits"
column8275: description:"The device includes chicken bits or undocumented features that can create entry points for unauthorized actors. A common design practice is to use undocumented bits on a device that can be used to disable certain functional security features. These bits are commonly referred to as \"chicken bits\". They can facilitate quick identification and isolation of faulty components
column8277: or features that do not provide the required controllability for debug and test. Another way to achieve this is through implementation of undocumented features. An attacker might exploit these interfaces for unauthorized access."
column8279: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nMCS51 Microcontroller (based on 8051) does not have a special bit to support write exclusivity. It also does not have an MMU\/MPU support. The Cortex-M CPU has an optional MPU that supports up to 8 regions.\nIf the MPU is not configured
column8280: then an attacker will be able to inject malicious data into memory and execute it.\n"
column8281: name:"CPU Hardware Not Configured to Support Exclusivity of Write and Execute Operations"
column8283: description:"The CPU is not configured to provide hardware support for exclusivity of write and execute operations on memory. This allows an attacker to execute data from all of memory. CPUs provide a special bit that supports exclusivity of write and execute operations. This bit is used to segregate areas of memory to either mark them as code (instructions
column8284: which can be executed) or data (which should not be executed). In this way
column8285: if a user can write to a region of memory
column8286: the user cannot execute from that region and vice versa. This exclusivity provided by special hardware bit is leveraged by the operating system to protect executable space. While this bit is available in most modern processors by default
column8287: in some CPUs the exclusivity is implemented via a memory-protection unit (MPU) and memory-management unit (MMU) in which memory regions can be carved out with exact read
column8290: if the CPU does not have an MMU\/MPU
column8291: then there is no write exclusivity. Without configuring exclusivity of operations via segregated areas of memory
column8292: an attacker may be able to inject malicious code onto memory and later execute it."
column8294:
{"exampleDescription":"Example 1

In a System-on-a-Chip (SoC) design the system fabric uses 16 bit addresses. An IP unit (Unit_A) has 4 kilobyte of internal memory which is mapped into a 16 kilobyte address range in the system fabric address map.
To protect the register controls in Unit_A unprivileged software is blocked from accessing addresses between 0x0000 - 0x0FFF.
The address decoder of Unit_A masks off the higher order address bits and decodes only the lower 12 bits for computing the offset into the 4 kilobyte internal memory space.

In this design the aliased memory address ranges are these:
0x0000 - 0x0FFF
0x1000 - 0x1FFF
0x2000 - 0x2FFF
0x3000 - 0x3FFF
The same register can be accessed using four different addresses: 0x0000
column8297: 0x3000.\nThe system address filter only blocks access to range 0x0000 - 0x0FFF and does not block access to the aliased addresses in 0x1000 - 0x3FFF range. Thus
column8298: untrusted software can leverage the aliased memory addresses to bypass the memory protection.\nIn this design the aliased memory addresses (0x1000 - 0x3FFF) could be blocked from all system software access since they are not used by software.\nAlternately
column8299: the MPU logic can be changed to apply the memory protection policies to the full address range mapped to Unit_A (0x0000 - 0x3FFF).\n"
column8300: name:"Improper Access Control Applied to Mirrored or Aliased Memory Regions"
column8302: description:"Aliased or mirrored memory regions in hardware designs may have inconsistent read\/write permissions enforced by the hardware. A possible result is that an untrusted agent is blocked from accessing a memory region but is not blocked from accessing the corresponding aliased memory region. Hardware product designs often need to implement memory protection features that enable privileged software to define isolated memory regions and access control (read\/write) policies. Isolated memory regions can be defined on different memory spaces in a design (e.g. system physical address
column8304: memory mapped IO). Each memory cell should be mapped and assigned a system address that the core software can use to read\/write to that memory. It is possible to map the same memory cell to multiple system addresses such that read\/write to any of the aliased system addresses would be decoded to the same memory cell. This is commonly done in hardware designs for redundancy and simplifying address decoding logic. If one of the memory regions is corrupted or faulty
column8305: then that hardware can switch to using the data in the mirrored memory region. Memory aliases can also be created in the system address map if the address decoder unit ignores higher order address bits when mapping a smaller address region into the full system address. A common security weakness that can exist in such memory mapping is that aliased memory regions could have different read\/write access protections enforced by the hardware such that an untrusted agent is blocked from accessing a memory address but is not blocked from accessing the corresponding aliased memory address. Such inconsistency can then be used to bypass the access protection of the primary memory block and read or modify the protected memory. An untrusted agent could also possibly create memory aliases in the system address map for malicious purposes if it is able to change the mapping of an address region or modify memory region sizes."

column8312: with the AES-key registers. Each bit in this 32-bit register defines a security Token. There could be a maximum of 32 security Tokens that are allowed access to the AES-key registers. The number of the bit when set (i.e.
