disallows the respective action to that corresponding agent.
Let's assume the system has two agents: a Main-controller and an Aux-controller. The respective Security Tokens are "1" and "2".

An agent with Security Token "1" has access to AES_ENC_DEC_KEY_0 through AES_ENC_DEC_KEY_3 registers. As per the above access policy
column8317: the AES-Key-access policy allows access to the AES-key registers if the security Token is \"1\".\nThe SoC does not properly protect the Security Token of the agents
column8320: the Aux-controller in the above example can spoof the transaction (i.e.
column8321: send the transaction as if it is coming from the Main-controller to access the AES-Key registers)\n"
column8322: name:"Improper Restriction of Security Token Assignment"
column8324: description:"The System-On-A-Chip (SoC) implements a Security Token mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. However
column8325: the Security Tokens are improperly protected. Systems-On-A-Chip (Integrated circuits and hardware engines) implement Security Tokens to differentiate and identify which actions originated from which agent. These actions may be one of the directives: 'read'
column8331: etc. Security Tokens are assigned to every agent in the System that is capable of generating an action or receiving an action from another agent. Multiple Security Tokens may be assigned to an agent and may be unique based on the agent's trust level or allowed privileges. Since the Security Tokens are integral for the maintenance of security in an SoC
column8332: they need to be protected properly. A common weakness afflicting Security Tokens is improperly restricting the assignment to trusted components. Consequently
column8333: an improperly protected Security Token may be able to be programmed by a malicious agent (i.e.
column8334: the Security Token is mutable) to spoof the action as if it originated from a trusted agent."
column8337: consider a design with a 16-bit address that has two software privilege levels: Privileged_SW and Non_privileged_SW. To isolate the system memory regions accessible by these two privilege levels
column8338: the design supports three memory regions: Region_0
column8340:
and Region_2.
Each region is defined by two 32 bit registers: its range and its access policy.
Certain bits of the access policy are defined symbolically as follows:
For any requests from software
column8341: an address-protection filter checks the address range and access policies for each of the three regions
column8342: and only allows software access if all three filters allow access.\nConsider the following goals for access control as intended by the designer:\nThe intention is that Non_privileged_SW cannot modify memory region and policies defined by Privileged_SW in Region_0 and Region_1. Thus
column8343: it cannot read or write the memory regions that Privileged_SW is using.\n\nNon_privileged_SW can program the Address_range register for Region_2 so that its address overlaps with the ranges defined by Region_0 or Region_1. Using this capability
column8344: it is possible for Non_privileged_SW to block any memory region from being accessed by Privileged_SW
column8346: Region_0 and Region_1.\nThis design could be improved in several ways.\n"
column8347: name:"Improper Handling of Overlap Between Protected Memory Ranges"
column8349: description:"The product allows address regions to overlap
column8350: which can result in the bypassing of intended memory protection. Isolated memory regions and access control (read\/write) policies are used by hardware to protect privileged software. Software components are often allowed to change or remap memory region definitions in order to enable flexible and dynamically changeable memory management by system software. If a software component running at lower privilege can program a memory address region to overlap with other memory regions used by software running at higher privilege
column8351: privilege escalation may be available to attackers. The memory protection unit (MPU) logic can incorrectly handle such an address overlap and allow the lower-privilege software to read or write into the protected memory region
column8352: resulting in privilege escalation attack. An address overlap weakness can also be used to launch a denial of service attack on the higher-privilege software memory regions."
column8354: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe register interface provides software access to hardware functionality. This functionality is an attack surface. This attack surface may be used to run untrusted code on the system through the register interface. As an example
column8355: cryptographic accelerators require a mechanism for software to select modes of operation and to provide plaintext or ciphertext data to be encrypted or decrypted as well as other functions. This functionality is commonly provided through registers.\n"
column8356: name:"Improper Access Control for Register Interface"
column8361: description:"The product uses memory-mapped I\/O registers that act as an interface to hardware functionality from software
column8362: but there is improper access control to those registers. Software commonly accesses peripherals in a System-on-Chip (SoC) or other device through a memory-mapped register interface. Malicious software could tamper with any security-critical hardware data that is accessible directly or indirectly through the register interface
column8363: which could lead to a loss of confidentiality and integrity."
column8368: description:"The product is designed with access restricted to certain information
column8369: but it does not sufficiently protect against an unauthorized actor with physical access to these areas. Sections of a product intended to have restricted access may be inadvertently or intentionally rendered accessible when the implemented physical protections are insufficient. The specific requirements around how robust the design of the physical protection mechanism needs to be depends on the type of product being protected. Selecting the correct physical protection mechanism and properly enforcing it through implementation and manufacturing are critical to the overall physical security of the product."
column8371: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nSensitive manufacturing data (such as die information) are stored in fuses. When the chip powers on
column8372: these values are read from the fuses and stored in microarchitectural registers. These registers are only given read access to trusted software running on the core. Untrusted software running on the core is not allowed to access these registers.\n"
column8373: name:"Sensitive Non-Volatile Information Not Protected During Debug"
column8375: description:"Access to security-sensitive information stored in fuses is not limited during debug. Several security-sensitive values are programmed into fuses to be used during early-boot flows or later at runtime. Examples of these security-sensitive values include root keys
column8379: and original-equipment-manufacturer (OEM) data. After the chip is powered on
column8380: these values are sensed from fuses and stored in temporary locations such as registers and local memories. These locations are typically access-control protected from untrusted agents capable of accessing them. Even to trusted agents
column8382: these locations are not blocked during debug operations
column8383: allowing a user to access this sensitive information."

column8451: name:"Policy Privileges are not Assigned Consistently Between Control and Data Agents"
column8453: description:"The product's hardware-enforced access control for a particular resource improperly accounts for privilege discrepancies between control and write policies. Integrated circuits and hardware engines may provide access to resources (device-configuration
column8455: etc.) belonging to trusted firmware or software modules (commonly set by a BIOS or a bootloader). These accesses are typically controlled and limited by the hardware. Hardware design access control is sometimes implemented using a policy. A policy defines which entity or agent may or may not be allowed to perform an action. When a system implements multiple levels of policies
column8456: a control policy may allow direct access to a resource as well as changes to the policies themselves. Resources that include agents in their control policy but not in their write policy could unintentionally allow an untrusted agent to insert itself in the write policy register. Inclusion in the write policy register could allow a malicious or misbehaving agent write access to resources. This action could result in security compromises including leaked information

column8469: description:"The product implements a Security Token mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. However
column8470: the Security Tokens generated in the system are incorrect. Systems-On-a-Chip (SoC) (Integrated circuits and hardware engines) implement Security Tokens to differentiate and identify actions originated from various agents. These actions could be \"read\"
column8476: etc. Security Tokens are generated and assigned to every agent on the SoC that is either capable of generating an action or receiving an action from another agent. Every agent could be assigned a unique

Incorrectly generated Security Tokens could result in the same token used for multiple agents or multiple tokens being used for the same agent. This condition could result in a Denial-of-Service (DoS) or the execution of an action that in turn could result in privilege escalation or unintended access."

column8486: name:"Improper Access Control for Volatile Memory Containing Boot Code"
column8488: description:"The product conducts a secure-boot process that transfers bootloader code from Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) into Volatile Memory (VM)
column8489: but it does not have sufficient access control or other protections for the Volatile Memory. Adversaries could bypass the secure-boot process and execute their own untrusted
column8490: malicious boot code. As a part of a secure-boot process
column8491: the read-only-memory (ROM) code for a System-on-Chip (SoC) or other system fetches bootloader code from Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) and stores the code in Volatile Memory (VM)
column8494: random-access memory (SRAM). The NVM is usually external to the SoC
column8495: while the VM is internal to the SoC. As the code is transferred from NVM to VM
column8496: it is authenticated by the SoC's ROM code. If the volatile-memory-region protections or access controls are insufficient to prevent modifications from an adversary or untrusted agent
column8497: the secure boot may be bypassed or replaced with the execution of an adversary's code."
column8499: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nMany SoCs use hardware to partition system resources between trusted and un-trusted entities. One example of this concept is the Arm TrustZone
column8500: in which the processor and all security-aware IP attempt to isolate resources based on the status of a privilege bit. This privilege bit is part of the input interface in all TrustZone-aware IP. If this privilege bit is accidentally grounded or left unconnected when the IP is instantiated

column8503: name:"Hardware Child Block Incorrectly Connected to Parent System"
column8505: description:"Signals between a hardware IP and the parent system design are incorrectly connected causing security risks. Individual hardware IP must communicate with the parent system in order for the product to function correctly and as intended. If implemented incorrectly
column8506: while not causing any apparent functional issues

column8508: if the IP should only be reset by a system-wide hard reset
column8509: but instead the reset input is connected to a software-triggered debug mode reset (which is also asserted during a hard reset)
column8510: integrity of data inside the IP can be violated."

column8660: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA memory-controller IP block is connected to the on-chip fabric in a System on Chip (SoC). The memory controller is configured to divide the memory into four parts: one original and three mirrored regions inside the memory. The upper two bits of the address indicate which region is being addressed. 00 indicates the original region and 01
column8662: and 11 are used to address the mirrored regions. All four regions operate in a lock-step manner and are always synchronized. The firewall in the on-chip fabric is programmed to protect the assets in the memory.\nThe firewall only protects the original range but not the mirrored regions.\nThe attacker (as an unprivileged user) sends a write transaction to the mirrored region. The mirrored region has an address with the upper two bits set to \"10\" and the remaining bits of the address pointing to an asset. The firewall does not block this write transaction. Once the write is successful
column8663: contents in the protected-memory region are also updated. Thus
column8665: memory protections.\nFirewall should protect mirrored regions.\n"
column8666: name:"Missing Protection for Mirrored Regions in On-Chip Fabric Firewall"
column8668: description:"The firewall in an on-chip fabric protects the main addressed region
column8669: but it does not protect any mirrored memory or memory-mapped-IO (MMIO) regions. Few fabrics mirror memory and address ranges
column8670: where mirrored regions contain copies of the original data. This redundancy is used to achieve fault tolerance. Whatever protections the fabric firewall implements for the original region should also apply to the mirrored regions. If not
column8671: an attacker could bypass existing read\/write protections by reading from\/writing to the mirrored regions to leak or corrupt the original data."
column8674: name:"Hardware Allows Activation of Test or Debug Logic at Runtime"
column8677: the hardware allows for test or debug logic (feature) to be activated

An adversary can take advantage of test or debug logic that is made accessible through the hardware during normal operation to modify the intended behavior of the system. For example
column8679: an accessible Test\/debug mode may allow read\/write access to any system data. Using error injection (a common test\/debug feature) during a transmit\/receive operation on a bus
column8680: data may be modified to produce an unintended message. Similarly
column8681: confidentiality could be compromised by such features allowing access to secrets."

The responder devices should have the bus-control-enable bit in the PCIe-end-point register set to 0 in hardware to prevent the devices from controlling transactions to the CPU or other peripherals.\nThe audio-codec chip does not have the bus-controller-enable-register bit hardcoded to 0. column8696: name:"Improper Setting of Bus Controlling Capability in Fabric End-point"
column8698: description:"The bus controller enables bits in the fabric end-point to allow responder devices to control transactions on the fabric. To support reusability
column8699: certain fabric interfaces and end points provide a configurable register bit that allows IP blocks connected to the controller to access other peripherals connected to the fabric. This allows the end point to be used with devices that function as a controller or responder. If this bit is set by default in hardware

column8703: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nAn on-chip fabric supports a 64KB address space that is memory-mapped. The fabric has two range registers that support creation of two protected ranges with specific size constraints--4KB
column8705: 16KB or 32KB. Assets that belong to user A require 4KB
column8706: and those of user B require 20KB. Registers and other assets that are not security-sensitive require 40KB. One range register is configured to program 4KB to protect user A's assets. Since a 20KB range cannot be created with the given size constraints
column8707: the range register for user B's assets is configured as 32KB. The rest of the address space is left as open. As a result
column8708: some part of untrusted and open-address space overlaps with user B range.\nThe fabric does not support least privilege
column8709: and an attacker can send a transaction to the overlapping region to tamper with user B data.\nSince range B only requires 20KB but is allotted 32KB
column8710: there is 12KB of reserved space. Overlapping this region of user B data
column8712: with the untrusted space will prevent an attacker from tampering with user B data.\n"
column8713: name:"Fabric-Address Map Allows Programming of Unwarranted Overlaps of Protected and Unprotected Ranges"
column8715: description:"The address map of the on-chip fabric has protected and unprotected regions overlapping
column8716: allowing an attacker to bypass access control to the overlapping portion of the protected region. Various ranges can be defined in the system-address map
column8717: either in the memory or in Memory-Mapped-IO (MMIO) space. These ranges are usually defined using special range registers that contain information
column8718: such as base address and size. Address decoding is the process of determining for which range the incoming transaction is destined. To ensure isolation
column8719: ranges containing secret data are access-control protected. Occasionally
column8720: these ranges could overlap. The overlap could either be intentional (e.g. due to a limited number of range registers or limited choice in choosing size of the range) or unintentional (e.g. introduced by errors). Some hardware designs allow dynamic remapping of address ranges assigned to peripheral MMIO ranges. In such designs
column8721: intentional address overlaps can be created through misconfiguration by malicious software. When protected and unprotected ranges overlap
column8722: an attacker could send a transaction and potentially compromise the protections in place
column8723: violating the principle of least privilege."

column8730: etc.) over AHB interface to an LPC bus. Several peripherals are connected to the LPC bus. The bridge is expected to check the privilege level of the transactions initiated in the core before forwarding them to the peripherals on the LPC bus.\nThe bridge does not implement the checks and allows reads and writes from all privilege levels.\nTo address this
column8731: designers should implement hardware-based checks that are either hardcoded to block untrusted agents from accessing secure peripherals or implement firmware flows that configure the bridge to block untrusted agents from making arbitrary reads or writes.\n"
column8732: name:"Improper Access Control in Fabric Bridge"
column8734: description:"The product uses a fabric bridge for transactions between two Intellectual Property (IP) blocks
column8735: but the bridge does not properly perform the expected privilege
column8737: or other access control checks between those IP blocks. In hardware designs
column8738: different IP blocks are connected through interconnect-bus fabrics (e.g. AHB and OCP). Within a System on Chip (SoC)
column8739: the IP block subsystems could be using different bus protocols. In such a case
column8740: the IP blocks are then linked to the central bus (and to other IP blocks) through a fabric bridge. Bridges are used as bus-interconnect-routing modules that link different protocols or separate
column8741: different segments of the overall SoC interconnect. For overall system security
column8742: it is important that the access-control privileges associated with any fabric transaction are consistently maintained and applied
column8743: even when they are routed or translated by a fabric bridge. A bridge that is connected to a fabric without security features forwards transactions to the slave without checking the privilege level of the master and results in a weakness in SoC access-control security. The same weakness occurs if a bridge does not check the hardware identity of the transaction received from the slave interface of the bridge."
column8745: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\n\nConsider a platform design where a Digital-Thermal Sensor (DTS) is used to monitor temperature and compare that output against a threshold value. If the temperature output equals or exceeds the threshold value

input triggers system shutdown. The alert signal is handled as a General-Purpose-I/O (GPIO) pin in input mode.

"
column8749: name:"Improper Protection for Outbound Error Messages and Alert Signals"
column8751: description:"Untrusted agents can disable alerts about signal conditions exceeding limits or the response mechanism that handles such alerts. Hardware sensors are used to detect whether a device is operating within design limits. The threshold values for these limits are set by hardware fuses or trusted software such as a BIOS. Modification of these limits may be protected by hardware mechanisms. When device sensors detect out of bound conditions
column8752: alert signals may be generated for remedial action
column8753: which may take the form of device shutdown or throttling. Warning signals that are not properly secured may be disabled or used to generate spurious alerts
column8754: causing degraded performance or denial-of-service (DoS). These alerts may be masked by untrusted software. Examples of these alerts involve thermal and power sensor alerts."

column8767: name:"Improper Management of Sensitive Trace Data"
column8769: description:"Trace data collected from several sources on the System-on-Chip (SoC) is stored in unprotected locations or transported to untrusted agents. To facilitate verification of complex System-on-Chip (SoC) designs
column8770: SoC integrators add specific IP blocks that trace the SoC's internal signals in real-time. This infrastructure enables observability of the SoC's internal behavior
column8772: and detection of hardware and software bugs. Such tracing IP blocks collect traces from several sources on the SoC including the CPU
column8774: and on-chip fabrics. Traces collected from these sources are then aggregated inside trace IP block and forwarded to trace sinks
column8775: such as debug-trace ports that facilitate debugging by external hardware and software debuggers. Since these traces are collected from several security-sensitive sources
column8776: they must be protected against untrusted debuggers. If they are stored in unprotected memory
column8777: an untrusted software debugger can access these traces and extract secret information. Additionally
column8778: if security-sensitive traces are not tagged as secure
column8779: an untrusted hardware debugger might access them to extract confidential information."
column8782: name:"Unauthorized Error Injection Can Degrade Hardware Redundancy"
column8784: description:"An unauthorized agent can inject errors into a redundant block to deprive the system of redundancy or put the system in a degraded operating mode. To ensure the performance and functional reliability of certain components
column8785: hardware designers can implement hardware blocks for redundancy in the case that others fail. This redundant block can be prevented from performing as intended if the design allows unauthorized agents to inject errors into it. In this way
column8786: a path with injected errors may become unavailable to serve as a redundant channel. This may put the system into a degraded mode of operation which could be exploited by a subsequent attack."

column8838: description:"The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required

column8883: description:"Allowing a .NET application to run at potentially escalated levels of access to the underlying operating and file systems can be dangerous and result in various forms of attacks. .NET server applications can optionally execute using the identity of the user authenticated to the client. Authentication is done by the underlying web server (Microsoft Internet Information Service IIS)
column8886: to the .NET application. Using the token to impersonate the client

column8892: name:"ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Use of Identity Impersonation"
column8894: description:"Configuring an ASP.NET application to run with impersonated credentials may give the application unnecessary privileges. column9112:
{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
This example considers the Rowhammer problem [REF-1083]. The Rowhammer issue was caused by a program in a tight loop writing repeatedly to a location to which the program was allowed to write but causing an adjacent memory location value to change.
Preventing the loop required to defeat the Rowhammer exploit is not always possible:
While the redesign may be possible for new devices
column9113: a redesign is not possible in existing devices. There is also the possibility that reducing capacitance with a relayout would impact the density of the device resulting in a less capable
column9114:
more costly device.
Example 2
Suppose a hardware design implements a set of software-accessible registers for scaling clock frequency and voltage but does not control access to these registers. Attackers may cause register and memory changes and race conditions by changing the clock or voltage of the device under their control.
Example 3
Consider the following SoC design. Security-critical settings for scaling clock frequency and voltage are available in a range of registers bounded by [PRIV_END_ADDR : PRIV_START_ADDR] in the tmcu.csr module in the HW Root of Trust. These values are writable based on the lock_bit register in the same module. The lock_bit is only writable by privileged software running on the tmcu.

We assume that untrusted software running on any of the Core{0-N} processors has access to the input and output ports of the hrot_iface. If untrusted software can clear the lock_bit or write the clock frequency and voltage registers due to inadequate protection
column9115: a fault injection attack could be performed.\n\n"
column9116: name:"Improper Restriction of Software Interfaces to Hardware Features"
column9122: description:"The product provides software-controllable device functionality for capabilities such as power and clock management
column9123: but it does not properly limit functionality that can lead to modification of hardware memory or register bits
column9124: or the ability to observe physical side channels. It is frequently assumed that physical attacks such as fault injection and side-channel analysis require an attacker to have physical access to the target device. This assumption may be false if the device has improperly secured power management features
column9125: or similar features. For mobile devices
column9127: but these devices run a wide variety of applications with different performance requirements. Software-controllable mechanisms to dynamically scale device voltage and frequency and monitor power consumption are common features in today's chipsets
column9128: but they also enable attackers to mount fault injection and side-channel attacks without having physical access to the device. Fault injection attacks involve strategic manipulation of bits in a device to achieve a desired effect such as skipping an authentication step
column9130: or altering the output of a cryptographic operation. Manipulation of the device clock and voltage supply is a well-known technique to inject faults and is cheap to implement with physical device access. Poorly protected power management features allow these attacks to be performed from software. Other features
column9131: such as the ability to write repeatedly to DRAM at a rapid rate from unprivileged software
column9132: can result in bit flips in other memory locations (Rowhammer
column9133: [REF-1083]). Side channel analysis requires gathering measurement traces of physical quantities such as power consumption. Modern processors often include power metering capabilities in the hardware itself (e.g.
column9134: Intel RAPL) which if not adequately protected enable attackers to gather measurements necessary for performing side-channel attacks from software."
column9136: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following example shows how an attacker can take advantage of a piece of confidential information that has not been protected from the OSAT.\nSuppose the preproduction device contains NVM (a storage medium that by definition\/design can retain its data without power)
column9137:
and this NVM contains a key that can unlock all the parts for that generation. An OSAT facility accidentally leaks the key.
Compromising a key that can unlock all the parts of a generation can be devastating to a chipmaker.
The likelihood of such a compromise can be reduced by ensuring all memories on the preproduction device are properly scrubbed.
"
column9138: name:"Unprotected Confidential Information on Device is Accessible by OSAT Vendors"
column9140: description:"The product does not adequately protect confidential information on the device from being accessed by Outsourced Semiconductor Assembly and Test (OSAT) vendors. In contrast to complete vertical integration of architecting
column9144: and testing chips all within a single organization
column9145: an organization can choose to simply architect and design a chip before outsourcing the rest of the process to OSAT entities (e.g.
column9146: external foundries and test houses). In the latter example
column9147: the device enters an OSAT facility in a much more vulnerable pre-production stage where many debug and test modes are accessible. Therefore
column9148: the chipmaker must place a certain level of trust with the OSAT. To counter this
column9149: the chipmaker often requires the OSAT partner to enter into restrictive non-disclosure agreements (NDAs). Nonetheless
column9150: OSAT vendors likely have many customers
column9151: which increases the risk of accidental sharing of information. There may also be a security vulnerability in the information technology (IT) system of the OSAT facility. Alternatively
column9152: a malicious insider at the OSAT facility may carry out an insider attack. Considering these factors
column9153: it behooves the chipmaker to minimize any confidential information in the device that may be accessible to the OSAT vendor. Logic errors during design or synthesis could misconfigure the interconnection of the debug components
column9154: which could provide improper authorization to sensitive information."
column9156: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA new version of firmware is signed with a security version number higher than the previous version. During the firmware update process the SoC checks for the security version number and upgrades the SoC firmware with the latest version. This security version number is stored in persistent memory upon successful upgrade for use across power-on resets.\nIn general
column9157: if the security version number is mutable
column9158: the implementation is vulnerable. A mutable security version number allows an adversary to change the security version to a lower value to allow roll-back or to a higher value to prevent future upgrades.\nThe security version number should be stored in immutable hardware such as fuses
column9159: and the writes to these fuses should be highly access-controlled with appropriate authentication and authorization protections.\n"
column9160: name:"Security Version Number Mutable to Older Versions"
column9162: description:"Security-version number in hardware is mutable
column9163: resulting in the ability to downgrade (roll-back) the boot firmware to vulnerable code versions. A System-on-Chip (SoC) implements secure boot or verified boot. It might support a security version number
column9164: which prevents downgrading the current firmware to a vulnerable version. Once downgraded to a previous version
column9165: an adversary can launch exploits on the SoC and thus compromise the security of the SoC. These downgrade attacks are also referred to as roll-back attacks. The security version number must be stored securely and persistently across power-on resets. A common weakness is that the security version number is modifiable by an adversary
column9166: allowing roll-back or downgrade attacks or
column9168: preventing upgrades (i.e. Denial-of-Service on upgrades). In both cases
column9169: the SoC is in a vulnerable state."

column9260: name:"Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information"
column9262: description:"The web application uses persistent cookies
column9263: but the cookies contain sensitive information. Cookies are small bits of data that are sent by the web application but stored locally in the browser. Typical types of information stored in cookies are session identifiers
column9265: and in rare cases even usernames to enable automated logins. There are two different types of cookies: session cookies and persistent cookies. Session cookies just live in the browser's memory and are not stored anywhere

column9418: name:"Missing Write Protection for Parametric Data Values"
column9420: description:"The device does not write-protect the parametric data values for sensors that scale the sensor value
column9421: allowing untrusted software to manipulate the apparent result and potentially damage hardware or cause operational failure. Various sensors are used by hardware to detect any devices operating outside of the design limits. The threshold limit values are set by hardware fuses or trusted software such as the BIOS. These limits may be related to thermal
column9425: and frequency. Hardware mechanisms may be used to protect against alteration of the threshold limit values by untrusted software. The limit values are generally programmed in standard units for the type of value being read. However
column9426: the hardware-sensor blocks may report the settings in different units depending upon sensor design and operation. The raw sensor output value is converted to the desired units using a scale conversion based on the parametric data programmed into the sensor. The final converted value is then compared with the previously programmed limits. While the limit values are usually protected
column9427: the sensor parametric data values may not be. By changing the parametric data
column9428: safe operational limits may be bypassed."

column9446: description:"The web application does not adequately enforce appropriate authorization on all restricted URLs

column9450: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nWhen executable library files are used on web servers
column9451: which is common in PHP applications
column9452: the developer might perform an access check in any user-facing executable
column9453: and omit the access check from the library file itself. By directly requesting the library file (CWE-425)
column9454: an attacker can bypass this access check.\nExample 2\nWhen a developer begins to implement input validation for a web application
column9455: often the validation is performed in each area of the code that uses externally-controlled input. In complex applications with many inputs
column9456: the developer often misses a parameter here or a cookie there. One frequently-applied solution is to centralize all input validation
column9457: store these validated inputs in a separate data structure
column9458: and require that all access of those inputs must be through that data structure. An alternate approach would be to use an external input validation framework such as Struts
column9459: which performs the validation before the inputs are ever processed by the code.\n"

column9507: description:"The product performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action
column9508: but it does not correctly perform the check. This allows attackers to bypass intended access restrictions. Assuming a user with a given identity
column9509: authorization is the process of determining whether that user can access a given resource
column9510: based on the user's privileges and any permissions or other access-control specifications that apply to the resource. When access control checks are incorrectly applied
column9511: users are able to access data or perform actions that they should not be allowed to perform. This can lead to a wide range of problems
column9516: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe JTAG interface is used to perform debugging and provide CPU core access for developers. JTAG-access protection is implemented as part of the JTAG_SHIELD bit in the hw_digctl_ctrl register. This register has no default value at power up and is set only after the system boots from ROM and control is transferred to the user software.\nThis means that since the end user has access to JTAG at system reset and during ROM code execution before control is transferred to user software
column9517: a JTAG user can modify the boot flow and subsequently disclose all CPU information
column9519: name:"Internal Asset Exposed to Unsafe Debug Access Level or State"
column9521: description:"The product uses physical debug or test interfaces with support for multiple access levels
column9522: but it assigns the wrong debug access level to an internal asset
column9523: providing unintended access to the asset from untrusted debug agents. Debug authorization can have multiple levels of access
column9524: defined such that different system internal assets are accessible based on the current authorized debug level. Other than debugger authentication (e.g.
column9526: the authorization can also be based on the system state or boot stage. For example
column9527: full system debug access might only be allowed early in boot after a system reset to ensure that previous session data is not accessible to the authenticated debugger. If this protection mechanism does not ensure that internal assets have the correct debug access level during each boot stage or change in system state
column9528: an attacker could obtain sensitive information from the internal asset using a debugger."
column9531: name:"Incorrect Behavior Order: Authorization Before Parsing and Canonicalization"
column9533: description:"If a web server does not fully parse requested URLs before it examines them for authorization
column9534: it may be possible for an attacker to bypass authorization protection. For instance
column9535: the character strings \/.\/ and \/ both mean current directory. If \/SomeDirectory is a protected directory and an attacker requests \/.\/SomeDirectory
column9536: the attacker may be able to gain access to the resource if \/.\/ is not converted to \/ before the authorization check is performed."
column9541: description:"The system's authorization functionality does not prevent one user from gaining access to another user's data or record by modifying the key value identifying the data. Retrieval of a user record occurs in the system based on some key value that is under user control. The key would typically identify a user-related record stored in the system and would be used to lookup that record for presentation to the user. It is likely that an attacker would have to be an authenticated user in the system. However
column9542: the authorization process would not properly check the data access operation to ensure that the authenticated user performing the operation has sufficient entitlements to perform the requested data access
column9543: hence bypassing any other authorization checks present in the system. For example
column9544: attackers can look at places where user specific data is retrieved (e.g. search screens) and determine whether the key for the item being looked up is controllable externally. The key may be a hidden field in the HTML form field
column9545: might be passed as a URL parameter or as an unencrypted cookie variable
column9546: then in each of these cases it will be possible to tamper with the key value. One manifestation of this weakness is when a system uses sequential or otherwise easily-guessable session IDs that would allow one user to easily switch to another user's session and read\/modify their data."
column9549: \"Using Alternative IP Address Encodings\"). An attacker identifies an application server that applies a security policy based on the domain and application name
column9550: so the access control policy covers authentication and authorization for anyone accessing http:\/\/example.domain:8080\/application. However
column9551: by putting in the IP address of the host the application authentication and authorization controls may be bypassed http:\/\/192.168.0.1:8080\/application. The attacker relies on the victim applying policy to the namespace abstraction and not having a default deny policy in place to manage exceptions.\n"
column9552: name:"Use of Non-Canonical URL Paths for Authorization Decisions"
column9554: description:"The product defines policy namespaces and makes authorization decisions based on the assumption that a URL is canonical. This can allow a non-canonical URL to bypass the authorization. If an application defines policy namespaces and makes authorization decisions based on the URL
column9555: but it does not require or convert to a canonical URL before making the authorization decision
column9556: then it opens the application to attack. For example
column9557: if the application only wants to allow access to http:\/\/www.example.com\/mypage
column9558: then the attacker might be able to bypass this restriction using equivalent URLs such as: http:\/\/WWW.EXAMPLE.COM\/mypage http:\/\/www.example.com\/%6Dypage (alternate encoding) http:\/\/192.168.1.1\/mypage (IP address) http:\/\/www.example.com\/mypage\/ (trailing \/) http:\/\/www.example.com:80\/mypage Therefore it is important to specify access control policy that is based on the path information in some canonical form with all alternate encodings rejected (which can be accomplished by a default deny rule)."
column9563: description:"The product uses a CAPTCHA challenge
column9564: but the challenge can be guessed or automatically recognized by a non-human actor. An automated attacker could bypass the intended protection of the CAPTCHA challenge and perform actions at a higher frequency than humanly possible
column9565: such as launching spam attacks. There can be several different causes of a guessable CAPTCHA: An audio or visual image that does not have sufficient distortion from the unobfuscated source image. A question is generated with a format that can be automatically recognized
column9566: such as a math question. A question for which the number of possible answers is limited
column9567: such as birth years or favorite sports teams. A general-knowledge or trivia question for which the answer can be accessed using a data base
column9568: such as country capitals or popular entertainers. Other data associated with the CAPTCHA may provide hints about its contents
column9569: such as an image whose filename contains the word that is used in the CAPTCHA."
column9571: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis application is exporting an activity and a service in its manifest.xml:\nBecause these components have intent filters but have not explicitly set 'android:exported=false' elsewhere in the manifest
column9572:
they are automatically exported so that any other application can launch them. This may lead to unintended behavior or exploits.
Example 2
This application has created a content provider to enable custom search suggestions within the application:
Because this content provider is only intended to be used within the application
column9573: it does not need to be exported. However
column9575: it is automatically exported thus potentially allowing malicious applications to access sensitive information.\n"
column9576: name:"Improper Export of Android Application Components"
column9578: description:"The Android application exports a component for use by other applications
column9579: but does not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains. The attacks and consequences of improperly exporting a component may depend on the exported component: If access to an exported Activity is not restricted
column9580: any application will be able to launch the activity. This may allow a malicious application to gain access to sensitive information
column9581: modify the internal state of the application
column9582: or trick a user into interacting with the victim application while believing they are still interacting with the malicious application. If access to an exported Service is not restricted
column9583: any application may start and bind to the Service. Depending on the exposed functionality
column9584: this may allow a malicious application to perform unauthorized actions
column9586: or corrupt the internal state of the application. If access to a Content Provider is not restricted to only the expected applications
column9587: then malicious applications might be able to access the sensitive data. Note that in Android before 4.2
column9588: the Content Provider is automatically exported unless it has been explicitly declared as NOT exported."
column9590: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis application wants to create a user account in several trusted applications using one broadcast intent:\nThis application assumes only the trusted applications will be listening for the action. A malicious application can register for this action and intercept the user's login information
column9591: as below:\nWhen a broadcast contains sensitive information
column9592: create an allowlist of applications that can receive the action using the application's manifest file
column9593: or programmatically send the intent to each individual intended receiver.\nExample 2\nThis application interfaces with a web service that requires a separate user login. It creates a sticky intent
column9594: so that future trusted applications that also use the web service will know who the current user is:\nSticky broadcasts can be read by any application at any time
column9595: and so should never contain sensitive information such as a username.\nExample 3\nThis application is sending an ordered broadcast
column9596: asking other applications to open a URL:\nAny application in the broadcast chain may alter the data within the intent. This malicious application is altering the URL to point to an attack site:\nThe final receiving application will then open the attack URL. Where possible
column9597:
send intents to specific trusted applications instead of using a broadcast chain.
Example 4
This application sends a special intent with a flag that allows the receiving application to read a data file for backup purposes.
Any malicious application can register to receive this intent. Because of the FLAG_GRANT_READ_URI_PERMISSION included with the intent
column9598: the malicious receiver code can read the user's data.\n"
column9599: name:"Use of Implicit Intent for Sensitive Communication"
column9601: description:"The Android application uses an implicit intent for transmitting sensitive data to other applications. Since an implicit intent does not specify a particular application to receive the data
column9602: any application can process the intent by using an Intent Filter for that intent. This can allow untrusted applications to obtain sensitive data. There are two variations on the standard broadcast intent
column9603: ordered and sticky. Ordered broadcast intents are delivered to a series of registered receivers in order of priority as declared by the Receivers. A malicious receiver can give itself a high priority and cause a denial of service by stopping the broadcast from propagating further down the chain. There is also the possibility of malicious data modification
column9604: as a receiver may also alter the data within the Intent before passing it on to the next receiver. The downstream components have no way of asserting that the data has not been altered earlier in the chain. Sticky broadcast intents remain accessible after the initial broadcast. An old sticky intent will be broadcast again to any new receivers that register for it in the future
column9605: greatly increasing the chances of information exposure over time. Also
column9606: sticky broadcasts cannot be protected by permissions that may apply to other kinds of intents. In addition
column9607: any broadcast intent may include a URI that references data that the receiving component does not normally have the privileges to access. The sender of the intent can include special privileges that grant the receiver read or write access to the specific URI included in the intent. A malicious receiver that intercepts this intent will also gain those privileges and be able to read or write the resource at the specified URI."
column9612: description:"The product does not properly manage a user within its environment. Users can be assigned to the wrong group (class) of permissions resulting in unintended access rights to sensitive objects."
column9615: name:"Placement of User into Incorrect Group"
column9622: description:"The product or the administrator places a user into an incorrect group. If the incorrect group has more access or privileges than the intended group
column9623: the user might be able to bypass intended security policy to access unexpected resources or perform unexpected actions. The access-control system might not be able to detect malicious usage of this group membership."
column9625: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code intends to ensure that the user is already logged in. If not
column9626: the code performs authentication with the user-provided username and password. If successful
column9627: it sets the loggedin and user cookies to \"remember\" that the user has already logged in. Finally
column9628: the code performs administrator tasks if the logged-in user has the \"Administrator\" username
column9629: as recorded in the user cookie.\nUnfortunately
column9630: this code can be bypassed. The attacker can set the cookies independently so that the code does not check the username and password. The attacker could do this with an HTTP request containing headers such as:\nBy setting the loggedin cookie to \"true\"
column9631: the attacker bypasses the entire authentication check. By using the \"Administrator\" value in the user cookie
column9632: the attacker also gains privileges to administer the software.\nExample 2\nIn January 2009
column9633: an attacker was able to gain administrator access to a Twitter server because the server did not restrict the number of login attempts [REF-236]. The attacker targeted a member of Twitter's support team and was able to successfully guess the member's password using a brute force attack by guessing a large number of common words. After gaining access as the member of the support staff
column9634: the attacker used the administrator panel to gain access to 33 accounts that belonged to celebrities and politicians. Ultimately
column9635: fake Twitter messages were sent that appeared to come from the compromised accounts.\nExample 3\nIn 2022
column9636: the OT:ICEFALL study examined products by 10 different Operational Technology (OT) vendors. The researchers reported 56 vulnerabilities and said that the products were \"insecure by design\" [REF-1283]. If exploited
column9637: these vulnerabilities often allowed adversaries to change how the products operated
column9638: ranging from denial of service to changing the code that the products executed. Since these products were often used in industries such as power
column9642: there could even be safety implications.\nMultiple vendors did not use any authentication or used client-side authentication for critical functionality in their OT products.\n"

column9713: description:"The product uses weak credentials (such as a default key or hard-coded password) that can be calculated
column9716: or guessed by an attacker. By design
column9717: authentication protocols try to ensure that attackers must perform brute force attacks if they do not know the credentials such as a key or password. However
column9718: when these credentials are easily predictable or even fixed (as with default or hard-coded passwords and keys)
column9719: then the attacker can defeat the mechanism without relying on brute force. Credentials may be weak for different reasons
column9721: static and unchangeable by the administrator) Default (i.e.
column9722: the same static value across different deployments\/installations
column9723: but able to be changed by the administrator) Predictable (i.e.
column9724: generated in a way that produces unique credentials across deployments\/installations
column9725: but can still be guessed with reasonable efficiency) Even if a new
column9726: unique credential is intended to be generated for each product installation
column9728: then that may also simplify guessing attacks."
column9731: the OT:ICEFALL study examined products by 10 different Operational Technology (OT) vendors. The researchers reported 56 vulnerabilities and said that the products were \"insecure by design\" [REF-1283]. If exploited
column9732: these vulnerabilities often allowed adversaries to change how the products operated
column9733: ranging from denial of service to changing the code that the products executed. Since these products were often used in industries such as power
column9737: there could even be safety implications.\nAt least one OT product used default credentials.\n"
column9743: description:"The product uses default credentials (such as passwords or cryptographic keys) for potentially critical functionality. It is common practice for products to be designed to use default keys
column9745: or other mechanisms for authentication. The rationale is to simplify the manufacturing process or the system administrator's task of installation and deployment into an enterprise. However
column9746: if admins do not change the defaults
column9747: it is easier for attackers to bypass authentication quickly across multiple organizations."
column9750: the OT:ICEFALL study examined products by 10 different Operational Technology (OT) vendors. The researchers reported 56 vulnerabilities and said that the products were \"insecure by design\" [REF-1283]. If exploited
column9751: these vulnerabilities often allowed adversaries to change how the products operated
column9752: ranging from denial of service to changing the code that the products executed. Since these products were often used in industries such as power
column9756: there could even be safety implications.\nMultiple OT products used default credentials.\n"
column9766: description:"The product uses default passwords for potentially critical functionality. It is common practice for products to be designed to use default passwords for authentication. The rationale is to simplify the manufacturing process or the system administrator's task of installation and deployment into an enterprise. However
column9767: if admins do not change the defaults
column9768: then it makes it easier for attackers to quickly bypass authentication across multiple organizations. There are many lists of default passwords and default-password scanning tools that are easily available from the World Wide Web."
column9775: description:"The product uses a default cryptographic key for potentially critical functionality. It is common practice for products to be designed to use default keys. The rationale is to simplify the manufacturing process or the system administrator's task of installation and deployment into an enterprise. However
column9776: if admins do not change the defaults
column9777: it is easier for attackers to bypass authentication quickly across multiple organizations."
column9782: description:"The product does not require that users should have strong passwords
column9783: which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism."

column9891: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA system does not enforce the changing of passwords every certain period.\n"
column9894: description:"The product does not have a mechanism in place for managing password aging. Password aging (or password rotation) is a policy that forces users to change their passwords after a defined time period passes
column9895: such as every 30 or 90 days. Without mechanisms such as aging
column9896: users might not change their passwords in a timely manner. Note that while password aging was once considered an important security feature
column9897: it has since fallen out of favor by many
column9898: because it is not as effective against modern threats compared to other mechanisms such as slow hashes. In addition
column9899: forcing frequent changes can unintentionally encourage users to select less-secure passwords. However
column9900: password aging is still in use due to factors such as compliance requirements
column9902: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS)."
column9904: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA system requires the changing of passwords every five years.\n"
column9908: but the expiration period is too long. Password aging (or password rotation) is a policy that forces users to change their passwords after a defined time period passes
column9909: such as every 30 or 90 days. A long expiration provides more time for attackers to conduct password cracking before users are forced to change to a new password. Note that while password aging was once considered an important security feature
column9910: it has since fallen out of favor by many
column9911: because it is not as effective against modern threats compared to other mechanisms such as slow hashes. In addition
column9912: forcing frequent changes can unintentionally encourage users to select less-secure passwords. However
column9913: password aging is still in use due to factors such as compliance requirements
column9915: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS)."

column9927: thus impersonating a trusted client.\nExample 3\nThe following code samples use a DNS lookup in order to decide whether or not an inbound request is from a trusted host. If an attacker can poison the DNS cache
column9928: they can gain trusted status.\nIP addresses are more reliable than DNS names
column9929: but they can also be spoofed. Attackers can easily forge the source IP address of the packets they send
column9930: but response packets will return to the forged IP address. To see the response packets
column9931: the attacker has to sniff the traffic between the victim machine and the forged IP address. In order to accomplish the required sniffing
column9932: attackers typically attempt to locate themselves on the same subnet as the victim machine. Attackers may be able to circumvent this requirement by using source routing
column9933: but source routing is disabled across much of the Internet today. In summary
column9934: IP address verification can be a useful part of an authentication scheme
column9935: but it should not be the single factor required for authentication.\n"

column9990: or (2) having legitimate control over a DNS server associated with their IP address."
column9996: description:"A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes). Capture-replay attacks are common and can be difficult to defeat without cryptography. They are a subset of network injection attacks that rely on observing previously-sent valid commands
column9997: then changing them slightly if necessary and resending the same commands to the server."
column10000: name:"Reflection Attack in an Authentication Protocol"
column10002: description:"Simple authentication protocols are subject to reflection attacks if a malicious user can use the target machine to impersonate a trusted user. A mutual authentication protocol requires each party to respond to a random challenge by the other party by encrypting it with a pre-shared key. Often
column10004: such protocols employ the same pre-shared key for communication with a number of different entities. A malicious user or an attacker can easily compromise this protocol without possessing the correct key by employing a reflection attack on the protocol. Reflection attacks capitalize on mutual authentication schemes in order to trick the target into revealing the secret shared between it and another valid user. In a basic mutual-authentication scheme
column10005: a secret is known to both the valid user and the server; this allows them to authenticate. In order that they may verify this shared secret without sending it plainly over the wire
column10006: they utilize a Diffie-Hellman-style scheme in which they each pick a value
column10007: then request the hash of that value as keyed by the shared secret. In a reflection attack
column10008: the attacker claims to be a valid user and requests the hash of a random value from the server. When the server returns this value and requests its own value to be hashed
column10009: the attacker opens another connection to the server. This time
column10010: the hash requested by the attacker is the value which the server requested in the first connection. When the server returns this hashed value
column10011: it is used in the first connection
column10012: authenticating the attacker successfully as the impersonated valid user."

column10236: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA famous example of this type of weakness being exploited is the eBay attack. eBay always displays the user id of the highest bidder. In the final minutes of the auction
column10237: one of the bidders could try to log in as the highest bidder three times. After three incorrect log in attempts
column10238: eBay password throttling would kick in and lock out the highest bidder's account for some time. An attacker could then make their own bid and their victim would not have a chance to place the counter bid because they would be locked out. Thus an attacker could win the auction.\n"
column10239: name:"Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password"
column10241: description:"The product contains a mechanism for users to recover or change their passwords without knowing the original password
column10242: but the mechanism is weak. It is common for an application to have a mechanism that provides a means for a user to gain access to their account in the event they forget their password. Very often the password recovery mechanism is weak
column10243: which has the effect of making it more likely that it would be possible for a person other than the legitimate system user to gain access to that user's account. Weak password recovery schemes completely undermine a strong password authentication scheme. This weakness may be that the security question is too easy to guess or find an answer to (e.g. because the question is too common
column10244: or the answers can be found using social media). Or there might be an implementation weakness in the password recovery mechanism code that may for instance trick the system into e-mailing the new password to an e-mail account other than that of the user. There might be no throttling done on the rate of password resets so that a legitimate user can be denied service by an attacker if an attacker tries to recover their password in a rapid succession. The system may send the original password to the user rather than generating a new temporary password. In summary
column10246: if not carefully designed and implemented can often become the system's weakest link that can be misused in a way that would allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access to the system."
column10251: description:"The product uses a CAPTCHA challenge
column10252: but the challenge can be guessed or automatically recognized by a non-human actor. An automated attacker could bypass the intended protection of the CAPTCHA challenge and perform actions at a higher frequency than humanly possible
column10253: such as launching spam attacks. There can be several different causes of a guessable CAPTCHA: An audio or visual image that does not have sufficient distortion from the unobfuscated source image. A question is generated with a format that can be automatically recognized
column10254: such as a math question. A question for which the number of possible answers is limited
column10255: such as birth years or favorite sports teams. A general-knowledge or trivia question for which the answer can be accessed using a data base
column10256: such as country capitals or popular entertainers. Other data associated with the CAPTCHA may provide hints about its contents
column10257: such as an image whose filename contains the word that is used in the CAPTCHA."
column10260: name:"Use of Password Hash Instead of Password for Authentication"
column10262: Product performs authentication with user-supplied password hashes that can be obtained from a separate SQL injection vulnerability (CVE-2009-1282).
column10264: description:"The product records password hashes in a data store
column10265: receives a hash of a password from a client
column10266: and compares the supplied hash to the hash obtained from the data store. Some authentication mechanisms rely on the client to generate the hash for a password
column10267: possibly to reduce load on the server or avoid sending the password across the network. However
column10268: when the client is used to generate the hash
column10269: an attacker can bypass the authentication by obtaining a copy of the hash
column10270: e.g. by using SQL injection to compromise a database of authentication credentials
column10271: or by exploiting an information exposure. The attacker could then use a modified client to replay the stolen hash without having knowledge of the original password. As a result
column10272: the server-side comparison against a client-side hash does not provide any more security than the use of passwords without hashing."

column10315: name:"Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust"
column10326: the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate
column10327: resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate. If a system does not follow the chain of trust of a certificate to a root server
column10328: the certificate loses all usefulness as a metric of trust. Essentially
column10329: the trust gained from a certificate is derived from a chain of trust -- with a reputable trusted entity at the end of that list. The end user must trust that reputable source
column10330: and this reputable source must vouch for the resource in question through the medium of the certificate. In some cases
column10331: this trust traverses several entities who vouch for one another. The entity trusted by the end user is at one end of this trust chain
column10332: while the certificate-wielding resource is at the other end of the chain. If the user receives a certificate at the end of one of these trust chains and then proceeds to check only that the first link in the chain
column10333: no real trust has been derived
column10334: since the entire chain must be traversed back to a trusted source to verify the certificate. There are several ways in which the chain of trust might be broken
column10335: including but not limited to: Any certificate in the chain is self-signed
column10336: unless it the root. Not every intermediate certificate is checked
column10337: starting from the original certificate all the way up to the root certificate. An intermediate
column10338: CA-signed certificate does not have the expected Basic Constraints or other important extensions. The root certificate has been compromised or authorized to the wrong party."

column10624: description:"The product uses an IP address for authentication. IP addresses can be easily spoofed. Attackers can forge the source IP address of the packets they send
column10625: but response packets will return to the forged IP address. To see the response packets
column10626: the attacker has to sniff the traffic between the victim machine and the forged IP address. In order to accomplish the required sniffing
column10627: attackers typically attempt to locate themselves on the same subnet as the victim machine. Attackers may be able to circumvent this requirement by using source routing
column10628: but source routing is disabled across much of the Internet today. In summary
column10629: IP address verification can be a useful part of an authentication scheme
column10630: but it should not be the single factor required for authentication."

column10770: name:"Incorrectly Specified Destination in a Communication Channel"
column10774: description:"The product creates a communication channel to initiate an outgoing request to an actor
column10775: but it does not correctly specify the intended destination for that actor. Attackers at the destination may be able to spoof trusted servers to steal data or cause a denial of service. There are at least two distinct weaknesses that can cause the product to communicate with an unintended destination: If the product allows an attacker to control which destination is specified
column10776: then the attacker can cause it to connect to an untrusted or malicious destination. For example
column10777: because UDP is a connectionless protocol
column10778: UDP packets can be spoofed by specifying a false source address in the packet; when the server receives the packet and sends a reply
column10779: it will specify a destination by using the source of the incoming packet - i.e.
column10780: the false source. The server can then be tricked into sending traffic to the wrong host
column10781: which is effective for hiding the real source of an attack and for conducting a distributed denial of service (DDoS). As another example
column10782: server-side request forgery (SSRF) and XML External Entity (XXE) can be used to trick a server into making outgoing requests to hosts that cannot be directly accessed by the attacker due to firewall restrictions. If the product incorrectly specifies the destination
column10783: then an attacker who can control this destination might be able to spoof trusted servers. While the most common occurrence is likely due to misconfiguration by an administrator

column10995: name:"Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request\/Response Smuggling')"
column11002: description:"The product acts as an intermediary HTTP agent (such as a proxy or firewall) in the data flow between two entities such as a client and server
column11003: but it does not interpret malformed HTTP requests or responses in ways that are consistent with how the messages will be processed by those entities that are at the ultimate destination. HTTP requests or responses (\"messages\") can be malformed or unexpected in ways that cause web servers or clients to interpret the messages in different ways than intermediary HTTP agents such as load balancers
column11008: an adversary may be able to add duplicate or different header fields that a client or server might interpret as one set of messages
column11009: whereas the intermediary might interpret the same sequence of bytes as a different set of messages. For example
column11010: discrepancies can arise in how to handle duplicate headers like two Transfer-encoding (TE) or two Content-length (CL)
column11011: or the malicious HTTP message will have different headers for TE and CL. The inconsistent parsing and interpretation of messages can allow the adversary to \"smuggle\" a message to the client\/server without the intermediary being aware of it. This weakness is usually the result of the usage of outdated or incompatible HTTP protocol versions in the HTTP agents."

column11016: description:"The server contains a protection mechanism that assumes that any URI that is accessed using HTTP GET will not cause a state change to the associated resource. This might allow attackers to bypass intended access restrictions and conduct resource modification and deletion attacks
column11017: since some applications allow GET to modify state. The HTTP GET method and some other methods are designed to retrieve resources and not to alter the state of the application or resources on the server side. Furthermore
column11018: the HTTP specification requires that GET requests (and other requests) should not have side effects. Believing that it will be enough to prevent unintended resource alterations
column11019: an application may disallow the HTTP requests to perform DELETE
column11020: PUT and POST operations on the resource representation. However
column11021: there is nothing in the HTTP protocol itself that actually prevents the HTTP GET method from performing more than just query of the data. Developers can easily code programs that accept a HTTP GET request that do in fact create
column11022: update or delete data on the server. For instance
column11023: it is a common practice with REST based Web Services to have HTTP GET requests modifying resources on the server side. However
