column11254: description:"Covert timing channels convey information by modulating some aspect of system behavior over time
column11255: so that the program receiving the information can observe system behavior and infer protected information. In some instances
column11256: knowing when data is transmitted between parties can provide a malicious user with privileged information. Also
column11257: externally monitoring the timing of operations can potentially reveal sensitive data. For example
column11258: a cryptographic operation can expose its internal state if the time it takes to perform the operation varies
column11259: based on the state. Covert channels are frequently classified as either storage or timing channels. Some examples of covert timing channels are the system's paging rate
column11260: the time a certain transaction requires to execute
column11261: and the time it takes to gain access to a shared bus."
column11263: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nAn excellent example of covert storage channels in a well known application is the ICMP error message echoing functionality. Due to ambiguities in the ICMP RFC
column11264: many IP implementations use the memory within the packet for storage or calculation. For this reason
column11265: certain fields of certain packets -- such as ICMP error packets which echo back parts of received messages -- may contain flaws or extra information which betrays information about the identity of the target operating system. This information is then used to build up evidence to decide the environment of the target. This is the first crucial step in determining if a given system is vulnerable to a particular flaw and what changes must be made to malicious code to mount a successful attack.\n"
column11268: description:"A covert storage channel transfers information through the setting of bits by one program and the reading of those bits by another. What distinguishes this case from that of ordinary operation is that the bits are used to convey encoded information. Covert storage channels occur when out-of-band data is stored in messages for the purpose of memory reuse. Covert channels are frequently classified as either storage or timing channels. Examples would include using a file intended to hold only audit information to convey user passwords--using the name of a file or perhaps status bits associated with it that can be read by all users to signal the contents of the file. Steganography
column11269: concealing information in such a manner that no one but the intended recipient knows of the existence of the message
column11270: is a good example of a covert storage channel."
column11272: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nSuppose a processor's Memory Management Unit (MMU) has 5 other shadow MMUs to distribute its workload for its various cores. Each MMU has the start address and end address of \"accessible\" memory. Any time this accessible range changes (as per the processor's boot status)
column11273: the main MMU sends an update message to all the shadow MMUs.\nSuppose the interconnect fabric does not prioritize such \"update\" packets over other general traffic packets. This introduces a race condition. If an attacker can flood the target with enough messages so that some of those attack packets reach the target before the new access ranges gets updated
column11274: then the attacker can leverage this scenario.\n"
column11275: name:"Improper Preservation of Consistency Between Independent Representations of Shared State"
column11277: description:"The product has or supports multiple distributed components or sub-systems that are each required to keep their own local copy of shared data - such as state or cache - but the product does not ensure that all local copies remain consistent with each other. In highly distributed environments
column11278: or on systems with distinct physical components that operate independently
column11279: there is often a need for each component to store and update its own local copy of key data such as state or cache
column11280: so that all components have the same \"view\" of the overall system and operate in a coordinated fashion. For example
column11281: users of a social media service or a massively multiplayer online game might be using their own personal computers while also interacting with different physical hosts in a globally distributed service
column11282: but all participants must be able to have the same \"view\" of the world. Alternately
column11283: a processor's Memory Management Unit (MMU) might have \"shadow\" MMUs to distribute its workload
column11284: and all shadow MMUs are expected to have the same accessible ranges of memory. In such environments
column11285: it becomes critical for the product to ensure that this \"shared state\" is consistently modified across all distributed systems. If state is not consistently maintained across all systems
column11286: then critical transactions might take place out of order
column11287: or some users might not get the same data as other users. When this inconsistency affects correctness of operations
column11288: it can introduce vulnerabilities in mechanisms that depend on consistent state."
column11290: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nSuppose that an attacker successfully gains root privileges on a Linux system and adds a new 'user2' account:\nThis new user2 account would not be noticed on the web interface
column11291: if the interface does not refresh its data of available users.\nIt could be argued that for this specific example
column11292: an attacker with root privileges would be likely to compromise the admin tool or otherwise feed it with false data. However
column11293: this example shows how the discrepancy in critical data can help attackers to escape detection.\n"
column11294: name:"Application-Level Admin Tool with Inconsistent View of Underlying Operating System"
column11296: description:"The product provides an application for administrators to manage parts of the underlying operating system
column11297: but the application does not accurately identify all of the relevant entities or resources that exist in the OS; that is
column11298: the application's model of the OS's state is inconsistent with the OS's actual state. Many products provide web-based applications or other interfaces for managing the underlying operating system. This is common with cloud
column11301: and other systems. When the management tool does not accurately represent what is in the OS - such as user accounts - then the administrator might not see suspicious activities that would be noticed otherwise. For example
column11302: numerous systems utilize a web front-end for administrative control. They also offer the ability to add
column11304: and drop users with various privileges as it relates to the functionality of the system. A potential architectural weakness may exist where the user information reflected in the web interface does not mirror the users in the underlying operating system. Many web UI or REST APIs use the underlying operating system for authentication; the system's logic may also track an additional set of user capabilities within configuration files and datasets for authorization capabilities. When there is a discrepancy between the user information in the UI or REST API's interface system and the underlying operating system's user listing
column11305: this may introduce a weakness into the system. For example
column11306: if an attacker compromises the OS and adds a new user account - a \"ghost\" account - then the attacker could escape detection if the management tool does not list the newly-added account. This discrepancy could be exploited in several ways: A rogue admin could insert a new account into a system that will persist if they are terminated or wish to take action on a system that cannot be directly associated with them. An attacker can leverage a separate command injection attack available through the web interface to insert a ghost account with shell privileges such as ssh. An attacker can leverage existing web interface APIs
column11307: manipulated in such a way that a new user is inserted into the operating system
column11308: and the user web account is either partially created or not at all. An attacker could create an admin account which is viewable by an administrator
column11309: use this account to create the ghost account
column11310: delete logs and delete the first created admin account. Many of these attacker scenarios can be realized by leveraging separate vulnerabilities related to XSS
column11313: or logic flaws on the various systems."

column11319: name:"Reliance on Component That is Not Updateable"
column11321: description:"The product contains a component that cannot be updated or patched in order to remove vulnerabilities or significant bugs. If the component is discovered to contain a vulnerability or critical bug
column11322: but the issue cannot be fixed using an update or patch
column11323: then the product's owner will not be able to protect against the issue. The only option might be replacement of the product
column11324: which could be too financially or operationally expensive for the product owner. As a result
column11325: the inability to patch or update can leave the product open to attacker exploitation or critical operation failures. This weakness can be especially difficult to manage when using ROM
column11327: or similar components that traditionally have had limited or no update capabilities. In industries such as healthcare
column11328: \"legacy\" devices can be operated for decades. As a US task force report [REF-1197] notes
column11329: \"the inability to update or replace equipment has both large and small health care delivery organizations struggle with numerous unsupported legacy systems that cannot easily be replaced (hardware
column11331: and operating systems) with large numbers of vulnerabilities and few modern countermeasures.\" While hardware can be prone to this weakness
column11332: software systems can also be affected
column11333: such as when a third-party driver or library is no longer actively maintained or supported but is still critical for the required functionality."

column11339: description:"The product does not provide its users with the ability to update or patch its firmware to address any vulnerabilities or weaknesses that may be present. Without the ability to patch or update firmware

column11348: name:"Missing Ability to Patch ROM Code"
column11350: description:"Missing an ability to patch ROM code may leave a System or System-on-Chip (SoC) in a vulnerable state. A System or System-on-Chip (SoC) that implements a boot process utilizing security mechanisms such as Root-of-Trust (RoT) typically starts by executing code from a Read-only-Memory (ROM) component. The code in ROM is immutable
column11351: hence any security vulnerabilities discovered in the ROM code can never be fixed for the systems that are already in use. A common weakness is that the ROM does not have the ability to patch if security vulnerabilities are uncovered after the system gets shipped. This leaves the system in a vulnerable state where an adversary can compromise the SoC."

This makes it easier for attackers to trick users into inflicting damage to their system. Product systems should warn users that a potentially dangerous action may occur if the user proceeds. For example

column11422: then the application's GUI can indicate that the file is unsafe."
column11424: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code excerpt handles three types of exceptions in an identical fashion.\nAt first blush

column11432: name:"Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception"
column11434: description:"Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities. Multiple catch blocks can get ugly and repetitive
column11435: but \"condensing\" catch blocks by catching a high-level class like Exception can obscure exceptions that deserve special treatment or that should not be caught at this point in the program. Catching an overly broad exception essentially defeats the purpose of Java's typed exceptions
column11436: and can become particularly dangerous if the program grows and begins to throw new types of exceptions. The new exception types will not receive any attention."

doing so hampers the caller's ability to understand and handle the exceptions that occur. Further

column11440: there is no easy way to enforce this requirement.\nExample 2\nEarly versions of C++ (C++98
column11442: C++11) included a feature known as Dynamic Exception Specification. This allowed functions to declare what type of exceptions it may throw. It is possible to declare a general class of exception to cover any derived exceptions that may be throw.\nIn the example above
column11443: the code declares that myfunction() can throw an exception of type \"std::exception\" thus hiding details about the possible derived exceptions that could potentially be thrown.\n"
column11444: name:"Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception"
column11446: description:"Throwing overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities. Declaring a method to throw Exception or Throwable makes it difficult for callers to perform proper error handling and error recovery. Java's exception mechanism
column11448: is set up to make it easy for callers to anticipate what can go wrong and write code to handle each specific exceptional circumstance. Declaring that a method throws a generic form of exception defeats this system."
column11451: name:"User Interface (UI) Misrepresentation of Critical Information"
column11478: description:"The user interface (UI) does not properly represent critical information to the user
column11479: allowing the information - or its source - to be obscured or spoofed. This is often a component in phishing attacks. If an attacker can cause the UI to display erroneous data
column11480: or to otherwise convince the user to display information that appears to come from a trusted source
column11481: then the attacker could trick the user into performing the wrong action. This is often a component in phishing attacks
column11482: but other kinds of problems exist. For example
column11483: if the UI is used to monitor the security state of a system or network
column11484: then omitting or obscuring an important indicator could prevent the user from detecting and reacting to a security-critical event. UI misrepresentation can take many forms: Incorrect indicator: incorrect information is displayed
column11485: which prevents the user from understanding the true state of the product or the environment the product is monitoring
column11486: especially of potentially-dangerous conditions or operations. This can be broken down into several different subtypes. Overlay: an area of the display is intended to give critical information
column11487: but another process can modify the display by overlaying another element on top of it. The user is not interacting with the expected portion of the user interface. This is the problem that enables clickjacking attacks
column11488: although many other types of attacks exist that involve overlay. Icon manipulation: the wrong icon
column11490: can be influenced (such as making a dangerous .EXE executable look like a harmless .GIF) Timing: the product is performing a state transition or context switch that is presented to the user with an indicator
column11491: but a race condition can cause the wrong indicator to be used before the product has fully switched context. The race window could be extended indefinitely if the attacker can trigger an error. Visual truncation: important information could be truncated from the display
column11492: such as a long filename with a dangerous extension that is not displayed in the GUI because the malicious portion is truncated. The use of excessive whitespace can also cause truncation
column11493: or place the potentially-dangerous indicator outside of the user's field of view (e.g. \"filename.txt .exe\"). A different type of truncation can occur when a portion of the information is removed due to reasons other than length
column11494: such as the accidental insertion of an end-of-input marker in the middle of an input
column11495: such as a NUL byte in a C-style string. Visual distinction: visual information might be presented in a way that makes it difficult for the user to quickly and correctly distinguish between critical and unimportant segments of the display. Homographs: letters from different character sets
column11497: or languages can appear very similar (i.e. may be visually equivalent) in a way that causes the human user to misread the text (for example
column11498: to conduct phishing attacks to trick a user into visiting a malicious web site with a visually-similar name as a trusted site). This can be regarded as a type of visual distinction issue."

The \"e\" is actually the \"CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER IE\" which is represented in HTML as the character &#x435

Example 2
The following displays an example of how creating usernames containing homoglyphs can lead to log forgery.
Assume an adversary visits a legitimate

This makes it more difficult to determine which actions were performed by the adversary and which actions were executed by the legitimate \"admin\" account.\n"
column11509: name:"Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User"
column11517: description:"The product displays information or identifiers to a user
column11518: but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs)
column11519: which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended
column11522: or icons can be semantically distinct to a program
column11523: while appearing very similar or identical to a human user. These are referred to as homoglyphs. For example
column11524: the lowercase \"l\" (ell) and uppercase \"I\" (eye) have different character codes
column11525: but these characters can be displayed in exactly the same way to a user
column11526: depending on the font. This can also occur between different character sets. For example
column11527: the Latin capital letter \"A\" and the Greek capital letter \"\" (Alpha) are treated as distinct by programs
column11528: but may be displayed in exactly the same way to a user. Accent marks may also cause letters to appear very similar
column11529: such as the Latin capital letter grave mark \"?\" and its equivalent \"?\" with the acute accent. Adversaries can exploit this visual similarity for attacks such as phishing
column11530: e.g. by providing a link to an attacker-controlled hostname that looks like a hostname that the victim trusts. In a different use of homoglyphs
column11531: an adversary may create a back door username that is visually similar to the username of a regular user
column11532: which then makes it more difficult for a system administrator to detect the malicious username while reviewing logs."

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
The following example demonstrates the weakness.
There are no limits to runnables. Potentially an attacker could cause resource problems very quickly.
Example 2
This code allocates a socket and forks each time it receives a new connection.
The program does not track how many connections have been made
column11542: and it does not limit the number of connections. Because forking is a relatively expensive operation
column11543: an attacker would be able to cause the system to run out of CPU
column11545: or memory by making a large number of connections. Alternatively
column11546: an attacker could consume all available connections
column11547: preventing others from accessing the system remotely.\nExample 3\nIn the following example a server socket connection is used to accept a request to store data on the local file system using a specified filename. The method openSocketConnection establishes a server socket to accept requests from a client. When a client establishes a connection to this service the getNextMessage method is first used to retrieve from the socket the name of the file to store the data
column11548:
the openFileToWrite method will validate the filename and open a file to write to on the local file system. The getNextMessage is then used within a while loop to continuously read data from the socket and output the data to the file until there is no longer any data from the socket.
This example creates a situation where data can be dumped to a file on the local file system without any limits on the size of the file. This could potentially exhaust file or disk resources and/or limit other clients' ability to access the service.
Example 4
In the following example
column11549: the processMessage method receives a two dimensional character array containing the message to be processed. The two-dimensional character array contains the length of the message in the first character array and the message body in the second character array. The getMessageLength method retrieves the integer value of the length from the first character array. After validating that the message length is greater than zero
column11550: the body character array pointer points to the start of the second character array of the two-dimensional character array and memory is allocated for the new body character array.\nThis example creates a situation where the length of the body character array can be very large and will consume excessive memory
column11551: exhausting system resources. This can be avoided by restricting the length of the second character array with a maximum length check\nAlso
column11552: consider changing the type from 'int' to 'unsigned int'
column11553: so that you are always guaranteed that the number is positive. This might not be possible if the protocol specifically requires allowing negative values
column11554: or if you cannot control the return value from getMessageLength()
column11555: but it could simplify the check to ensure the input is positive
column11556: and eliminate other errors such as signed-to-unsigned conversion errors (CWE-195) that may occur elsewhere in the code.\nExample 5\nIn the following example
column11557:
a server object creates a server socket and accepts client connections to the socket. For every client connection to the socket a separate thread object is generated using the ClientSocketThread class that handles request made by the client through the socket.
In this example there is no limit to the number of client connections and client threads that are created. Allowing an unlimited number of client connections and threads could potentially overwhelm the system and system resources.
The server should limit the number of client connections and the client threads that are created. This can be easily done by creating a thread pool object that limits the number of threads that are generated.
"
column11576: description:"The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource
column11577: thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed
column11578: eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources. Limited resources include memory
column11581: and CPU. If an attacker can trigger the allocation of these limited resources
column11582: but the number or size of the resources is not controlled
column11583: then the attacker could cause a denial of service that consumes all available resources. This would prevent valid users from accessing the product
column11584: and it could potentially have an impact on the surrounding environment. For example
column11585: a memory exhaustion attack against an application could slow down the application as well as its host operating system. There are at least three distinct scenarios which can commonly lead to resource exhaustion: Lack of throttling for the number of allocated resources Losing all references to a resource before reaching the shutdown stage Not closing\/returning a resource after processing Resource exhaustion problems are often result due to an incorrect implementation of the following situations: Error conditions and other exceptional circumstances. Confusion over which part of the program is responsible for releasing the resource."
column11587: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nJava has a boxed primitive for each primitive type. A long can be represented with the boxed primitive Long. Issues arise where boxed primitives are used when not strictly necessary.\nIn the above loop
column11588: we see that the count variable is declared as a boxed primitive. This causes autoboxing on the line that increments. This causes execution to be magnitudes less performant (time and possibly space) than if the \"long\" primitive was used to declare the count variable
column11589:
which can impact availability of a resource.
Example 2
This code uses primitive long which fixes the issue.
"
column11590: name:"Incorrect Use of Autoboxing and Unboxing for Performance Critical Operations"
column11593: which may introduce inefficiencies into performance-critical operations. Languages such as Java and C# support automatic conversion through their respective compilers from primitive types into objects of the corresponding wrapper classes
column11595: a compiler might convert an int to Integer (called autoboxing) or an Integer to int (called unboxing). This eliminates forcing the programmer to perform these conversions manually
column11596: which makes the code cleaner. However
column11597: this feature comes at a cost of performance and can lead to resource exhaustion and impact availability when used with generic collections. Therefore
column11598: they should not be used for scientific computing or other performance critical operations. They are only suited to support \"impedance mismatch\" between reference types and primitives."

An attacker can render a memory line unusable by repeatedly causing a write to the memory line.
Below is example code from [REF-1058] that the user can execute repeatedly to cause line failure. W is the maximum associativity of any cache in the system; S is the size of the largest cache in the system.
Without wear leveling
column11601: the above attack will be successful. Simple randomization of blocks will not suffice as instead of the original physical block
column11602: the randomized physical block will be worn out.\n"
column11603: name:"Improper Write Handling in Limited-write Non-Volatile Memories"
column11605: description:"The product does not implement or incorrectly implements wear leveling operations in limited-write non-volatile memories. Non-volatile memories such as NAND Flash
column11608: each of which can be put through a limited number of program\/erase or write cycles. For example
column11609: the device can only endure a limited number of writes
column11610: after which the device becomes unreliable. In order to wear out the cells in a uniform manner
column11611: non-volatile memory and storage products based on the above-mentioned technologies implement a technique called wear leveling. Once a set threshold is reached
column11612: wear leveling maps writes of a logical block to a different physical block. This prevents a single physical block from prematurely failing due to a high concentration of writes. If wear leveling is improperly implemented
column11613: attackers may be able to programmatically cause the storage to become unreliable within a much shorter time than would normally be expected."

column11646: description:"The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated

column11854: name:"Sensitive Information in Resource Not Removed Before Reuse"
column11862: description:"The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse
column11863: but it does not clear or \"zeroize\" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities. When resources are released
column11864: they can be made available for reuse. For example
column11866: an operating system may make the memory available to another process
column11867: or disk space may be reallocated when a file is deleted. As removing information requires time and additional resources
column11868: operating systems do not usually clear the previously written information. Even when the resource is reused by the same process
column11869: this weakness can arise when new data is not as large as the old data
column11870: which leaves portions of the old data still available. Equivalent errors can occur in other situations where the length of data is variable but the associated data structure is not. If memory is not cleared after use
column11871: the information may be read by less trustworthy parties when the memory is reallocated. This weakness can apply in hardware
column11872: such as when a device or system switches between power
column11874: or debug states during normal operation
column11875: or when execution changes to different users or privilege levels."
column11877: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nSuppose a hardware IP for implementing an encryption routine works as expected
column11878: but it leaves the intermediate results in some registers that can be accessed. Exactly why this access happens is immaterial - it might be unintentional or intentional
column11879: where the designer wanted a \"quick fix\" for something.\n"
column11882: description:"The hardware product does not properly clear sensitive information from built-in registers when the user of the hardware block changes. Hardware logic operates on data stored in registers local to the hardware block. Most hardware IPs
column11884: rely on registers to buffer I\/O
column11886: and interface with software. The result of this is that sensitive information
column11887: such as passwords or encryption keys
column11888: can exist in locations not transparent to the user of the hardware logic. When a different entity obtains access to the IP due to a change in operating mode or conditions
column11889: the new entity can extract information belonging to the previous user if no mechanisms are in place to clear register contents. It is important to clear information stored in the hardware if a physical attack on the product is detected
column11890: or if the user of the hardware block changes. The process of clearing register contents in a hardware IP is referred to as zeroization in standards for cryptographic hardware modules such as FIPS-140-2 [REF-267]."
column11893: name:"Insufficient or Incomplete Data Removal within Hardware Component"
column11895: description:"The product's data removal process does not completely delete all data and potentially sensitive information within hardware components. Physical properties of hardware devices
column11896: such as remanence of magnetic media
column11898: or screen burn-in may still retain sensitive data after a data removal process has taken place and power is removed. Recovering data after erasure or overwriting is possible due to a phenomenon called data remanence. For example
column11899: if the same value is written repeatedly to a memory location
column11900: the corresponding memory cells can become physically altered to a degree such that even after the original data is erased that data can still be recovered through physical characterization of the memory cells."
column11902: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a device that uses flash memory for non-volatile-data storage. To optimize flash-access performance or reliable-flash lifetime
column11903: the device might limit the number of flash writes\/erases by maintaining some state in internal SRAM and only committing changes to flash memory periodically.\nThe device also supports user reset to factory defaults with the expectation that all personal information is erased from the device after this operation. On factory reset
column11904: user files are erased using explicit
column11905: erase commands supported by the flash device.\nIn the given
column11907: the flash-file system can support performance-optimized erase such that only the file metadata are erased and not the content. If this optimized erase is used for files containing user data during factory-reset flow
column11909: flash memory can contain remanent data from these files.\nOn device-factory reset
column11910: the implementation might not erase these copies
column11911: since the file organization has changed and the flash file system does not have the metadata to track all previous copies.\nA flash-memory region that is used by a flash-file system should be fully erased as part of the factory-reset flow. This should include secure-erase flow for the flash media such as overwriting patterns multiple times followed by erase.\n"
column11912: name:"Remanent Data Readable after Memory Erase"
column11914: description:"Confidential information stored in memory circuits is readable or recoverable after being cleared or erased. Data remanence occurs when stored
column11915: memory content is not fully lost after a memory-clear or -erase operation. Confidential memory contents can still be readable through data remanence in the hardware. Data remanence can occur because of performance optimization or memory organization during 'clear' or 'erase' operations
column11916: like a design that allows the memory-organization metadata (e.g.
column11917: file pointers) to be erased without erasing the actual memory content. To protect against this weakness
column11918: memory devices will often support different commands for optimized memory erase and explicit secure erase. Data remanence can also happen because of the physical properties of memory circuits in use. For example
column11921: random-access-memory (DRAM) data retention is based on the charge retained in the memory cell
column11922: which depends on factors such as power supply
column11924: and temperature. Other than explicit erase commands
column11926: secure-memory devices can also support secure erase through cryptographic erase commands. In such designs
column11927: only the decryption keys for encrypted data stored on the device are erased. That is
column11928: the stored data are always remnant in the media after a cryptographic erase. However
column11929: only the encrypted data can be extracted. Thus
column11930: protection against data recovery in such designs relies on the strength of the encryption algorithm."

column12070: rather than on the client side. In the case of cryptographic protocols where the resource-intensive part should happen on the client-side first (such as SSH)
column12071: a malicious client can send a forged\/precalculated computation result
column12072: which seems correct to the server
column12073: so the resource-intensive part of the handshake is going to happen on the server side. A malicious client is required to send only the initial messages of a cryptographic handshake to initiate the resource-consuming part of the cryptographic handshake. These messages are usually small
column12074: and generating them requires minimal computational effort

column12086: description:"The product does not properly control situations in which an adversary can cause the product to consume or produce excessive resources without requiring the adversary to invest equivalent work or otherwise prove authorization
column12088: the adversary's influence is \"asymmetric.\" This can lead to poor performance due to \"amplification\" of resource consumption
column12089: typically in a non-linear fashion. This situation is worsened if the product allows malicious users or attackers to consume more resources than their access level permits."
column12092: name:"Excessive Platform Resource Consumption within a Loop"
column12094: description:"The product has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or indirectly consumes platform resources
column12098: or file descriptors. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If an attacker can influence the number of iterations in the loop
column12099: then this performance problem might allow a denial of service by consuming more platform resources than intended."
column12102: name:"Data Resource Access without Use of Connection Pooling"
column12104: description:"The product accesses a data resource through a database without using a connection pooling capability. This issue can make the product perform more slowly
column12105: as connection pools allow connections to be reused without the overhead and time consumption of opening and closing a new connection. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column12106: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability."
column12109: name:"Non-SQL Invokable Control Element with Excessive Number of Data Resource Accesses"
column12111: description:"The product contains a client with a function or method that contains a large number of data accesses\/queries that are sent through a data manager
column12113: does not use efficient database capabilities. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column12114: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"large number of data accesses\/queries\" may vary for each product or developer
column12115: CISQ recommends a default maximum of 2 data accesses per function\/method."
column12118: name:"Invokable Control Element with Excessive File or Data Access Operations"
column12120: description:"A function or method contains too many operations that utilize a data manager or file resource. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column12121: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. While the interpretation of \"too many operations\" may vary for each product or developer
column12122: CISQ recommends a default maximum of 7 operations for the same data manager or file."
column12125: name:"Large Data Table with Excessive Number of Indices"
column12127: description:"The product uses a large data table that contains an excessively large number of indices. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column12128: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"large data table\" and \"excessively large number of indices\" may vary for each product or developer
column12129: CISQ recommends a default threshold of 1000000 rows for a \"large\" table and a default threshold of 3 indices."
column12132: name:"Excessive Index Range Scan for a Data Resource"
column12134: description:"The product contains an index range scan for a large data table
column12135: but the scan can cover a large number of rows. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column12136: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of \"large data table\" and \"excessive index range\" may vary for each product or developer
column12137: CISQ recommends a threshold of 1000000 table rows and a threshold of 10 for the index range."

column12195: description:"The product does not sufficiently monitor or control transmitted network traffic volume

column12233: description:"The product uses a regular expression with an inefficient
column12234: possibly exponential worst-case computational complexity that consumes excessive CPU cycles. Some regular expression engines have a feature called \"backtracking\". If the token cannot match
column12235: the engine \"backtracks\" to a position that may result in a different token that can match. Backtracking becomes a weakness if all of these conditions are met: The number of possible backtracking attempts are exponential relative to the length of the input. The input can fail to match the regular expression. The input can be long enough. Attackers can create crafted inputs that intentionally cause the regular expression to use excessive backtracking in a way that causes the CPU consumption to spike."

column12360: description:"The product mixes trusted and untrusted data in the same data structure or structured message. A trust boundary can be thought of as line drawn through a program. On one side of the line
column12361: data is untrusted. On the other side of the line
column12362: data is assumed to be trustworthy. The purpose of validation logic is to allow data to safely cross the trust boundary - to move from untrusted to trusted. column12377: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following example shows a snippet of code from a J2EE web application where the application authenticates users with LoginContext.login() without first calling HttpSession.invalidate().\nIn order to exploit the code above

column12387: the ability to keep the compromised session active and a victim interested in logging into the vulnerable application on the public terminal.\nIn most circumstances
column12388: the first two challenges are surmountable given a sufficient investment of time. Finding a victim who is both using a public terminal and interested in logging into the vulnerable application is possible as well
column12389: so long as the site is reasonably popular. The less well known the site is
column12390: the lower the odds of an interested victim using the public terminal and the lower the chance of success for the attack vector described above. The biggest challenge an attacker faces in exploiting session fixation vulnerabilities is inducing victims to authenticate against the vulnerable application using a session identifier known to the attacker.\nIn the example above
column12391: the attacker did this through a direct method that is not subtle and does not scale suitably for attacks involving less well-known web sites. However

column12533: description:"Executing commands or loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands (and payloads) on behalf of an attacker. Process control vulnerabilities take two forms: An attacker can change the command that the program executes: the attacker explicitly controls what the command is. An attacker can change the environment in which the command executes: the attacker implicitly controls what the command means. Process control vulnerabilities of the first type occur when either data enters the application from an untrusted source and the data is used as part of a string representing a command that is executed by the application. By executing the command
column12534: the application gives an attacker a privilege or capability that the attacker would not otherwise have."

column12609: description:"The product does not properly acquire or release a lock on a resource
column12610: leading to unexpected resource state changes and behaviors. Locking is a type of synchronization behavior that ensures that multiple independently-operating processes or threads do not interfere with each other when accessing the same resource. All processes\/threads are expected to follow the same steps for locking. If these steps are not followed precisely - or if no locking is done at all - then another process\/thread could modify the shared resource in a way that is not visible or predictable to the original process. This can lead to data or memory corruption

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1

Consider the memory configuration settings of a system that uses DDR3 DRAM memory. Protecting the DRAM memory configuration from modification by software is required to ensure that system memory access control protections cannot be bypassed. This can be done by using lock bit protection that locks all of the memory configuration registers. The memory configuration lock can be set by the BIOS during the boot process.
If such a system also supports a rapid power on mode like hibernate
column12615: the DRAM data must be saved to a disk before power is removed and restored back to the DRAM once the system powers back up and before the OS resumes operation after returning from hibernate.\n\nTo support the hibernate transition back to the operating state
column12616: the DRAM memory configuration must be reprogrammed even though it was locked previously. As the hibernate resume does a partial reboot
column12617: the memory configuration could be altered before the memory lock is set. Functionally the hibernate resume flow requires a bypass of the lock-based protection. The memory configuration must be securely stored and restored by trusted system firmware. Lock settings and system configuration must be restored to the same state it was in before the device entered into the hibernate mode.\n"
column12618: name:"Improper Lock Behavior After Power State Transition"
column12620: description:"Register lock bit protection disables changes to system configuration once the bit is set. Some of the protected registers or lock bits become programmable after power state transitions (e.g.
column12621: Entry and wake from low power sleep modes) causing the system configuration to be changeable. Devices may allow device configuration controls which need to be programmed after device power reset via a trusted firmware or software module (commonly set by BIOS\/bootloader) and then locked from any further modification. This action is commonly implemented using a programmable lock bit
column12624: disables writes to a protected set of registers or address regions. After a power state transition
column12625: the lock bit is set to unlocked. Some common weaknesses that can exist in such a protection scheme are that the lock gets cleared
column12626: the values of the protected registers get reset

column12708: the VirtualLock() function is only a stub and provides no protection. On POSIX systems the mlock() call ensures that a page will stay resident in memory but does not guarantee that the page will not appear in the swap. Therefore

column12848: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThere are several standard on-chip bus protocols used in modern SoCs to allow communication between components. There are a wide variety of commercially available hardware IP implementing the interconnect logic for these protocols. A bus connects components which initiate\/request communications such as processors and DMA controllers (bus masters) with peripherals which respond to requests. In a typical system
column12849: the privilege level or security designation of the bus master along with the intended functionality of each peripheral determine the security policy specifying which specific bus masters can access specific peripherals. This security policy (commonly referred to as a bus firewall) can be enforced using separate IP\/logic from the actual interconnect responsible for the data routing.\n"
column12850: name:"Hardware Logic with Insecure De-Synchronization between Control and Data Channels"
column12852: description:"The hardware logic for error handling and security checks can incorrectly forward data before the security check is complete. Many high-performance on-chip bus protocols and processor data-paths employ separate channels for control and data to increase parallelism and maximize throughput. Bugs in the hardware logic that handle errors and security checks can make it possible for data to be forwarded before the completion of the security checks. If the data can propagate to a location in the hardware observable to an attacker
column12853: loss of data confidentiality can occur. 'Meltdown' is a concrete example of how de-synchronization between data and permissions checking logic can violate confidentiality requirements. Data loaded from a page marked as privileged was returned to the cpu regardless of current privilege level for performance reasons. The assumption was that the cpu could later remove all traces of this data during the handling of the illegal memory access exception
column12854: but this assumption was proven false as traces of the secret data were not removed from the microarchitectural state."

column12977: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis code allocates a socket and forks each time it receives a new connection.\nThe program does not track how many connections have been made

column12982: an attacker could consume all available connections
column12983: preventing others from accessing the system remotely.\nExample 2\nIn the following example a server socket connection is used to accept a request to store data on the local file system using a specified filename. column12984:
the openFileToWrite method will validate the filename and open a file to write to on the local file system. The getNextMessage is then used within a while loop to continuously read data from the socket and output the data to the file until there is no longer any data from the socket.
This example creates a situation where data can be dumped to a file on the local file system without any limits on the size of the file. This could potentially exhaust file or disk resources and/or limit other clients' ability to access the service.
Example 3
In the following example
column12985: the processMessage method receives a two dimensional character array containing the message to be processed. The two-dimensional character array contains the length of the message in the first character array and the message body in the second character array. The getMessageLength method retrieves the integer value of the length from the first character array. After validating that the message length is greater than zero
column12986: the body character array pointer points to the start of the second character array of the two-dimensional character array and memory is allocated for the new body character array.\nThis example creates a situation where the length of the body character array can be very large and will consume excessive memory
column12987: exhausting system resources. This can be avoided by restricting the length of the second character array with a maximum length check\nAlso
column12988: consider changing the type from 'int' to 'unsigned int'
column12989: so that you are always guaranteed that the number is positive. This might not be possible if the protocol specifically requires allowing negative values
column12990: or if you cannot control the return value from getMessageLength()
column12991: but it could simplify the check to ensure the input is positive
column12992: and eliminate other errors such as signed-to-unsigned conversion errors (CWE-195) that may occur elsewhere in the code.\nExample 4\nIn the following example
column12993:
a server object creates a server socket and accepts client connections to the socket. For every client connection to the socket a separate thread object is generated using the ClientSocketThread class that handles request made by the client through the socket.
In this example there is no limit to the number of client connections and client threads that are created. Allowing an unlimited number of client connections and threads could potentially overwhelm the system and system resources.
The server should limit the number of client connections and the client threads that are created. This can be easily done by creating a thread pool object that limits the number of threads that are generated.

column13008: description:"The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated
column13009: in violation of the intended security policy for that actor. Code frequently has to work with limited resources
column13010: so programmers must be careful to ensure that resources are not consumed too quickly
column13011: or too easily. Without use of quotas
column13014: it can be easy for an attacker to consume many resources by rapidly making many requests
column13015: or causing larger resources to be used than is needed. When too many resources are allocated
column13016: or if a single resource is too large
column13017: then it can prevent the code from working correctly
column13018: possibly leading to a denial of service."

column13226: name:"Operation on Resource in Wrong Phase of Lifetime"
column13228: description:"The product performs an operation on a resource at the wrong phase of the resource's lifecycle
column13229: which can lead to unexpected behaviors. A resource's lifecycle includes several phases: initialization
column13232: it is important to follow the specifications outlined for how to operate on the resource and to ensure that the resource is in the expected phase. Otherwise
column13233: if a resource is in one phase but the operation is not valid for that phase (i.e.
column13234: an incorrect phase of the resource's lifetime)
column13235: then this can produce resultant weaknesses. For example
column13236: using a resource before it has been fully initialized could cause corruption or incorrect data to be used."

column13254: and steal its UDP packets\/TCP connection."

column13324: name:"Premature Release of Resource During Expected Lifetime"
column13326: description:"The product releases a resource that is still intended to be used by itself or another actor. This weakness focuses on errors in which the product should not release a resource
column13327: but performs the release anyway. This is different than a weakness in which the product releases a resource at the appropriate time
column13328: but it maintains a reference to the resource
column13329: which it later accesses. For this weakness
column13330: the resource should still be valid upon the subsequent access. When a product releases a resource that is still being used
column13331: it is possible that operations will still be taken on this resource
column13332: which may have been repurposed in the meantime
column13333: leading to issues similar to CWE-825. Consequences may include denial of service
column13338: name:"Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere"
column13340: description:"The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere
column13341: providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource. Resources such as files and directories may be inadvertently exposed through mechanisms such as insecure permissions
column13342: or when a program accidentally operates on the wrong object. For example
column13343: a program may intend that private files can only be provided to a specific user. This effectively defines a control sphere that is intended to prevent attackers from accessing these private files. If the file permissions are insecure
column13344: then parties other than the user will be able to access those files. A separate control sphere might effectively require that the user can only access the private files
column13345: but not any other files on the system. If the program does not ensure that the user is only requesting private files
column13346: then the user might be able to access other files on the system. In either case
column13347: the end result is that a resource has been exposed to the wrong party."
column13349: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider the following SoC design. The Hardware Root of Trust (HRoT) local SRAM is memory mapped in the core{0-N} address space. The HRoT allows or disallows access to private memory ranges
column13350: thus allowing the sram to function as a mailbox for communication between untrusted and trusted HRoT partitions.\n\nWe assume that the threat is from malicious software in the untrusted domain. We assume this software has access to the core{0-N} memory map and can be running at any privilege level on the untrusted cores. The capability of this threat in this example is communication to and from the mailbox region of SRAM modulated by the hrot_iface. To address this threat
column13351: information must not enter or exit the shared region of SRAM through hrot_iface when in secure or privileged mode.\n\n"
column13352: name:"Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-a-Chip (SoC)"
column13354: description:"The System-On-a-Chip (SoC) does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents. A System-On-a-Chip (SoC) has a lot of functionality
column13355: but it may have a limited number of pins or pads. A pin can only perform one function at a time. However
column13356: it can be configured to perform multiple different functions. This technique is called pin multiplexing. Similarly
column13357: several resources on the chip may be shared to multiplex and support different features or functions. When such resources are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column13358: untrusted agents may be able to access the assets intended to be accessed only by the trusted agents."
column13360: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nOn some processors the hardware indirect branch predictor is shared between execution contexts
column13362: between sibling SMT threads. When SMT thread A executes an indirect branch to a target address X
column13363: this target may be temporarily stored by the indirect branch predictor. A subsequent indirect branch mis-prediction for SMT thread B could speculatively execute instructions at X (or at a location in B's address space that partially aliases X). Even though the processor rolls back the architectural effects of the mis-predicted indirect branch
column13364: the memory accesses alter data cache state
column13365: which is not rolled back after the indirect branch is resolved.\n"
column13368: description:"Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g.
column13369: caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts. Modern processors use techniques such as out-of-order execution
column13373: and caching to increase performance. Details about the implementation of these techniques are hidden from the programmer's view. This is problematic when the hardware implementation of these techniques results in resources being shared across supposedly isolated contexts. Contention for shared resources between different contexts opens covert channels that allow malicious programs executing in one context to recover information from another context. Some examples of shared micro-architectural resources that have been used to leak information between contexts are caches
column13375: and load or store buffers. Speculative and out-of-order execution provides an attacker with increased control over which data is leaked through the covert channel. If the extent of resource sharing between contexts in the design microarchitecture is undocumented
column13376: it is extremely difficult to ensure system assets are protected against disclosure."
column13378: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nCryptographic hash functions are commonly used to create unique fixed-length digests used to ensure the integrity of code and keys. A golden digest is stored on the device and compared to the digest computed from the data to be verified. If the digests match
column13379: the data has not been maliciously modified. If an attacker can modify the golden digest they then have the ability to store arbitrary data that passes the verification check. Hash digests used to verify public keys and early stage boot code should be immutable
column13380: with the strongest protection offered by hardware immutability.\n"
column13381: name:"Assumed-Immutable Data is Stored in Writable Memory"
column13386: and \"write-once\" configuration settings are stored in writable memory that can be re-programmed or updated in the field. Security services such as secure boot
column13388: and device attestation all require assets such as the first stage bootloader
column13391: etc. which are implicitly trusted. Storing these assets in read-only memory (ROM)
column13393: or one-time programmable (OTP) memory provides strong integrity guarantees and provides a root of trust for securing the rest of the system. Security is lost if assets assumed to be immutable can be modified."
column13395: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a NoC that implements a one-dimensional mesh network with four nodes. This supports two flows: Flow A from node 0 to node 3 (via node 1 and node 2) and Flow B from node 1 to node 2. Flows A and B share a common link between Node 1 and Node 2. Only one flow can use the link in each cycle.\nOne of the masters to this NoC implements a cryptographic algorithm (RSA)
column13396: and another master to the NoC is a core that can be exercised by an attacker. The RSA algorithm performs a modulo multiplication of two large numbers and depends on each bit of the secret key. The algorithm examines each bit in the secret key and only performs multiplication if the bit is 1. This algorithm is known to be prone to timing attacks. Whenever RSA performs multiplication
column13397: there is additional network traffic to the memory controller. One of the reasons for this is cache conflicts.\nSince this is a one-dimensional mesh
column13398: only one flow can use the link in each cycle. Also
column13399: packets from the attack program and the RSA program share the output port of the network-on-chip. This contention results in network interference
column13400: and the throughput and latency of one flow can be affected by the other flow's demand.\nThere may be different ways to fix this particular weakness.\n"
column13401: name:"Improper Isolation of Shared Resources in Network On Chip (NoC)"
column13403: description:"The Network On Chip (NoC) does not isolate or incorrectly isolates its on-chip-fabric and internal resources such that they are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column13405: network on chips (NoC) have many internal resources that are shared between packets from different trust domains. These resources include internal buffers
column13408: and channels. The sharing of resources causes contention and introduces interference between differently trusted domains
column13409: which poses a security threat via a timing channel
column13410: allowing attackers to infer data that belongs to a trusted agent. This may also result in introducing network interference
column13411: resulting in degraded throughput and latency."

column13434: name:"Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor"
column13452: description:"The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information. There are many different kinds of mistakes that introduce information exposures. The severity of the error can range widely
column13453: depending on the context in which the product operates
column13454: the type of sensitive information that is revealed
column13455: and the benefits it may provide to an attacker. Some kinds of sensitive information include: private
column13461: or contact details system status and environment
column13462: such as the operating system and installed packages business secrets and intellectual property network status and configuration the product's own code or internal state metadata
column13463: e.g. logging of connections or message headers indirect information
column13464: such as a discrepancy between two internal operations that can be observed by an outsider Information might be sensitive to different parties
column13465: each of which may have their own expectations for whether the information should be protected. These parties include: the product's own users people or organizations whose information is created or used by the product
column13466: even if they are not direct product users the product's administrators
column13467: including the admins of the system(s) and\/or networks on which the product operates the developer Information exposures can occur in different ways: the code explicitly inserts sensitive information into resources or messages that are intentionally made accessible to unauthorized actors
column13468: but should not contain the information - i.e.
column13469: the information should have been \"scrubbed\" or \"sanitized\" a different weakness or mistake indirectly inserts the sensitive information into resources
column13470: such as a web script error revealing the full system path of the program. the code manages resources that intentionally contain sensitive information
column13471: but the resources are unintentionally made accessible to unauthorized actors. In this case
column13472: the information exposure is resultant - i.e.
column13473: a different weakness enabled the access to the information in the first place. It is common practice to describe any loss of confidentiality as an \"information exposure
column13474: \" but this can lead to overuse of CWE-200 in CWE mapping. From the CWE perspective
column13475: loss of confidentiality is a technical impact that can arise from dozens of different weaknesses
column13476: such as insecure file permissions or out-of-bounds read. CWE-200 and its lower-level descendants are intended to cover the mistakes that occur in behaviors that explicitly manage
column13481: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA cryptographic core in a System-On-a-Chip (SoC) is used for cryptographic acceleration and implements several cryptographic operations (e.g.
column13482: computation of AES encryption and decryption
column13485: etc.). The keys for these operations or the intermediate values are stored in registers internal to the cryptographic core. These internal registers are in the Memory Mapped Input Output (MMIO) space and are blocked from access by software and other untrusted agents on the SoC. These registers are accessible through the debug and test interface.\n"
column13486: name:"Exposure of Sensitive System Information Due to Uncleared Debug Information"
column13488: description:"The hardware does not fully clear security-sensitive values
column13489: such as keys and intermediate values in cryptographic operations
column13490: when debug mode is entered. Security sensitive values
column13493: etc. are stored in temporary registers in the hardware. If these values are not cleared when debug mode is entered they may be accessed by a debugger allowing sensitive information to be accessible by untrusted parties."

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
This example here shows how an attacker can take advantage of unnecessary information in debug messages.
Example 1: Suppose in response to a Test Access Port (TAP) chaining request the debug message also reveals the current TAP hierarchy (the full topology) in addition to the success/failure message.
Example 2: In response to a password-filling request
column13497: instead of a simple Granted\/Denied response
column13499:
"The user-entered password does not match the actual password stored in <directory name>."
The result of the above examples is that the user is able to gather additional unauthorized information about the system from the debug messages.
The solution is to ensure that Debug messages do not reveal additional details.
"
column13502: description:"The product fails to adequately prevent the revealing of unnecessary and potentially sensitive system information within debugging messages. Debug messages are messages that help troubleshoot an issue by revealing the internal state of the system. For example
column13503: debug data in design can be exposed through internal memory array dumps or boot logs through interfaces like UART via TAP commands
column13506: the more information contained in a debug message
column13507: the easier it is to debug. However
column13508: there is also the risk of revealing information that could help an attacker either decipher a vulnerability
column13509: and\/or gain a better understanding of the system. Thus
column13510: this extra information could lower the \"security by obscurity\" factor. While \"security by obscurity\" alone is insufficient
column13511: it can help as a part of \"Defense-in-depth\"."

column13563: description:"The product behaves differently or sends different responses under different circumstances in a way that is observable to an unauthorized actor
column13564: which exposes security-relevant information about the state of the product
column13565: such as whether a particular operation was successful or not. Discrepancies can take many forms
column13566: and variations may be detectable in timing
column13568: communications such as replies or requests
column13569: or general behavior. These discrepancies can reveal information about the product's operation or internal state to an unauthorized actor. In some cases

column13572: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a device that checks a passcode to unlock the screen.\nPIN numbers used to unlock a cell phone should not exhibit any characteristics about themselves. This creates a side channel. An attacker could monitor the pulses using an oscilloscope or other method. Once the first character is correctly guessed (based on the oscilloscope readings)
column13573: they can then move to the next character
column13574: which is much more efficient than the brute force method of guessing every possible sequence of characters.\nExample 2\nConsider the device vulnerability CVE-2021-3011
column13575: which affects certain microcontrollers [REF-1221]. The Google Titan Security Key is used for two-factor authentication using cryptographic algorithms. The device uses an internal secret key for this purpose and exchanges information based on this key for the authentication. If this internal secret key and the encryption algorithm were known to an adversary
column13576: the key function could be duplicated
column13577: allowing the adversary to masquerade as the legitimate user.\n"
column13578: name:"Improper Protection of Physical Side Channels"
column13583: description:"The device does not contain sufficient protection mechanisms to prevent physical side channels from exposing sensitive information due to patterns in physically observable phenomena such as variations in power consumption
column13585: or acoustic emissions. An adversary could monitor and measure physical phenomena to detect patterns and make inferences
column13586: even if it is not possible to extract the information in the digital domain. Physical side channels have been well-studied for decades in the context of breaking implementations of cryptographic algorithms or other attacks against security features. These side channels may be easily observed by an adversary with physical access to the device
column13587: or using a tool that is in close proximity. If the adversary can monitor hardware operation and correlate its data processing with power
column13590: the adversary might be able to recover of secret keys and data."
column13592: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider an example hardware module that checks a user-provided password (or PIN) to grant access to a user. The user-provided password is compared against a stored value byte-by-byte.\nSince the algorithm uses a different number of 1's and 0's for password validation
column13593: a different amount of power is consumed for the good byte versus the bad byte comparison. Using this information
column13594: an attacker may be able to guess the correct password for that byte-by-byte iteration with several repeated attempts by stopping the password evaluation before it completes.\nAmong various options for mitigating the string comparison is obscuring the power consumption by having opposing bit flips during bit operations. Note that in this example
column13595: the initial change of the bit values could still provide power indication depending upon the hardware itself. This possibility needs to be measured for verification.\nSince the algorithm uses a different number of 1's and 0's for password validation
column13596: a different amount of power is consumed for the good byte versus the bad byte comparison. Using this information
column13597: an attacker may be able to guess the correct password for that byte-by-byte iteration with several repeated attempts by stopping the password evaluation before it completes.\nAn alternative to the previous example is simply comparing the whole password simultaneously.\nSince comparison is done atomically
column13598:
there is no indication which bytes fail forcing the attacker to brute force the whole password at once. Note that other mitigations may exist such as masking - causing a large current draw to mask individual bit flips.
Example 2
This code demonstrates the transfer of a secret key using Serial-In/Serial-Out shift. It's easy to extract the secret using simple power analysis as each shift gives data on a single bit of the key.
This code demonstrates the transfer of a secret key using a Parallel-In/Parallel-Out shift. In a parallel shift

column13647: description:"The product provides different responses to incoming requests in a way that reveals internal state information to an unauthorized actor outside of the intended control sphere. This issue frequently occurs during authentication
column13648: where a difference in failed-login messages could allow an attacker to determine if the username is valid or not. These exposures can be inadvertent (bug) or intentional (design)."
column13654: description:"The product's behaviors indicate important differences that may be observed by unauthorized actors in a way that reveals (1) its internal state or decision process
column13655: or (2) differences from other products with equivalent functionality. Ideally
column13656: a product should provide as little information about its internal operations as possible. Otherwise
column13657: attackers could use knowledge of these internal operations to simplify or optimize their attack. In some cases
column13658: behavioral discrepancies can be used by attackers to form a side channel."
column13666: description:"The product performs multiple behaviors that are combined to produce a single result
column13667: but the individual behaviors are observable separately in a way that allows attackers to reveal internal state or internal decision points. Ideally
column13668: a product should provide as little information as possible to an attacker. Any hints that the attacker may be making progress can then be used to simplify or optimize the attack. For example
column13669: in a login procedure that requires a username and password
column13670: ultimately there is only one decision: success or failure. However
column13672: two separate actions are performed: determining if the username exists
column13673: and checking if the password is correct. If the product behaves differently based on whether the username exists or not
column13674: then the attacker only needs to concentrate on the password."
column13677: name:"Observable Behavioral Discrepancy With Equivalent Products"
column13681: description:"The product operates in an environment in which its existence or specific identity should not be known
column13682: but it behaves differently than other products with equivalent functionality
column13683: in a way that is observable to an attacker. For many kinds of products
column13684: multiple products may be available that perform the same functionality
column13687: or intrusion detection system. Attackers often perform \"fingerprinting
column13688: \" which uses discrepancies in order to identify which specific product is in use. Once the specific product has been identified
column13689: the attacks can be made more customized and efficient. Often
column13690: an organization might intentionally allow the specific product to be identifiable. However
column13692: the ability to identify a distinct product is unacceptable
column13693: and it is expected that every product would behave in exactly the same way. In these more restricted environments
column13694: a behavioral difference might pose an unacceptable risk if it makes it easier to identify the product's vendor
column13708: description:"Two separate operations in a product require different amounts of time to complete
column13709: in a way that is observable to an actor and reveals security-relevant information about the state of the product
column13710: such as whether a particular operation was successful or not. In security-relevant contexts
column13711: even small variations in timing can be exploited by attackers to indirectly infer certain details about the product's internal operations. For example
column13713: attackers can use timing differences to infer certain properties about a private key
column13714: making the key easier to guess. Timing discrepancies effectively form a timing side channel."

column13868: name:"Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor"
column13870: description:"The product does not properly prevent a person's private
column13871: personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected. There are many types of sensitive information that products must protect from attackers
column13877: and an individual's personal (private) information. Private personal information may include a password
column13882: etc. Private information is important to consider whether the person is a user of the product
column13883: or part of a data set that is processed by the product. An exposure of private information does not necessarily prevent the product from working properly
column13884: and in fact the exposure might be intended by the developer
column13885: e.g. as part of data sharing with other organizations. However
column13886: the exposure of personal private information can still be undesirable or explicitly prohibited by law or regulation. Some types of private information include: Government identifiers
column13887: such as Social Security Numbers Contact information
column13888: such as home addresses and telephone numbers Geographic location - where the user is (or was) Employment history Financial data - such as credit card numbers
column13893: or audio Behavioral patterns - such as web surfing history
column13895: etc. Relationships (and types of relationships) with others - family
column13904: prescription records Account passwords and other credentials Some of this information may be characterized as PII (Personally Identifiable Information)
column13906: etc. Categories of private information may overlap or vary based on the intended usage or the policies and practices of a particular industry. Sometimes data that is not labeled as private can have a privacy implication in a different context. For example
column13907: student identification numbers are usually not considered private because there is no explicit and publicly-available mapping to an individual student's personal information. However
column13908: if a school generates identification numbers based on student social security numbers
column13909: then the identification numbers should be considered private."
