column14036: description:"The Web services architecture may require exposing a Web Service Definition Language (WSDL) file that contains information on the publicly accessible services and how callers of these services should interact with them (e.g. what parameters they expect and what types they return). column14060: name:"Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')"
column14079: description:"The product uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory
column14080: but the product does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory. column14081: attackers can escape outside of the restricted location to access files or directories that are elsewhere on the system. One of the most common special elements is the \"..\/\" sequence
column14082: which in most modern operating systems is interpreted as the parent directory of the current location. This is referred to as relative path traversal. Path traversal also covers the use of absolute pathnames such as \"\/usr\/local\/bin\"
column14083: which may also be useful in accessing unexpected files. This is referred to as absolute path traversal. In many programming languages
column14084: the injection of a null byte (the 0 or NUL) may allow an attacker to truncate a generated filename to widen the scope of attack. For example
column14085: the product may add \".txt\" to any pathname
column14086: thus limiting the attacker to text files
column14087: but a null injection may effectively remove this restriction."

column14321: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following example demonstrates the weakness.\nIn this example
column14322: bar and baz will be passed by reference to doOtherStuff() which may change them.\nExample 2\nIn the following Java example
column14323: the BookStore class manages the sale of books in a bookstore
column14324: this class includes the member objects for the bookstore inventory and sales database manager classes. The BookStore class includes a method for updating the sales database and inventory when a book is sold. This method retrieves a Book object from the bookstore inventory object using the supplied ISBN number for the book class
column14325: then calls a method for the sales object to update the sales information and then calls a method for the inventory object to update inventory for the BookStore.\nHowever
column14326: in this example the Book object that is retrieved and passed to the method of the sales object could have its contents modified by the method. This could cause unexpected results when the book object is sent to the method for the inventory object to update the inventory.\nIn the Java programming language arguments to methods are passed by value
column14327: however in the case of objects a reference to the object is passed by value to the method. When an object reference is passed as a method argument a copy of the object reference is made within the method and therefore both references point to the same object. This allows the contents of the object to be modified by the method that holds the copy of the object reference. [REF-374]\nIn this case the contents of the Book object could be modified by the method of the sales object prior to the call to update the inventory.\nTo prevent the contents of the Book object from being modified
column14328: a copy of the Book object should be made before the method call to the sales object. In the following example a copy of the Book object is made using the clone() method and the copy of the Book object is passed to the method of the sales object. This will prevent any changes being made to the original Book object.\n"
column14329: name:"Passing Mutable Objects to an Untrusted Method"
column14331: description:"The product sends non-cloned mutable data as an argument to a method or function. The function or method that has been called can alter or delete the mutable data. column14332: this external code could make changes to the data sent. If this data was not previously cloned
column14333: the modified data might not be valid in the context of execution."

column14344: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code uses a temporary file for storing intermediate data gathered from the network before it is processed.\nThis otherwise unremarkable code is vulnerable to a number of different attacks because it relies on an insecure method for creating temporary files. The vulnerabilities introduced by this function and others are described in the following sections. The most egregious security problems related to temporary file creation have occurred on Unix-based operating systems
column14345: but Windows applications have parallel risks. This section includes a discussion of temporary file creation on both Unix and Windows systems. Methods and behaviors can vary between systems
column14346: but the fundamental risks introduced by each are reasonably constant.\n"
column14349: description:"Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack. "
column14351: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nIn the following code examples a temporary file is created and written to. After using the temporary file
column14352: the file is closed and deleted from the file system.\nHowever
column14353: within this C\/C++ code the method tmpfile() is used to create and open the temp file. The tmpfile() method works the same way as the fopen() method would with read\/write permission
column14354: allowing attackers to read potentially sensitive information contained in the temp file or modify the contents of the file.\nSimilarly
column14355: the createTempFile() method used in the Java code creates a temp file that may be readable and writable to all users.\nAdditionally both methods used above place the file into a default directory. On UNIX systems the default directory is usually \"\/tmp\" or \"\/var\/tmp\" and on Windows systems the default directory is usually \"C:\\\\Windows\\\\Temp\"
column14356: which may be easily accessible to attackers
column14357: possibly enabling them to read and modify the contents of the temp file.\n"

column14368: which may be easily accessible to attackers

column14370: name:"Creation of Temporary File in Directory with Insecure Permissions"
column14372: description:"The product creates a temporary file in a directory whose permissions allow unintended actors to determine the file's existence or otherwise access that file. On some operating systems
column14373: the fact that the temporary file exists may be apparent to any user with sufficient privileges to access that directory. Since the file is visible
column14374: the application that is using the temporary file could be known. If one has access to list the processes on the system
column14375: the attacker has gained information about what the user is doing at that time. By correlating this with the applications the user is running
column14376: an attacker could potentially discover what a user's actions are. From this
column14377: higher levels of security could be breached."
column14380: name:"Transmission of Private Resources into a New Sphere ('Resource Leak')"
column14382: description:"The product makes resources available to untrusted parties when those resources are only intended to be accessed by the product. "
column14385: name:"Exposure of File Descriptor to Unintended Control Sphere ('File Descriptor Leak')"
column14394: description:"A process does not close sensitive file descriptors before invoking a child process
column14395: which allows the child to perform unauthorized I\/O operations using those descriptors. When a new process is forked or executed
column14396: the child process inherits any open file descriptors. When the child process has fewer privileges than the parent process
column14397: this might introduce a vulnerability if the child process can access the file descriptor but does not have the privileges to access the associated file."
column14399: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code is from a web application that allows users access to an interface through which they can update their password on the system. In this environment
column14400: user passwords can be managed using the Network Information System (NIS)
column14401: which is commonly used on UNIX systems. When performing NIS updates
column14402: part of the process for updating passwords is to run a make command in the \/var\/yp directory. Performing NIS updates requires extra privileges.\nThe problem here is that the program does not specify an absolute path for make and does not clean its environment prior to executing the call to Runtime.exec(). If an attacker can modify the $PATH variable to point to a malicious binary called make and cause the program to be executed in their environment
column14403: then the malicious binary will be loaded instead of the one intended. Because of the nature of the application
column14404: it runs with the privileges necessary to perform system operations
column14405: which means the attacker's make will now be run with these privileges
column14406: possibly giving the attacker complete control of the system.\nExample 2\nIn February 2021 [REF-1169]
column14407: a researcher was able to demonstrate the ability to breach major technology companies by using \"dependency confusion\" where the companies would download and execute untrusted packages.\nThe researcher discovered the names of some internal
column14408: private packages by looking at dependency lists in public source code
column14409: such as package.json. The researcher then created new
column14410: untrusted packages with the same name as the internal packages
column14411: then uploaded them to package hosting services. These services included the npm registry for Node
column14414: their dependency resolution would search the public hosting services first before consulting their internal service
column14415: causing the untrusted packages to be automatically downloaded and executed.\n"
column14446: description:"The product uses a fixed or controlled search path to find resources
column14447: but one or more locations in that path can be under the control of unintended actors. Although this weakness can occur with any type of resource
column14448: it is frequently introduced when a product uses a directory search path to find executables or code libraries
column14449: but the path contains a directory that can be modified by an attacker
column14450: such as \"\/tmp\" or the current working directory. In Windows-based systems
column14451: when the LoadLibrary or LoadLibraryEx function is called with a DLL name that does not contain a fully qualified path
column14452: the function follows a search order that includes two path elements that might be uncontrolled: the directory from which the program has been loaded the current working directory In some cases
column14453: the attack can be conducted remotely
column14454: such as when SMB or WebDAV network shares are used. One or more locations in that path could include the Windows drive root or its subdirectories. This often exists in Linux-based code assuming the controlled nature of the root directory (\/) or its subdirectories (\/etc
column14456: or a code that recursively accesses the parent directory. In Windows
column14457: the drive root and some of its subdirectories have weak permissions by default
column14458: which makes them uncontrolled. In some Unix-based systems
column14459: a PATH might be created that contains an empty element
column14460: e.g. by splicing an empty variable into the PATH. This empty element can be interpreted as equivalent to the current working directory
column14461: which might be an untrusted search element. In software package management frameworks (e.g.
column14465: the framework may identify dependencies on third-party libraries or other packages
column14466: then consult a repository that contains the desired package. The framework may search a public repository before a private repository. This could be exploited by attackers by placing a malicious package in the public repository that has the same name as a package from the private repository. The search path might not be directly under control of the developer relying on the framework
column14467: but this search order effectively contains an untrusted element."
column14474: description:"The product uses a search path that contains an unquoted element
column14475: in which the element contains whitespace or other separators. This can cause the product to access resources in a parent path. If a malicious individual has access to the file system
column14476: it is possible to elevate privileges by inserting such a file as \"C:\\Program.exe\" to be run by a privileged program making use of WinExec."
column14478: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following Servlet stores the value of a request parameter in a member field and then later echoes the parameter value to the response output stream.\nWhile this code will work perfectly in a single-user environment

column14480: it is possible for the two request handler threads to interleave in the following way: Thread 1: assign \"Dick\" to name Thread 2: assign \"Jane\" to name Thread 1: print \"Jane
column14482: thanks for visiting!\" Thereby showing the first user the second user's name.\n"
column14483: name:"Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session"
column14485: description:"The product does not sufficiently enforce boundaries between the states of different sessions
column14486: causing data to be provided to
column14488: the wrong session. Data can \"bleed\" from one session to another through member variables of singleton objects
column14490: and objects from a shared pool. In the case of Servlets
column14491: developers sometimes do not understand that
column14492: unless a Servlet implements the SingleThreadModel interface
column14493: the Servlet is a singleton; there is only one instance of the Servlet
column14494: and that single instance is used and re-used to handle multiple requests that are processed simultaneously by different threads. A common result is that developers use Servlet member fields in such a way that one user may inadvertently see another user's data. In other words
column14495: storing user data in Servlet member fields introduces a data access race condition."

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
The following Java Applet code mistakenly makes use of an inner class.
Example 2
The following example shows a basic use of inner classes. The class OuterClass contains the private member inner class InnerClass. The private inner class InnerClass includes the method concat that accesses the private member variables of the class OuterClass to output the value of one of the private member variables of the class OuterClass and returns a string that is a concatenation of one of the private member variables of the class OuterClass
column14506: the separator input parameter of the method and the private member variable of the class InnerClass.\nAlthough this is an acceptable use of inner classes it demonstrates one of the weaknesses of inner classes that inner classes have complete access to all member variables and methods of the enclosing class even those that are declared private and protected. When inner classes are compiled and translated into Java bytecode the JVM treats the inner class as a peer class with package level access to the enclosing class.\nTo avoid this weakness of inner classes
column14507: consider using either static inner classes
column14509: or anonymous inner classes.\nThe following Java example demonstrates the use of static inner classes using the previous example. The inner class InnerClass is declared using the static modifier that signifies that InnerClass is a static member of the enclosing class OuterClass. By declaring an inner class as a static member of the enclosing class
column14510:
the inner class can only access other static members and methods of the enclosing class and prevents the inner class from accessing nonstatic member variables and methods of the enclosing class. In this case the inner class InnerClass can only access the static member variable memberTwo of the enclosing class OuterClass but cannot access the nonstatic member variable memberOne.
The only limitation with using a static inner class is that as a static member of the enclosing class the inner class does not have a reference to instances of the enclosing class. For many situations this may not be ideal. An alternative is to use a local inner class or an anonymous inner class as shown in the next examples.
Example 3
In the following example the BankAccount class contains the private member inner class InterestAdder that adds interest to the bank account balance. The start method of the BankAccount class creates an object of the inner class InterestAdder
column14511: the InterestAdder inner class implements the ActionListener interface with the method actionPerformed. A Timer object created within the start method of the BankAccount class invokes the actionPerformed method of the InterestAdder class every 30 days to add the interest to the bank account balance based on the interest rate passed to the start method as an input parameter. The inner class InterestAdder needs access to the private member variable balance of the BankAccount class in order to add the interest to the bank account balance.\nHowever as demonstrated in the previous example
column14512: because InterestAdder is a non-static member inner class of the BankAccount class
column14513: InterestAdder also has access to the private member variables of the BankAccount class - including the sensitive data contained in the private member variables for the bank account owner's name
column14515: and the bank account number.\nIn the following example the InterestAdder class from the above example is declared locally within the start method of the BankAccount class. As a local inner class InterestAdder has its scope restricted to the method (or enclosing block) where it is declared
column14516: in this case only the start method has access to the inner class InterestAdder
column14517:
no other classes including the enclosing class has knowledge of the inner class outside of the start method. This allows the inner class to access private member variables of the enclosing class but only within the scope of the enclosing method or block.
A similar approach would be to use an anonymous inner class as demonstrated in the next example. An anonymous inner class is declared without a name and creates only a single instance of the inner class object. As in the previous example the anonymous inner class has its scope restricted to the start method of the BankAccount class.
Example 4
In the following Java example a simple applet provides the capability for a user to input a URL into a text field and have the URL opened in a new browser window. The applet contains an inner class that is an action listener for the submit button
column14518: when the user clicks the submit button the inner class action listener's actionPerformed method will open the URL entered into the text field in a new browser window. As with the previous examples using inner classes in this manner creates a security risk by exposing private variables and methods. Inner classes create an additional security risk with applets as applets are executed on a remote machine through a web browser within the same JVM and therefore may run side-by-side with other potentially malicious code.\nAs with the previous examples a solution to this problem would be to use a static inner class
column14519: a local inner class or an anonymous inner class. An alternative solution would be to have the applet implement the action listener rather than using it as an inner class as shown in the following example.\n"
column14520: name:"Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data"
column14522: description:"Inner classes are translated into classes that are accessible at package scope and may expose code that the programmer intended to keep private to attackers. Inner classes quietly introduce several security concerns because of the way they are translated into Java bytecode. In Java source code
column14523: it appears that an inner class can be declared to be accessible only by the enclosing class
column14524: but Java bytecode has no concept of an inner class
column14525: so the compiler must transform an inner class declaration into a peer class with package level access to the original outer class. More insidiously
column14526: since an inner class can access private fields in its enclosing class
column14527: once an inner class becomes a peer class in bytecode
column14528: the compiler converts private fields accessed by the inner class into protected fields."

column14776: name:"Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information"
column14778: description:"The web application uses persistent cookies
column14779: but the cookies contain sensitive information. Cookies are small bits of data that are sent by the web application but stored locally in the browser. This lets the application use the cookie to pass information between pages and store variable information. The web application controls what information is stored in a cookie and how it is used. Typical types of information stored in cookies are session identifiers
column14781: and in rare cases even usernames to enable automated logins. There are two different types of cookies: session cookies and persistent cookies. Session cookies just live in the browser's memory and are not stored anywhere
column14782: but persistent cookies are stored on the browser's hard drive. This can cause security and privacy issues depending on the information stored in the cookie and how it is accessed."

column15000: description:"Executing commands or loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands (and payloads) on behalf of an attacker. Process control vulnerabilities take two forms: An attacker can change the command that the program executes: the attacker explicitly controls what the command is. An attacker can change the environment in which the command executes: the attacker implicitly controls what the command means. Process control vulnerabilities of the first type occur when either data enters the application from an untrusted source and the data is used as part of a string representing a command that is executed by the application. By executing the command
column15001: the application gives an attacker a privilege or capability that the attacker would not otherwise have."

column15125: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis application wants to create a user account in several trusted applications using one broadcast intent:\nThis application assumes only the trusted applications will be listening for the action. A malicious application can register for this action and intercept the user's login information
column15126: as below:\nWhen a broadcast contains sensitive information
column15127: create an allowlist of applications that can receive the action using the application's manifest file
column15128: or programmatically send the intent to each individual intended receiver.\nExample 2\nThis application interfaces with a web service that requires a separate user login. It creates a sticky intent
column15129: so that future trusted applications that also use the web service will know who the current user is:\nSticky broadcasts can be read by any application at any time
column15130: and so should never contain sensitive information such as a username.\nExample 3\nThis application is sending an ordered broadcast

column15132:
send intents to specific trusted applications instead of using a broadcast chain.

Any malicious application can register to receive this intent. Because of the FLAG_GRANT_READ_URI_PERMISSION included with the intent

column15134: name:"Use of Implicit Intent for Sensitive Communication"
column15136: description:"The Android application uses an implicit intent for transmitting sensitive data to other applications. Since an implicit intent does not specify a particular application to receive the data
column15137: any application can process the intent by using an Intent Filter for that intent. This can allow untrusted applications to obtain sensitive data. There are two variations on the standard broadcast intent
column15138: ordered and sticky. Ordered broadcast intents are delivered to a series of registered receivers in order of priority as declared by the Receivers. A malicious receiver can give itself a high priority and cause a denial of service by stopping the broadcast from propagating further down the chain. There is also the possibility of malicious data modification
column15139: as a receiver may also alter the data within the Intent before passing it on to the next receiver. The downstream components have no way of asserting that the data has not been altered earlier in the chain. Sticky broadcast intents remain accessible after the initial broadcast. An old sticky intent will be broadcast again to any new receivers that register for it in the future
column15140: greatly increasing the chances of information exposure over time. Also
column15141: sticky broadcasts cannot be protected by permissions that may apply to other kinds of intents. In addition
column15142: any broadcast intent may include a URI that references data that the receiving component does not normally have the privileges to access. The sender of the intent can include special privileges that grant the receiver read or write access to the specific URI included in the intent. A malicious receiver that intercepts this intent will also gain those privileges and be able to read or write the resource at the specified URI."

column15154: name:"Improper Removal of Sensitive Information Before Storage or Transfer"
column15159: or shares a resource that contains sensitive information
column15160: but it does not properly remove that information before the product makes the resource available to unauthorized actors. Resources that may contain sensitive data include documents
column15164: etc. While this data may be useful to an individual user or small set of users who share the resource
column15165: it may need to be removed before the resource can be shared outside of the trusted group. The process of removal is sometimes called cleansing or scrubbing. For example
column15166: a product for editing documents might not remove sensitive data such as reviewer comments or the local pathname where the document is stored. Or
column15167: a proxy might not remove an internal IP address from headers before making an outgoing request to an Internet site."
column15169: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA cryptographic core in a System-On-a-Chip (SoC) is used for cryptographic acceleration and implements several cryptographic operations (e.g.
column15170: computation of AES encryption and decryption
column15173: etc.). The keys for these operations or the intermediate values are stored in registers internal to the cryptographic core. These internal registers are in the Memory Mapped Input Output (MMIO) space and are blocked from access by software and other untrusted agents on the SoC. These registers are accessible through the debug and test interface.\n"
column15174: name:"Exposure of Sensitive System Information Due to Uncleared Debug Information"
column15176: description:"The hardware does not fully clear security-sensitive values
column15177: such as keys and intermediate values in cryptographic operations
column15178: when debug mode is entered. Security sensitive values
column15181: etc. are stored in temporary registers in the hardware. If these values are not cleared when debug mode is entered they may be accessed by a debugger allowing sensitive information to be accessible by untrusted parties."

they can be accessed indirectly by reading the memory that contains the private keys.

column15193: name:"Sensitive Information in Resource Not Removed Before Reuse"
column15201: description:"The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse
column15202: but it does not clear or \"zeroize\" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities. When resources are released
column15203: they can be made available for reuse. For example
column15205: an operating system may make the memory available to another process
column15206: or disk space may be reallocated when a file is deleted. As removing information requires time and additional resources
column15207: operating systems do not usually clear the previously written information. Even when the resource is reused by the same process
column15208: this weakness can arise when new data is not as large as the old data
column15209: which leaves portions of the old data still available. Equivalent errors can occur in other situations where the length of data is variable but the associated data structure is not. If memory is not cleared after use
column15210: the information may be read by less trustworthy parties when the memory is reallocated. This weakness can apply in hardware
column15211: such as when a device or system switches between power
column15213: or debug states during normal operation
column15214: or when execution changes to different users or privilege levels."
column15216: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nSuppose a hardware IP for implementing an encryption routine works as expected
column15217: but it leaves the intermediate results in some registers that can be accessed. Exactly why this access happens is immaterial - it might be unintentional or intentional
column15218: where the designer wanted a \"quick fix\" for something.\n"
column15221: description:"The hardware product does not properly clear sensitive information from built-in registers when the user of the hardware block changes. Hardware logic operates on data stored in registers local to the hardware block. Most hardware IPs
column15223: rely on registers to buffer I\/O
column15225: and interface with software. The result of this is that sensitive information
column15226: such as passwords or encryption keys
column15227: can exist in locations not transparent to the user of the hardware logic. When a different entity obtains access to the IP due to a change in operating mode or conditions
column15228: the new entity can extract information belonging to the previous user if no mechanisms are in place to clear register contents. It is important to clear information stored in the hardware if a physical attack on the product is detected
column15229: or if the user of the hardware block changes. The process of clearing register contents in a hardware IP is referred to as zeroization in standards for cryptographic hardware modules such as FIPS-140-2 [REF-267]."
column15232: name:"Insufficient or Incomplete Data Removal within Hardware Component"
column15234: description:"The product's data removal process does not completely delete all data and potentially sensitive information within hardware components. Physical properties of hardware devices
column15235: such as remanence of magnetic media
column15237: or screen burn-in may still retain sensitive data after a data removal process has taken place and power is removed. Recovering data after erasure or overwriting is possible due to a phenomenon called data remanence. For example
column15238: if the same value is written repeatedly to a memory location
column15239: the corresponding memory cells can become physically altered to a degree such that even after the original data is erased that data can still be recovered through physical characterization of the memory cells."
column15241: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a device that uses flash memory for non-volatile-data storage. To optimize flash-access performance or reliable-flash lifetime
column15242: the device might limit the number of flash writes\/erases by maintaining some state in internal SRAM and only committing changes to flash memory periodically.\nThe device also supports user reset to factory defaults with the expectation that all personal information is erased from the device after this operation. On factory reset
column15243: user files are erased using explicit
column15244: erase commands supported by the flash device.\nIn the given
column15246: the flash-file system can support performance-optimized erase such that only the file metadata are erased and not the content. If this optimized erase is used for files containing user data during factory-reset flow
column15248: flash memory can contain remanent data from these files.\nOn device-factory reset
column15249: the implementation might not erase these copies
column15250: since the file organization has changed and the flash file system does not have the metadata to track all previous copies.\nA flash-memory region that is used by a flash-file system should be fully erased as part of the factory-reset flow. This should include secure-erase flow for the flash media such as overwriting patterns multiple times followed by erase.\n"
column15251: name:"Remanent Data Readable after Memory Erase"
column15253: description:"Confidential information stored in memory circuits is readable or recoverable after being cleared or erased. Data remanence occurs when stored
column15254: memory content is not fully lost after a memory-clear or -erase operation. Confidential memory contents can still be readable through data remanence in the hardware. Data remanence can occur because of performance optimization or memory organization during 'clear' or 'erase' operations
column15255: like a design that allows the memory-organization metadata (e.g.
column15256: file pointers) to be erased without erasing the actual memory content. To protect against this weakness
column15257: memory devices will often support different commands for optimized memory erase and explicit secure erase. Data remanence can also happen because of the physical properties of memory circuits in use. For example
column15260: random-access-memory (DRAM) data retention is based on the charge retained in the memory cell
column15261: which depends on factors such as power supply
column15263: and temperature. Other than explicit erase commands
column15265: secure-memory devices can also support secure erase through cryptographic erase commands. In such designs
column15266: only the decryption keys for encrypted data stored on the device are erased. That is
column15267: the stored data are always remnant in the media after a cryptographic erase. However
column15268: only the encrypted data can be extracted. Thus
column15269: protection against data recovery in such designs relies on the strength of the encryption algorithm."
column15271: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nFaulting loads in a victim domain may trigger incorrect transient forwarding
column15272:
which leaves secret-dependent traces in the microarchitectural state. Consider this example from [REF-1203].
Consider the code gadget:

A processor with this weakness will store the value of untrusted_arg (which may be provided by an attacker) to the stack
column15274: this store operation will save this value in some microarchitectural buffer
column15275: e.g. the store queue.\nIn this code gadget
column15276: trusted_ptr is dereferenced while the attacker forces a page fault. The faulting load causes the processor to mis-speculate by forwarding untrusted_arg as the (speculative) load result. The processor then uses untrusted_arg for the pointer dereference. After the fault has been handled and the load has been re-issued with the correct argument
column15277: secret-dependent information stored at the address of trusted_ptr remains in microarchitectural state and can be extracted by an attacker using a code gadget.\n\n"
column15278: name:"Information Exposure through Microarchitectural State after Transient Execution"
column15280: description:"The processor does not properly clear microarchitectural state after incorrect microcode assists or speculative execution
column15281: resulting in transient execution. In many processor architectures an exception
column15283: or microcode assist results in a flush operation to clear results that are no longer required. This action prevents these results from influencing architectural state that is intended to be visible from software. However
column15284: traces of this transient execution may remain in microarchitectural buffers
column15285: resulting in a change in microarchitectural state that can expose sensitive information to an attacker using side-channel analysis. For example
column15286: Load Value Injection (LVI) [REF-1202] can exploit direct injection of erroneous values into intermediate load and store buffers. Several conditions may need to be fulfilled for a successful attack: 1) incorrect transient execution that results in remanence of sensitive information; 2) attacker has the ability to provoke microarchitectural exceptions; 3) operations and structures in victim code that can be exploited must be identified."

column15384: name:"Inclusion of Web Functionality from an Untrusted Source"
column15386: description:"The product includes web functionality (such as a web widget) from another domain
column15387: which causes it to operate within the domain of the product
column15388: potentially granting total access and control of the product to the untrusted source. Including third party functionality in a web-based environment is risky
column15389: especially if the source of the functionality is untrusted. Even if the third party is a trusted source
column15390: the product may still be exposed to attacks and malicious behavior if that trusted source is compromised
column15391: or if the code is modified in transmission from the third party to the product. This weakness is common in \"mashup\" development on the web
column15392: which may include source functionality from other domains. For example
column15393: Javascript-based web widgets may be inserted by using '<SCRIPT SRC=\"http:\/\/other.domain.here\">' tags
column15394: which causes the code to run in the domain of the product
column15395: not the remote site from which the widget was loaded. As a result
column15396: the included code has access to the local DOM
column15397: including cookies and other data that the developer might not want the remote site to be able to access. Such dependencies may be desirable
column15399: but sometimes programmers are not aware that a dependency exists."

ping would considered "0127.0.0.1" the same as "87.0.0.1".

column15468: it will use the unexpectedly valid IP address (CWE-1389). For example
column15469: \"0x63.63.63.63\" would be considered equivalent to \"99.63.63.63\". As a result

the attacker could potentially ping systems that the attacker cannot reach directly.

column15482: name:"Incorrect Parsing of Numbers with Different Radices"
column15490: description:"The product parses numeric input assuming base 10 (decimal) values
column15491: but it does not account for inputs that use a different base number (radix). Frequently
column15492: a numeric input that begins with \"0\" is treated as octal
column15493: or \"0x\" causes it to be treated as hexadecimal
column15494: e.g. by the inet_addr() function. For example
column15496: or \"0x31\" is 49 decimal. Other bases may be used as well. If the developer assumes decimal-only inputs
column15497: the code could produce incorrect numbers when the inputs are parsed using a different base. This can result in unexpected and\/or dangerous behavior. For example
column15498: a \"0127.0.0.1\" IP address is parsed as octal due to the leading \"0\"
column15499: whose numeric value would be the same as 87.0.0.1 (decimal)
column15500: where the developer likely expected to use 127.0.0.1. The consequences vary depending on the surrounding code in which this weakness occurs
column15501: but they can include bypassing network-based access control using unexpected IP addresses or netmasks
column15502: or causing apparently-symbolic identifiers to be processed as if they are numbers. In web applications
column15503: this can enable bypassing of SSRF restrictions."

column15645: name:"Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')"
column15664: description:"The product uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory
column15665: but the product does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory. Many file operations are intended to take place within a restricted directory. By using special elements such as \"..\" and \"\/\" separators
column15666: attackers can escape outside of the restricted location to access files or directories that are elsewhere on the system. One of the most common special elements is the \"..\/\" sequence
column15667: which in most modern operating systems is interpreted as the parent directory of the current location. This is referred to as relative path traversal. Path traversal also covers the use of absolute pathnames such as \"\/usr\/local\/bin\"
column15668: which may also be useful in accessing unexpected files. This is referred to as absolute path traversal. In many programming languages
column15669: the injection of a null byte (the 0 or NUL) may allow an attacker to truncate a generated filename to widen the scope of attack. For example
column15670: the product may add \".txt\" to any pathname
column15671: thus limiting the attacker to text files
column15672: but a null injection may effectively remove this restriction."

column16234: description:"The product does not handle or incorrectly handles a file name that identifies a \"virtual\" resource that is not directly specified within the directory that is associated with the file name

column16240: name:"Improper Handling of Windows Device Names"
column16250: description:"The product constructs pathnames from user input

column16255: LPT1) can result in different types of vulnerabilities. In some cases an attacker can request a device via injection of a virtual filename in a URL
column16256: which may cause an error that leads to a denial of service or an error page that reveals sensitive information. A product that allows device names to bypass filtering runs the risk of an attacker injecting malicious code in a file with the name of a device."

column16269: name:"Improper Handling of Apple HFS+ Alternate Data Stream Path"
column16271: description:"The product does not properly handle special paths that may identify the data or resource fork of a file on the HFS+ file system. If the product chooses actions to take based on the file name

column16296: description:"The product uses a reference count to manage a resource
column16297: but it does not update or incorrectly updates the reference count. Reference counts can be used when tracking how many objects contain a reference to a particular resource
column16298: such as in memory management or garbage collection. When the reference count reaches zero
column16299: the resource can be de-allocated or reused because there are no more objects that use it. If the reference count accidentally reaches zero
column16300: then the resource might be released too soon
column16301: even though it is still in use. If all objects no longer use the resource
column16302: but the reference count is not zero
column16303: then the resource might not ever be released."

column16308: description:"The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables
column16313: or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code

column16925: description:"The product contains a code sequence that can run concurrently with other code
column16926: and the code sequence requires temporary
column16927: exclusive access to a shared resource
column16928: but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence that is operating concurrently. This can have security implications when the expected synchronization is in security-critical code
column16929: such as recording whether a user is authenticated or modifying important state information that should not be influenced by an outsider. A race condition occurs within concurrent environments
column16930: and is effectively a property of a code sequence. Depending on the context
column16931: a code sequence may be in the form of a function call
column16934: etc. A race condition violates these properties
column16935: which are closely related: Exclusivity - the code sequence is given exclusive access to the shared resource
column16937: no other code sequence can modify properties of the shared resource before the original sequence has completed execution. Atomicity - the code sequence is behaviorally atomic
column16939: no other thread or process can concurrently execute the same sequence of instructions (or a subset) against the same resource. A race condition exists when an \"interfering code sequence\" can still access the shared resource
column16940: violating exclusivity. Programmers may assume that certain code sequences execute too quickly to be affected by an interfering code sequence; when they are not
column16942: the single \"x++\" statement may appear atomic at the code layer
column16943: but it is actually non-atomic at the instruction layer
column16944: since it involves a read (the original value of x)
column16946: followed by a write (save the result to x). The interfering code sequence could be \"trusted\" or \"untrusted.\" A trusted interfering code sequence occurs within the product; it cannot be modified by the attacker
column16947: and it can only be invoked indirectly. An untrusted interfering code sequence can be authored directly by the attacker
column16948: and typically it is external to the vulnerable product."

column17181: description:"The product does not properly acquire or release a lock on a resource
column17182: leading to unexpected resource state changes and behaviors. Locking is a type of synchronization behavior that ensures that multiple independently-operating processes or threads do not interfere with each other when accessing the same resource. All processes\/threads are expected to follow the same steps for locking. If these steps are not followed precisely - or if no locking is done at all - then another process\/thread could modify the shared resource in a way that is not visible or predictable to the original process. This can lead to data or memory corruption
column17186:
{"exampleDescription":"Example 1

Consider the memory configuration settings of a system that uses DDR3 DRAM memory. Protecting the DRAM memory configuration from modification by software is required to ensure that system memory access control protections cannot be bypassed. This can be done by using lock bit protection that locks all of the memory configuration registers. The memory configuration lock can be set by the BIOS during the boot process.
If such a system also supports a rapid power on mode like hibernate
column17187: the DRAM data must be saved to a disk before power is removed and restored back to the DRAM once the system powers back up and before the OS resumes operation after returning from hibernate.\n\nTo support the hibernate transition back to the operating state
column17188: the DRAM memory configuration must be reprogrammed even though it was locked previously. As the hibernate resume does a partial reboot
column17189: the memory configuration could be altered before the memory lock is set. Functionally the hibernate resume flow requires a bypass of the lock-based protection. The memory configuration must be securely stored and restored by trusted system firmware. Lock settings and system configuration must be restored to the same state it was in before the device entered into the hibernate mode.\n"
column17190: name:"Improper Lock Behavior After Power State Transition"
column17192: description:"Register lock bit protection disables changes to system configuration once the bit is set. Some of the protected registers or lock bits become programmable after power state transitions (e.g.
column17193: Entry and wake from low power sleep modes) causing the system configuration to be changeable. Devices may allow device configuration controls which need to be programmed after device power reset via a trusted firmware or software module (commonly set by BIOS\/bootloader) and then locked from any further modification. This action is commonly implemented using a programmable lock bit
column17196: disables writes to a protected set of registers or address regions. After a power state transition
column17197: the lock bit is set to unlocked. Some common weaknesses that can exist in such a protection scheme are that the lock gets cleared
column17198: the values of the protected registers get reset

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
Consider the example design below for a digital thermal sensor that detects overheating of the silicon and triggers system shutdown. The system critical temperature limit (CRITICAL_TEMP_LIMIT) and thermal sensor calibration (TEMP_SENSOR_CALIB) data have to be programmed by the firmware.

In this example note that only the CRITICAL_TEMP_LIMIT register is protected by the TEMP_SENSOR_LOCK bit
column17202: while the security design intent is to protect any modification of the critical temperature detection and response.\nThe response of the system
column17203: if the system heats to a critical temperature
column17206: the TEMP_SENSOR_CALIB register is not protected by the lock bit.\nBy modifying the temperature sensor calibration
column17207: the conversion of the sensor data to a degree centigrade can be changed
column17208: such that the current temperature will never be detected to exceed critical temperature value programmed by the protected lock.\nSimilarly
column17210:
the system response detection of the current temperature exceeding critical temperature can be disabled.

Change TEMP_HW_SHUTDOWN and TEMP_SENSOR_CALIB controls to be locked by TEMP_SENSOR_LOCK.

"
column17211: name:"Security-Sensitive Hardware Controls with Missing Lock Bit Protection"
column17214: description:"The product uses a register lock bit protection mechanism
column17215: but it does not ensure that the lock bit prevents modification of system registers or controls that perform changes to important hardware system configuration. Integrated circuits and hardware intellectual properties (IPs) might provide device configuration controls that need to be programmed after device power reset by a trusted firmware or software module
column17216: commonly set by BIOS\/bootloader. After reset
column17217: there can be an expectation that the controls cannot be used to perform any further modification. This behavior is commonly implemented using a trusted lock bit
column17218: which can be set to disable writes to a protected set of registers or address regions. The lock protection is intended to prevent modification of certain system configuration (e.g.
column17220: if the lock bit does not effectively write-protect all system registers or controls that could modify the protected system configuration
column17221: then an adversary may be able to use software to access the registers\/controls and modify the protected hardware configuration."

column17232: disables writes to a protected set of registers or address regions. The lock protection is intended to prevent modification of certain system configuration (e.g.

column17256: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following function attempts to acquire a lock in order to perform operations on a shared resource.\nHowever
column17257: the code does not check the value returned by pthread_mutex_lock() for errors. If pthread_mutex_lock() cannot acquire the mutex for any reason
column17258: the function may introduce a race condition into the program and result in undefined behavior.\nIn order to avoid data races
column17259: correctly written programs must check the result of thread synchronization functions and appropriately handle all errors
column17260:
either by attempting to recover from them or reporting them to higher levels.
Example 2
This Java example shows a simple BankAccount class with deposit and withdraw methods.
However
column17261: the deposit and withdraw methods have shared access to the account balance private class variable. This can result in a race condition if multiple threads attempt to call the deposit and withdraw methods simultaneously where the account balance is modified by one thread before another thread has completed modifying the account balance. For example
column17262: if a thread attempts to withdraw funds using the withdraw method before another thread that is depositing funds using the deposit method completes the deposit then there may not be sufficient funds for the withdraw transaction.\nTo prevent multiple threads from having simultaneous access to the account balance variable the deposit and withdraw methods should be synchronized using the synchronized modifier.\nAn alternative solution is to use a lock object to ensure exclusive access to the bank account balance variable. column17271: name:"Sensitive Data Storage in Improperly Locked Memory"
column17273: description:"The product stores sensitive data in memory that is not locked
column17274: or that has been incorrectly locked
column17275: which might cause the memory to be written to swap files on disk by the virtual memory manager. This can make the data more accessible to external actors. On Windows systems the VirtualLock function can lock a page of memory to ensure that it will remain present in memory and not be swapped to disk. However
column17280: the VirtualLock() function is only a stub and provides no protection. On POSIX systems the mlock() call ensures that a page will stay resident in memory but does not guarantee that the page will not appear in the swap. Therefore
column17281: it is unsuitable for use as a protection mechanism for sensitive data. Some platforms
column17283: do make the guarantee that the page will not be swapped
column17284: but this is non-standard and is not portable. Calls to mlock() also require supervisor privilege. Return values for both of these calls must be checked to ensure that the lock operation was actually successful."

column17420: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThere are several standard on-chip bus protocols used in modern SoCs to allow communication between components. There are a wide variety of commercially available hardware IP implementing the interconnect logic for these protocols. A bus connects components which initiate\/request communications such as processors and DMA controllers (bus masters) with peripherals which respond to requests. In a typical system
column17421: the privilege level or security designation of the bus master along with the intended functionality of each peripheral determine the security policy specifying which specific bus masters can access specific peripherals. This security policy (commonly referred to as a bus firewall) can be enforced using separate IP\/logic from the actual interconnect responsible for the data routing.\n"
column17422: name:"Hardware Logic with Insecure De-Synchronization between Control and Data Channels"
column17424: description:"The hardware logic for error handling and security checks can incorrectly forward data before the security check is complete. Many high-performance on-chip bus protocols and processor data-paths employ separate channels for control and data to increase parallelism and maximize throughput. Bugs in the hardware logic that handle errors and security checks can make it possible for data to be forwarded before the completion of the security checks. If the data can propagate to a location in the hardware observable to an attacker
column17425: loss of data confidentiality can occur. 'Meltdown' is a concrete example of how de-synchronization between data and permissions checking logic can violate confidentiality requirements. Data loaded from a page marked as privileged was returned to the cpu regardless of current privilege level for performance reasons. The assumption was that the cpu could later remove all traces of this data during the handling of the illegal memory access exception
column17426: but this assumption was proven false as traces of the secret data were not removed from the microarchitectural state."

column17436: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nIn the following Java example a Customer Entity EJB provides access to customer information in a database for a business application.\nHowever
column17437: the customer entity EJB uses the synchronized keyword for the set methods to attempt to provide thread safe synchronization for the member variables. column17438: name:"EJB Bad Practices: Use of Synchronization Primitives"
column17440: description:"The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using thread synchronization primitives. The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case
column17441: the product violates the following EJB guideline: \"An enterprise bean must not use thread synchronization primitives to synchronize execution of multiple instances.\" The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: \"This rule is required to ensure consistent runtime semantics because while some EJB containers may use a single JVM to execute all enterprise bean's instances
column17442: others may distribute the instances across multiple JVMs.\""

column17585: name:"DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase"
column17587: description:"The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established
column17588: which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product. DMA is included in a number of devices because it allows data transfer between the computer and the connected device
column17589: using direct hardware access to read or write directly to main memory without any OS interaction. An attacker could exploit this to access secrets. Several virtualization-based mitigations have been introduced to thwart DMA attacks. These are usually configured\/setup during boot time. However
column17590: certain IPs that are powered up before boot is complete (known as early boot IPs) may be DMA capable. Such IPs
column17592: could launch DMA attacks and gain access to assets that should otherwise be protected."
column17595: name:"Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control"
column17597: description:"The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled. After initial reset

column17706: name:"Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference"
column17708: description:"Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer. Programmers typically catch NullPointerException under three circumstances: The program contains a null pointer dereference. Catching the resulting exception was easier than fixing the underlying problem. The program explicitly throws a NullPointerException to signal an error condition. The code is part of a test harness that supplies unexpected input to the classes under test. Of these three circumstances
column17711: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following code excerpt handles three types of exceptions in an identical fashion.\nAt first blush
column17712: it may seem preferable to deal with these exceptions in a single catch block
column17714: if doExchange() is modified to throw a new type of exception that should be handled in some different kind of way
column17715: the broad catch block will prevent the compiler from pointing out the situation. Further
column17716: the new catch block will now also handle exceptions derived from RuntimeException such as ClassCastException
column17718: which is not the programmer's intent.\n"
column17719: name:"Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception"
column17721: description:"Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities. Multiple catch blocks can get ugly and repetitive
column17722: but \"condensing\" catch blocks by catching a high-level class like Exception can obscure exceptions that deserve special treatment or that should not be caught at this point in the program. Catching an overly broad exception essentially defeats the purpose of Java's typed exceptions
column17723: and can become particularly dangerous if the program grows and begins to throw new types of exceptions. The new exception types will not receive any attention."

Declaring a method to throw Exception or Throwable makes it difficult for callers to perform proper error handling and error recovery. Java's exception mechanism
column17735: is set up to make it easy for callers to anticipate what can go wrong and write code to handle each specific exceptional circumstance. Declaring that a method throws a generic form of exception defeats this system."

column17782: description:"The product contains a conditional statement with multiple logical expressions in which one of the non-leading expressions may produce side effects. This may lead to an unexpected state in the program after the execution of the conditional
column17783: because short-circuiting logic may prevent the side effects from occurring. Usage of short circuit evaluation
column17784: though well-defined in the C standard
column17785: may alter control flow in a way that introduces logic errors that are difficult to detect
column17786: possibly causing errors later during the product's execution. If an attacker can discover such an inconsistency
column17787: it may be exploitable to gain arbitrary control over a system. If the first condition of an \"or\" statement is assumed to be true under normal circumstances
column17788: or if the first condition of an \"and\" statement is assumed to be false
column17789: then any subsequent conditional may contain its own logic errors that are not detected during code review or testing. Finally
column17790: the usage of short circuit evaluation may decrease the maintainability of the code."

column17795: description:"The product does not properly limit the number or frequency of interactions that it has with an actor
column17796: such as the number of incoming requests. This can allow the actor to perform actions more frequently than expected. The actor could be a human or an automated process such as a virus or bot. This could be used to cause a denial of service
column17797: compromise program logic (such as limiting humans to a single vote)
column17799: an authentication routine might not limit the number of times an attacker can guess a password. Or
column17800: a web site might conduct a poll but only expect humans to vote a maximum of once a day."
column17803: an attacker was able to gain administrator access to a Twitter server because the server did not restrict the number of login attempts [REF-236]. The attacker targeted a member of Twitter's support team and was able to successfully guess the member's password using a brute force attack by guessing a large number of common words. After gaining access as the member of the support staff

column17807: performs an authentication lookup every time the servlet is invoked.\nHowever
column17808:
the software makes no attempt to restrict excessive authentication attempts.

However
column17809: there is no limit on parallel connections
column17810: so this does not increase the amount of time an attacker needs to complete an attack.\nExample 4\nIn the following C\/C++ example the validateUser method opens a socket connection
column17811:
reads a username and password from the socket and attempts to authenticate the username and password.
The validateUser method will continuously check for a valid username and password without any restriction on the number of authentication attempts made. The method should limit the number of authentication attempts made to prevent brute force attacks as in the following example code.
Example 5

column17835: description:"The product requires that an actor should only be able to perform an action once
column17836: or to have only one unique action
column17837: but the product does not enforce or improperly enforces this restriction. In various applications
column17838: a user is only expected to perform a certain action once
column17841: or making a purchase. When this restriction is not enforced
column17842: sometimes this can have security implications. For example
column17844: an attacker could attempt to \"stuff the ballot box\" by voting multiple times. If these votes are counted separately
column17845: then the attacker could directly affect who wins the vote. This could have significant business impact depending on the purpose of the product."
column17851: description:"The product performs an iteration or loop without sufficiently limiting the number of times that the loop is executed. If the iteration can be influenced by an attacker
column17852: this weakness could allow attackers to consume excessive resources such as CPU or memory. In many cases
column17853: a loop does not need to be infinite in order to cause enough resource consumption to adversely affect the product or its host system; it depends on the amount of resources consumed per iteration."
column17856: name:"Use of Blocking Code in Single-threaded
column17859: description:"The product uses a non-blocking model that relies on a single threaded process for features such as scalability
column17860: but it contains code that can block when it is invoked. When an attacker can directly invoke the blocking code
column17861: or the blocking code can be affected by environmental conditions that can be influenced by an attacker
column17862: then this can lead to a denial of service by causing unexpected hang or freeze of the code. Examples of blocking code might be an expensive computation or calling blocking library calls
column17863: such as those that perform exclusive file operations or require a successful network operation. Due to limitations in multi-thread models
column17864: single-threaded models are used to overcome the resource constraints that are caused by using many threads. In such a model
column17865: all code should generally be non-blocking. If blocking code is called
column17866: then the event loop will effectively be stopped
column17867: which can be undesirable or dangerous. Such models are used in Python asyncio
column17870: or other custom event loop code."

column17917: description:"The product supports a session in which more than one behavior must be performed by an actor
column17918: but it does not properly ensure that the actor performs the behaviors in the required sequence. By performing actions in an unexpected order
column17920: an attacker could manipulate the business logic of the product or cause it to enter an invalid state. In some cases
column17921: this can also expose resultant weaknesses. For example
column17922: a file-sharing protocol might require that an actor perform separate steps to provide a username
column17924: before being able to transfer files. If the file-sharing server accepts a password command followed by a transfer command
column17926: the product might still perform the transfer. Note that this is different than CWE-696
column17927: which focuses on when the product performs actions in the wrong sequence; this entry is closely related
column17928: but it is focused on ensuring that the actor performs actions in the correct sequence. Workflow-related behaviors include: Steps are performed in the expected order. Required steps are not omitted. Steps are not interrupted. Steps are performed in a timely fashion."
column17933: description:"The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A \"missing\" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An \"insufficient\" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example
column17934: against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally
column17935: an \"ignored\" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product
column17936: but the developer has not applied it in some code path."
column17939: name:"Automated Recognition Mechanism with Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations"
column17941: description:"The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category
column17942: but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different
column17943: incorrect concept. When techniques such as machine learning are used to automatically classify input streams
column17944: and those classifications are used for security-critical decisions
column17945: then any mistake in classification can introduce a vulnerability that allows attackers to cause the product to make the wrong security decision. If the automated mechanism is not developed or \"trained\" with enough input data
column17946: then attackers may be able to craft malicious input that intentionally triggers the incorrect classification. Targeted technologies include
column17947: but are not necessarily limited to: automated speech recognition automated image recognition For example
column17948: an attacker might modify road signs or road surface markings to trick autonomous vehicles into misreading the sign\/marking and performing a dangerous action."

The network-on-chip implements a firewall for access control to peripherals from all IP cores capable of mastering transactions.
