"
column17951: name:"Semiconductor Defects in Hardware Logic with Security-Sensitive Implications"
column17953: description:"The security-sensitive hardware module contains semiconductor defects. A semiconductor device can fail for various reasons. While some are manufacturing and packaging defects
column17954: the rest are due to prolonged use or usage under extreme conditions. Some mechanisms that lead to semiconductor defects include encapsulation failure
column17962: and thermal\/electrical stress. These defects manifest as faults on chip-internal signals or registers
column17965: or intermediate signals being always 0 or always 1
column17966: and do not switch as expected. If such faults occur in security-sensitive hardware modules
column17967: security guarantees offered by the device will be compromised."
column17969: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\n\nA chip implements a secure boot and uses the sensed value of a fuse \"do_secure_boot\" to determine whether to perform a secure boot or not. If this fuse value is \"0\"
column17970: the system performs secure boot. Otherwise
column17971: it does not perform secure boot.\nAn attacker blows the \"do_secure_boot\" fuse to \"1\". After reset
column17972: the attacker loads a custom bootloader
column17974: since the fuse value is now \"1\"
column17975: the system does not perform secure boot
column17976: and the attacker can execute their custom firmware image.\nSince by default
column17978: an attacker can blow it to a \"1\" with inexpensive hardware.\nIf the logic is reversed
column17979: an attacker cannot easily reset the fuse. Note that
column17981: an attacker with full physical access might be able to \"unblow\" the fuse value to a \"0\".\n\n"
column17984: description:"The logic level used to set a system to a secure state relies on a fuse being unblown. An attacker can set the system to an insecure state merely by blowing the fuse. Fuses are often used to store secret data
column17985: including security configuration data. When not blown
column17986: a fuse is considered to store a logic 0
column17989: it indicates a logic 1. Fuses are generally considered to be one-directional
column17992: it cannot be reset to logic 0. However
column17993: if the logic used to determine system-security state (by leveraging the values sensed from the fuses) uses negative logic
column17994: an attacker might blow the fuse and drive the system to an insecure state."
column17996: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider an SoC design that embeds a secret key in read-only memory (ROM). The key is baked into the design logic and may not be modified after fabrication causing the key to be identical for all devices. An attacker in possession of the IC can decapsulate and delayer the device. After imaging the layers
column17997: computer vision algorithms or manual inspection of the circuit features locate the ROM and reveal the value of the key bits as encoded in the visible circuit structure of the ROM.\n"
column17998: name:"Missing Protection Against Hardware Reverse Engineering Using Integrated Circuit (IC) Imaging Techniques"
column18000: description:"Information stored in hardware may be recovered by an attacker with the capability to capture and analyze images of the integrated circuit using techniques such as scanning electron microscopy. The physical structure of a device
column18002: can reveal the information stored inside. Typical steps in IC reverse engineering involve removing the chip packaging (decapsulation) then using various imaging techniques ranging from high resolution x-ray microscopy to invasive techniques involving removing IC layers and imaging each layer using a scanning electron microscope. The goal of such activities is to recover secret keys
column18004: and proprietary code and circuit designs embedded in hardware that the attacker has been unsuccessful at accessing through other means. These secrets may be stored in non-volatile memory or in the circuit netlist. Memory technologies such as masked ROM allow easier to extraction of secrets than One-time Programmable (OTP) memory."
column18006: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThis example illustrates the danger of using the same public key for debug and production.\nSuppose the product design requires frugality of silicon real estate. Assume that originally the architecture allows just enough storage for two 2048-bit RSA keys in the fuse: one to be used for debug and the other for production. However
column18008: a business decision is taken to make the security future-proof beyond 2030
column18009: which means the architecture needs to use the NIST-recommended 3072-bit keys instead of the originally-planned 2048-bit keys. This means that
column18011: one key can be fully stored in the fuses
column18012: not two. So the product design team decides to use the same public key for debug and production.\nIncrease the storage so that two different keys of the required size can be stored.\n"
column18013: name:"Public Key Re-Use for Signing both Debug and Production Code"
column18015: description:"The same public key is used for signing both debug and production code. A common usage of public-key cryptography is to verify the integrity and authenticity of another entity (for example a firmware binary). If a company wants to ensure that its firmware runs only on its own hardware
column18017: an encrypted hash of the firmware image will be decrypted with the public key and then verified against the now-computed hash of the firmware image. This means that the public key forms the root of trust
column18018: which necessitates that the public key itself must be protected and used properly. During the development phase
column18019: debug firmware enables many hardware debug hooks
column18021: and debug messages for testing. Those debug facilities provide significant
column18022: additional views about the firmware's capability and
column18024: additional capability into the chip or SoC. If compromised
column18025: these capabilities could be exploited by an attacker to take full control of the system. Once the product exits the manufacturing stage and enters production
column18026: it is good practice to use a different public key. Debug firmware images are known to leak. With the debug key being reused as the production key
column18027: the debug image will also work on the production image. Thus
column18028: it will open all the internal
column18029: debug capabilities to the attacker. If a different public key is used for the production image
column18030: even if the attacker gains access to the debug firmware image
column18031: they will not be able to run it on a production machine. Thus
column18032: damage will be limited to the intellectual property leakage resulting from the debug image."
column18034: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nSeveral systems on chips (SoCs) use the Advanced-Microcontroller Bus Architecture (AMBA) Advanced-Peripheral Bus (APB) protocol. APB is a simple
column18035: low-power bus and uses the PPROT[2:0] bits to indicate the security state of the bus masters ;PPROT[0] indicates privilege
column18037: and PPROT[2] indicates instruction\/data. Assume that there is no fabric bridge in the SoC. One of the slaves
column18039: contains registers that store the thermal-shutdown limits.\nThe APB bus is used to connect several bus masters
column18040: each with a unique and immutable hardware identity
column18041: to several slaves. For a CPU supporting 8 potential identities (each with varying privilege levels)
column18042: 16 types of outgoing transactions can be made--8 read transactions with each supported privilege level and 8 write transactions with each supported privilege level.\nSince APB PPROT can only support up to 8 transaction types
column18043: access-control checks cannot be performed on transactions going to the slaves at the right granularity for all possible transaction types. Thus
column18045: user code running on the CPU could maliciously corrupt the thermal-shutdown-configuration registers to burn the device
column18046: resulting in permanent denial of service.\nIn this scenario
column18047: only peripherals that need access protection from 8 of the 16 possible transaction types can be connected to the APB bus. Peripherals that require protection from the remaining 8 transaction types can be connected to a different APB bus. Alternatively
column18048: a bridge could be implemented to handle such complex scenarios before forwarding traffic to the APB bus.\nExample 2\nThe Open-Core-Protocol (OCP) fabric supports two configurable
column18049: width-optional signals for transporting security attributes: MReqInfo and SRespInfo. MReqInfo is used to transport security attributes from bus master to slave
column18050: and SRespInfo is used to transport security attributes from slave to bus master. An SoC uses OCP to connect several bus masters
column18051: each with a unique and immutable hardware identity
column18052: to several slaves. One of the bus masters
column18054: reports the privilege level (user or super user) in addition to the unique identity. One of the slaves
column18056: contains registers that store the thermal-shutdown limits.\nSince MReqInfo and SRespInfo are not mandatory
column18057: these signals are not configured when autogenerating RTL for the OCP fabric. Thus
column18058: the fabric cannot be used to transport security attributes from bus masters to slave.\nCode running at user-privilege level on the CPU could maliciously corrupt the thermal-shutdown-configuration registers to burn the device and cause permanent denial of service.\nTo address this
column18059: configure the fabric to include MReqInfo and SRespInfo signals and use these to transport security identity and privilege level to perform access-control checks at the slave interface.\n"
column18060: name:"Missing Support for Security Features in On-chip Fabrics or Buses"
column18062: description:"On-chip fabrics or buses either do not support or are not configured to support privilege separation or other security features
column18063: such as access control. Certain on-chip fabrics and buses
column18065: do not support security features. Apart from data transfer and addressing ports
column18066: some fabrics and buses do not have any interfaces to transfer privilege
column18068: or any other security attribute coming from the bus master. Similarly
column18069: they do not have dedicated signals to transport security-sensitive data from slave to master
column18070: such as completions for certain types of transactions. Few other on-chip fabrics and buses support security features and define specific interfaces\/signals for transporting security attributes from master to slave or vice-versa. However
column18071: including these signals is not mandatory and could be left unconfigured when generating the register-transfer-level (RTL) description for the fabric. Such fabrics or buses should not be used to transport any security attribute coming from the bus master. In general
column18072: peripherals with security assets should not be connected to such buses before the transaction from the bus master reaches the bus
column18073: unless some form of access control is performed at a fabric bridge or another intermediate module."
column18076: security related information is stored in fuses. These fuses are loaded into shadow registers at boot time. Disturbing this transfer phase with EM-FI can lead to the shadow registers storing erroneous values potentially resulting in reduced security.\nColin O'Flynn has demonstrated an attack scenario which uses electro-magnetic glitching during booting to bypass security and gain read access to flash
column18077: read and erase access to shadow memory area (where the private password is stored). Most devices in the MPC55xx and MPC56xx series that include the Boot Assist Module (BAM) (a serial or CAN bootloader mode) are susceptible to this attack. In this paper
column18078: a GM ECU was used as a real life target. While the success rate appears low (less than 2 percent)
column18079: in practice a success can be found within 1-5 minutes once the EMFI tool is setup. In a practical scenario
column18080: the author showed that success can be achieved within 30-60 minutes from a cold start.\n"
column18081: name:"Improper Protection against Electromagnetic Fault Injection (EM-FI)"
column18083: description:"The device is susceptible to electromagnetic fault injection attacks
column18084: causing device internal information to be compromised or security mechanisms to be bypassed. Electromagnetic fault injection may allow an attacker to locally and dynamically modify the signals (both internal and external) of an integrated circuit. EM-FI attacks consist of producing a local
column18085: transient magnetic field near the device
column18086: inducing current in the device wires. A typical EMFI setup is made up of a pulse injection circuit that generates a high current transient in an EMI coil
column18087: producing an abrupt magnetic pulse which couples to the target producing faults in the device
column18088: which can lead to: Bypassing security mechanisms such as secure JTAG or Secure Boot Leaking device information Modifying program flow Perturbing secure hardware modules (e.g. random number generators)"
column18090: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe RoT is stored in memory. This memory can be modified by an adversary. For example
column18091: if an SoC implements \"Secure Boot\" by storing the boot code in an off-chip\/on-chip flash
column18092: the contents of the flash can be modified by using a flash programmer. Similarly
column18093: if the boot code is stored in ROM (Read-Only Memory) but the public key or the hash of the public key (used to enable \"Secure Boot\") is stored in Flash or a memory that is susceptible to modifications or writes
column18096: key materials and data that enable \"Secure Boot\" are all mutable
column18097: the implementation is vulnerable.\nGood architecture defines RoT as immutable in hardware. One of the best ways to achieve immutability is to store boot code
column18098: public key or hash of the public key and other relevant data in Read-Only Memory (ROM) or One-Time Programmable (OTP) memory that prevents further programming or writes.\n"
column18099: name:"Missing Immutable Root of Trust in Hardware"
column18101: description:"A missing immutable root of trust in the hardware results in the ability to bypass secure boot or execute untrusted or adversarial boot code. A System-on-Chip (SoC) implements secure boot by verifying or authenticating signed boot code. The signing of the code is achieved by an entity that the SoC trusts. Before executing the boot code
column18102: the SoC verifies that the code or the public key with which the code has been signed has not been tampered with. The other data upon which the SoC depends are system-hardware settings in fuses such as whether \"Secure Boot is enabled\". These data play a crucial role in establishing a Root of Trust (RoT) to execute secure-boot flows. One of the many ways RoT is achieved is by storing the code and data in memory or fuses. This memory should be immutable
column18104: once the RoT is programmed\/provisioned in memory
column18105: that memory should be locked and prevented from further programming or writes. If the memory contents (i.e.
column18107: then an adversary can modify the RoT to execute their choice of code
column18108: resulting in a compromised secure boot. Note that
column18110: secure patching\/update features should be supported to allow authenticated and authorized updates in the field."
column18112: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nMalicious software running on a core can execute instructions that consume maximum power or increase core frequency. Such a power-virus program could execute on the platform for an extended time to overheat the device
column18113: resulting in permanent damage.\nExecution core and platform do not support thermal sensors
column18115: or platform-cooling countermeasures to ensure that any software executing on the system cannot cause overheating past the maximum allowable temperature.\nThe platform and SoC should have failsafe thermal limits that are enforced by thermal sensors that trigger critical temperature alerts when high temperature is detected. Upon detection of high temperatures
column18116: the platform should trigger cooling or shutdown automatically.\n"
column18119: description:"A hardware device is missing or has inadequate protection features to prevent overheating. Hardware
column18121: and semiconductor silicon have thermal side effects
column18122: such that some of the energy consumed by the device gets dissipated as heat and increases the temperature of the device. For example
column18124: higher-operating frequency of silicon results in higher power dissipation and heat. The leakage current in CMOS circuits increases with temperature
column18125: and this creates positive feedback that can result in thermal runaway and damage the device permanently. Any device lacking protections such as thermal sensors
column18127: or thermal insulation is susceptible to attacks by malicious software that might deliberately operate the device in modes that result in overheating. This can be used as an effective denial of service (DoS) or permanent denial of service (PDoS) attack. Depending on the type of hardware device and its expected usage
column18128: such thermal overheating can also cause safety hazards and reliability issues. Note that battery failures can also cause device overheating but the mitigations and examples included in this submission cannot reliably protect against a battery failure. There can be similar weaknesses with lack of protection from attacks based on overvoltage or overcurrent conditions. However
column18129: thermal heat is generated by hardware operation and the device should implement protection from overheating."

column18355: description:"The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors. Many communication channels can be \"sniffed\" (monitored) by adversaries during data transmission. For example
column18357: packets can traverse many intermediary nodes from the source to the destination
column18361: etc. Some actors might have privileged access to a network interface or any link along the channel
column18363: but they might not be authorized to collect the underlying data. As a result
column18364: network traffic could be sniffed by adversaries
column18365: spilling security-critical data. Applicable communication channels are not limited to software products. Applicable channels include hardware-specific technologies such as internal hardware networks and external debug channels
column18366: supporting remote JTAG debugging. When mitigations are not applied to combat adversaries within the product's threat model
column18367: this weakness significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by such adversaries. When full communications are recorded or logged
column18368: such as with a packet dump
column18369: an adversary could attempt to obtain the dump long after the transmission has occurred and try to \"sniff\" the cleartext from the recorded communications in the dump itself."

column18410: description:"The product uses an algorithm that produces a digest (output value) that does not meet security expectations for a hash function that allows an adversary to reasonably determine the original input (preimage attack)
column18411: find another input that can produce the same hash (2nd preimage attack)
column18412: or find multiple inputs that evaluate to the same hash (birthday attack). A hash function is defined as an algorithm that maps arbitrarily sized data into a fixed-sized digest (output) such that the following properties hold: 1. The algorithm is not invertible (also called \"one-way\" or \"not reversible\") 2. The algorithm is deterministic; the same input produces the same digest every time Building on this definition
column18413: a cryptographic hash function must also ensure that a malicious actor cannot leverage the hash function to have a reasonable chance of success at determining any of the following: 1. the original input (preimage attack)
column18414: given only the digest 2. another input that can produce the same digest (2nd preimage attack)
column18415: given the original input 3. a set of two or more inputs that evaluate to the same digest (birthday attack)
column18416: given the actor can arbitrarily choose the inputs to be hashed and can do so a reasonable amount of times What is regarded as \"reasonable\" varies by context and threat model
column18418: \"reasonable\" could cover any attack that is more efficient than brute force (i.e.
column18420: attempting half of all possible combinations). Note that some attacks might be more efficient than brute force but are still not regarded as achievable in the real world. Any algorithm does not meet the above conditions will generally be considered weak for general use in hashing. In addition to algorithmic weaknesses
column18421: a hash function can be made weak by using the hash in a security context that breaks its security guarantees. For example
column18422: using a hash function without a salt for storing passwords (that are sufficiently short) could enable an adversary to create a \"rainbow table\" [REF-637] to recover the password under certain conditions; this attack works against such hash functions as MD5

thereby defeating the purpose for which the hash was used.

column18438: name:"Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm"
column18449: description:"The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol. Cryptographic algorithms are the methods by which data is scrambled to prevent observation or influence by unauthorized actors. Insecure cryptography can be exploited to expose sensitive information
column18451: spoof identities of other users or devices
column18452: or other impacts. It is very difficult to produce a secure algorithm
column18453: and even high-profile algorithms by accomplished cryptographic experts have been broken. Well-known techniques exist to break or weaken various kinds of cryptography. Accordingly
column18454: there are a small number of well-understood and heavily studied algorithms that should be used by most products. Using a non-standard or known-insecure algorithm is dangerous because a determined adversary may be able to break the algorithm and compromise whatever data has been protected. Since the state of cryptography advances so rapidly
column18455: it is common for an algorithm to be considered \"unsafe\" even if it was once thought to be strong. This can happen when new attacks are discovered
column18456: or if computing power increases so much that the cryptographic algorithm no longer provides the amount of protection that was originally thought. For a number of reasons
column18457: this weakness is even more challenging to manage with hardware deployment of cryptographic algorithms as opposed to software implementation. First
column18458: if a flaw is discovered with hardware-implemented cryptography
column18459: the flaw cannot be fixed in most cases without a recall of the product
column18460: because hardware is not easily replaceable like software. Second
column18461: because the hardware product is expected to work for years
column18462: the adversary's computing power will only increase over time."
column18464: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nRe-using random values may compromise security.\nWhile an LFSR may provide pseudo-random number generation service
column18465: the entropy (measure of randomness) of the resulting output may be less than that of an accepted DRNG (like that used in dev\/urandom). Thus
column18466: using an LFSR weakens the strength of the cryptographic system
column18467: because it may be possible for an attacker to guess the LFSR output and subsequently the encryption key.\n"
column18468: name:"Use of a Cryptographic Primitive with a Risky Implementation"
column18481: description:"To fulfill the need for a cryptographic primitive
column18482: the product implements a cryptographic algorithm using a non-standard
column18484: or disallowed\/non-compliant cryptographic implementation. Cryptographic protocols and systems depend on cryptographic primitives (and associated algorithms) as their basic building blocks. Some common examples of primitives are digital signatures
column18488: the notion of \"primitive\" can vary depending on point of view. See \"Terminology Notes\" for further explanation of some concepts. Cryptographic primitives are defined to accomplish one very specific task in a precisely defined and mathematically reliable fashion. For example
column18489: suppose that for a specific cryptographic primitive (such as an encryption routine)
column18490: the consensus is that the primitive can only be broken after trying out N different inputs (where the larger the value of N
column18491: the stronger the cryptography). For an encryption scheme like AES-256
column18492: one would expect N to be so large as to be infeasible to execute in a reasonable amount of time. If a vulnerability is ever found that shows that one can break a cryptographic primitive in significantly less than the expected number of attempts
column18493: then that primitive is considered weakened (or sometimes in extreme cases
column18494: colloquially it is \"broken\"). As a result
column18495: anything using this cryptographic primitive would now be considered insecure or risky. Thus
column18496: even breaking or weakening a seemingly small cryptographic primitive has the potential to render the whole system vulnerable
column18497: due to its reliance on the primitive. A historical example can be found in TLS when using DES. One would colloquially call DES the cryptographic primitive for transport encryption in this version of TLS. In the past
column18499: because no weaknesses were found in it; importantly
column18500: DES has a key length of 56 bits. Trying N=2^56 keys was considered impractical for most actors. Unfortunately
column18501: attacking a system with 56-bit keys is now practical via brute force
column18502: which makes defeating DES encryption practical. It is now practical for an adversary to read any information sent under this version of TLS and use this information to attack the system. As a result
column18503: it can be claimed that this use of TLS is weak
column18504: and that any system depending on TLS with DES could potentially render the entire system vulnerable to attack. Cryptographic primitives and associated algorithms are only considered safe after extensive research and review from experienced cryptographers from academia
column18506: and government entities looking for any possible flaws. Furthermore
column18507: cryptographic primitives and associated algorithms are frequently reevaluated for safety when new mathematical and attack techniques are discovered. As a result and over time
column18508: even well-known cryptographic primitives can lose their compliance status with the discovery of novel attacks that might either defeat the algorithm or reduce its robustness significantly. If ad-hoc cryptographic primitives are implemented
column18509: it is almost certain that the implementation will be vulnerable to attacks that are well understood by cryptographers
column18510: resulting in the exposure of sensitive information and other consequences. This weakness is even more difficult to manage for hardware-implemented deployment of cryptographic algorithms. First
column18511: because hardware is not patchable as easily as software

column18538: description:"The product uses an algorithm that produces a digest (output value) that does not meet security expectations for a hash function that allows an adversary to reasonably determine the original input (preimage attack)
column18539: find another input that can produce the same hash (2nd preimage attack)
column18540: or find multiple inputs that evaluate to the same hash (birthday attack). A hash function is defined as an algorithm that maps arbitrarily sized data into a fixed-sized digest (output) such that the following properties hold: 1. The algorithm is not invertible (also called \"one-way\" or \"not reversible\") 2. The algorithm is deterministic; the same input produces the same digest every time Building on this definition
column18541: a cryptographic hash function must also ensure that a malicious actor cannot leverage the hash function to have a reasonable chance of success at determining any of the following: 1. the original input (preimage attack)
column18542: given only the digest 2. another input that can produce the same digest (2nd preimage attack)
column18543: given the original input 3. a set of two or more inputs that evaluate to the same digest (birthday attack)
column18544: given the actor can arbitrarily choose the inputs to be hashed and can do so a reasonable amount of times What is regarded as \"reasonable\" varies by context and threat model
column18546: \"reasonable\" could cover any attack that is more efficient than brute force (i.e.
column18548: attempting half of all possible combinations). Note that some attacks might be more efficient than brute force but are still not regarded as achievable in the real world. Any algorithm does not meet the above conditions will generally be considered weak for general use in hashing. In addition to algorithmic weaknesses
column18549: a hash function can be made weak by using the hash in a security context that breaks its security guarantees. For example
column18550: using a hash function without a salt for storing passwords (that are sufficiently short) could enable an adversary to create a \"rainbow table\" [REF-637] to recover the password under certain conditions; this attack works against such hash functions as MD5

column18562: name:"Use of Password Hash With Insufficient Computational Effort"
column18569: description:"The product generates a hash for a password
column18570: but it uses a scheme that does not provide a sufficient level of computational effort that would make password cracking attacks infeasible or expensive. Many password storage mechanisms compute a hash and store the hash
column18571: instead of storing the original password in plaintext. In this design
column18572: authentication involves accepting an incoming password
column18574: and comparing it to the stored hash. Many hash algorithms are designed to execute quickly with minimal overhead
column18576: this efficiency is a problem for password storage
column18577: because it can reduce an attacker's workload for brute-force password cracking. If an attacker can obtain the hashes through some other method (such as SQL injection on a database that stores hashes)
column18578: then the attacker can store the hashes offline and use various techniques to crack the passwords by computing hashes efficiently. Without a built-in workload
column18579: modern attacks can compute large numbers of hashes
column18580: or even exhaust the entire space of all possible passwords
column18581: within a very short amount of time
column18582: using massively-parallel computing (such as cloud computing) and GPU
column18584: or FPGA hardware. In such a scenario
column18585: an efficient hash algorithm helps the attacker. There are several properties of a hash scheme that are relevant to its strength against an offline
column18586: massively-parallel attack: The amount of CPU time required to compute the hash (\"stretching\") The amount of memory required to compute the hash (\"memory-hard\" operations) Including a random value
column18588: as input to the hash computation (\"salting\") Given a hash
column18589: there is no known way of determining an input (e.g.
column18590: a password) that produces this hash value
column18591: other than by guessing possible inputs (\"one-way\" hashing) Relative to the number of all possible hashes that can be generated by the scheme
column18592: there is a low likelihood of producing the same hash for multiple different inputs (\"collision resistance\") Note that the security requirements for the product may vary depending on the environment and the value of the passwords. Different schemes might not provide all of these properties
column18593: yet may still provide sufficient security for the environment. Conversely
column18594: a solution might be very strong in preserving one property
column18595: which still being very weak for an attack against another property
column18596: or it might not be able to significantly reduce the efficiency of a massively-parallel attack."

CBC mode eliminates a weakness of Electronic Code Book (ECB) mode by allowing identical plaintext blocks to be encrypted to different ciphertext blocks. This is possible by the XOR-ing of an IV with the initial plaintext block so that every plaintext block in the chain is XOR'd with a different value before encryption. If IVs are reused
column18701: then identical plaintexts would be encrypted to identical ciphertexts. However

column18703: then they still break the security of CBC mode against Chosen Plaintext Attacks (CPA)."

{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
This code uses a TRNG to generate a unique session id for new connections to a server:
This code does not attempt to limit the number of new connections or make sure the TRNG can successfully generate a new random number. An attacker may be able to create many new connections and exhaust the entropy of the TRNG. The TRNG may then block and cause the program to crash or hang.

column18724: name:"Improper Handling of Insufficient Entropy in TRNG"
column18726: description:"True random number generators (TRNG) generally have a limited source of entropy and therefore can fail or block. The rate at which true random numbers can be generated is limited. It is important that one uses them only when they are needed for security."
column18728:
{"exampleDescription":"Example 1
The following XML example code is a deployment descriptor for a Java web application deployed on a Sun Java Application Server. This deployment descriptor includes a session configuration property for configuring the session ID length.
This deployment descriptor has set the session ID length for this Java web application to 8 bytes (or 64 bits). The session ID length for Java web applications should be set to 16 bytes (128 bits) to prevent attackers from guessing and/or stealing a session ID and taking over a user's session.
Note for most application servers including the Sun Java Application Server the session ID length is by default set to 128 bits and should not be changed. And for many application servers the session ID length cannot be changed from this default setting. Check your application server documentation for the session ID length default setting and configuration options to ensure that the session ID length is set to 128 bits.
"

column18745: name:"Incorrect Usage of Seeds in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)"
column18750: description:"The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) but does not correctly manage seeds. PRNGs are deterministic and
column18752: they cannot actually create entropy. They rely on cryptographically secure and unique seeds for entropy so proper seeding is critical to the secure operation of the PRNG. Management of seeds could be broken down into two main areas: (1) protecting seeds as cryptographic material (such as a cryptographic key); (2) whenever possible
column18753: using a uniquely generated seed from a cryptographically secure source PRNGs require a seed as input to generate a stream of numbers that are functionally indistinguishable from random numbers. While the output is
column18756: the output of any PRNG is directly determined by the seed provided as input. If the seed can be ascertained by a third party
column18757: the entire output of the PRNG can be made known to them. As such
column18758: the seed should be kept secret and should ideally not be able to be guessed. For example
column18759: the current time may be a poor seed. Knowing the approximate time the PRNG was seeded greatly reduces the possible key space. Seeds do not necessarily need to be unique
column18760: but reusing seeds may open up attacks if the seed is discovered."

column18768: name:"Same Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)"
column18770: description:"A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses the same seed each time the product is initialized. Given the deterministic nature of PRNGs
column18771: using the same seed for each initialization will lead to the same output in the same order. If an attacker can guess (or knows) the seed
column18772: then the attacker may be able to determine the random numbers that will be produced from the PRNG."

column18776: name:"Predictable Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)"
column18782: description:"A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) is initialized from a predictable seed

column18791: description:"A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses a relatively small seed space
column18792: which makes it more susceptible to brute force attacks. PRNGs are entirely deterministic once seeded
column18793: so it should be extremely difficult to guess the seed. If an attacker can collect the outputs of a PRNG and then brute force the seed by trying every possibility to see which seed matches the observed output
column18794: then the attacker will know the output of any subsequent calls to the PRNG. A small seed space implies that the attacker will have far fewer possible values to try to exhaust all possibilities."

Sometimes a mediocre source of randomness is sufficient or preferable for algorithms that use random numbers. Weak generators generally take less processing power and\/or do not use the precious

column18829: name:"Predictable Exact Value from Previous Values"
column18834: description:"An exact value or random number can be precisely predicted by observing previous values. "
column18837: name:"Predictable Value Range from Previous Values"
column18839: description:"The product's random number generator produces a series of values which
column18841: can be used to infer a relatively small range of possibilities for the next value that could be generated. The output of a random number generator should not be predictable based on observations of previous values. In some cases
column18842: an attacker cannot predict the exact value that will be produced next
column18843: but can narrow down the possibilities significantly. This reduces the amount of effort to perform a brute force attack. For example
column18844: suppose the product generates random numbers between 1 and 100
column18845: but it always produces a larger value until it reaches 100. If the generator produces an 80
column18846: then the attacker knows that the next value will be somewhere between 81 and 100. Instead of 100 possibilities
column18847: the attacker only needs to consider 20."

Any user of that program may be able to extract the password. Client-side systems with hard-coded passwords pose even more of a threat

column19106: description:"The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission
column19107: such as a checksum. If integrity check values or \"checksums\" are omitted from a protocol
column19108: there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications
column19109: the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum

column19114: name:"Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value"
column19116: description:"The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or \"checksums\" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences."

column19326: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider the following SoC design. The Hardware Root of Trust (HRoT) local SRAM is memory mapped in the core{0-N} address space. The HRoT allows or disallows access to private memory ranges
column19327: thus allowing the sram to function as a mailbox for communication between untrusted and trusted HRoT partitions.\n\nWe assume that the threat is from malicious software in the untrusted domain. column19329: name:"Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-a-Chip (SoC)"
column19331: description:"The System-On-a-Chip (SoC) does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents. A System-On-a-Chip (SoC) has a lot of functionality
column19332: but it may have a limited number of pins or pads. A pin can only perform one function at a time. However
column19333: it can be configured to perform multiple different functions. This technique is called pin multiplexing. Similarly
column19334: several resources on the chip may be shared to multiplex and support different features or functions. When such resources are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column19335: untrusted agents may be able to access the assets intended to be accessed only by the trusted agents."
column19337: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nOn some processors the hardware indirect branch predictor is shared between execution contexts
column19339: between sibling SMT threads. When SMT thread A executes an indirect branch to a target address X
column19340: this target may be temporarily stored by the indirect branch predictor. A subsequent indirect branch mis-prediction for SMT thread B could speculatively execute instructions at X (or at a location in B's address space that partially aliases X). Even though the processor rolls back the architectural effects of the mis-predicted indirect branch
column19341: the memory accesses alter data cache state
column19342: which is not rolled back after the indirect branch is resolved.\n"
column19345: description:"Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g.
column19346: caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts. Modern processors use techniques such as out-of-order execution
column19350: and caching to increase performance. Details about the implementation of these techniques are hidden from the programmer's view. This is problematic when the hardware implementation of these techniques results in resources being shared across supposedly isolated contexts. Contention for shared resources between different contexts opens covert channels that allow malicious programs executing in one context to recover information from another context. Some examples of shared micro-architectural resources that have been used to leak information between contexts are caches
column19352: and load or store buffers. Speculative and out-of-order execution provides an attacker with increased control over which data is leaked through the covert channel. If the extent of resource sharing between contexts in the design microarchitecture is undocumented
column19353: it is extremely difficult to ensure system assets are protected against disclosure."
column19355: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a NoC that implements a one-dimensional mesh network with four nodes. This supports two flows: Flow A from node 0 to node 3 (via node 1 and node 2) and Flow B from node 1 to node 2. Flows A and B share a common link between Node 1 and Node 2. Only one flow can use the link in each cycle.\nOne of the masters to this NoC implements a cryptographic algorithm (RSA)
column19356: and another master to the NoC is a core that can be exercised by an attacker. The RSA algorithm performs a modulo multiplication of two large numbers and depends on each bit of the secret key. The algorithm examines each bit in the secret key and only performs multiplication if the bit is 1. This algorithm is known to be prone to timing attacks. Whenever RSA performs multiplication
column19357: there is additional network traffic to the memory controller. One of the reasons for this is cache conflicts.\nSince this is a one-dimensional mesh
column19358: only one flow can use the link in each cycle. Also
column19359: packets from the attack program and the RSA program share the output port of the network-on-chip. This contention results in network interference
column19360: and the throughput and latency of one flow can be affected by the other flow's demand.\nThere may be different ways to fix this particular weakness.\n"
column19361: name:"Improper Isolation of Shared Resources in Network On Chip (NoC)"
column19363: description:"The Network On Chip (NoC) does not isolate or incorrectly isolates its on-chip-fabric and internal resources such that they are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column19365: network on chips (NoC) have many internal resources that are shared between packets from different trust domains. These resources include internal buffers
column19368: and channels. The sharing of resources causes contention and introduces interference between differently trusted domains
column19369: which poses a security threat via a timing channel
column19370: allowing attackers to infer data that belongs to a trusted agent. This may also result in introducing network interference
column19371: resulting in degraded throughput and latency."

column19799: name:"Automated Recognition Mechanism with Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations"
column19801: description:"The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category
column19802: but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different
column19803: incorrect concept. When techniques such as machine learning are used to automatically classify input streams
column19804: and those classifications are used for security-critical decisions
column19805: then any mistake in classification can introduce a vulnerability that allows attackers to cause the product to make the wrong security decision. If the automated mechanism is not developed or \"trained\" with enough input data
column19806: then attackers may be able to craft malicious input that intentionally triggers the incorrect classification. Targeted technologies include
column19807: but are not necessarily limited to: automated speech recognition automated image recognition For example
column19808: an attacker might modify road signs or road surface markings to trick autonomous vehicles into misreading the sign\/marking and performing a dangerous action."
column19811: name:"Floating Point Comparison with Incorrect Operator"
column19813: description:"The code performs a comparison such as an equality test between two float (floating point) values
column19814: but it uses comparison operators that do not account for the possibility of loss of precision. Numeric calculation using floating point values can generate imprecise results because of rounding errors. As a result
column19815: two different calculations might generate numbers that are mathematically equal
column19816: but have slightly different bit representations that do not translate to the same mathematically-equal values. As a result
column19817: an equality test or other comparison might produce unexpected results. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column19818: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability."

column19862: such as cookies that may include session information

column19918: name:"Object Model Violation: Just One of Equals and Hashcode Defined"
column19920: description:"The product does not maintain equal hashcodes for equal objects. Java objects are expected to obey a number of invariants related to equality. One of these invariants is that equal objects must have equal hashcodes. In other words
column19921: if a.equals(b) == true then a.hashCode() == b.hashCode()."

column19928: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nBelow is a representative snippet of C code that is part of the secure-boot flow. A signature of the runtime-firmware image is calculated and compared against a golden value. If the signatures match
column19929: the bootloader loads runtime firmware. If there is no match

column19934: name:"Improper Protection Against Voltage and Clock Glitches"
column19936: description:"The device does not contain or contains incorrectly implemented circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate voltage and clock glitches and protect sensitive information or software contained on the device. A device might support features such as secure boot which are supplemented with hardware and firmware support. This involves establishing a chain of trust
column19937: starting with an immutable root of trust by checking the signature of the next stage (culminating with the OS and runtime software) against a golden value before transferring control. The intermediate stages typically set up the system in a secure state by configuring several access control settings. Similarly
column19938: security logic for exercising a debug or testing interface may be implemented in hardware
column19940: or both. A device needs to guard against fault attacks such as voltage glitches and clock glitches that an attacker may employ in an attempt to compromise the system."

column19950: name:"Improper Handling of Single Event Upsets"
column19952: description:"The hardware logic does not effectively handle when single-event upsets (SEUs) occur. Technology trends such as CMOS-transistor down-sizing
column19954: and system-on-chip architectures continue to increase the sensitivity of systems to soft errors. These errors are random
column19955: and their causes might be internal (e.g.
column19957: cosmic radiation). These soft errors are not permanent in nature and cause temporary bit flips known as single-event upsets (SEUs). SEUs are induced errors in circuits caused when charged particles lose energy by ionizing the medium through which they pass
column19958: leaving behind a wake of electron-hole pairs that cause temporary failures. If these failures occur in security-sensitive modules in a chip
column19959: it might compromise the security guarantees of the chip. For instance
column19960: these temporary failures could be bit flips that change the privilege of a regular user to root."

column19963: name:"Improper Handling of Faults that Lead to Instruction Skips"
column19965: description:"The device is missing or incorrectly implements circuitry or sensors that detect and mitigate the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions when they occur. The operating conditions of hardware may change in ways that cause unexpected behavior to occur
column19966: including the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions. Generally
column19967: this can occur due to electrical disturbances or when the device operates outside of its expected conditions. In practice
column19968: application code may contain conditional branches that are security-sensitive (e.g.
column19969: accepting or rejecting a user-provided password). These conditional branches are typically implemented by a single conditional branch instruction in the program binary which
column19971: may lead to effectively flipping the branch condition - i.e.
column19972: causing the wrong security-sensitive branch to be taken. This affects processes such as firmware authentication
column19974: and other security-sensitive decision points. Attackers can use fault injection techniques to alter the operating conditions of hardware so that security-critical instructions are skipped more frequently or more reliably than they would in a \"natural\" setting."
column19977: name:"Improper Handling of Hardware Behavior in Exceptionally Cold Environments"
column19980: or the firmware running on it
column19981: is missing or has incorrect protection features to maintain goals of security primitives when the device is cooled below standard operating temperatures. The hardware designer may improperly anticipate hardware behavior when exposed to exceptionally cold conditions. As a result they may introduce a weakness by not accounting for the modified behavior of critical components when in extreme environments. An example of a change in behavior is that power loss won't clear\/reset any volatile state when cooled below standard operating temperatures. This may result in a weakness when the starting state of the volatile memory is being relied upon for a security decision. For example
column19982: a Physical Unclonable Function (PUF) may be supplied as a security primitive to improve confidentiality
column19985: when the PUF is paired with DRAM
column19987: or another temperature sensitive entropy source
column19988: the system designer may introduce weakness by failing to account for the chosen entropy source's behavior at exceptionally low temperatures. In the case of DRAM and SRAM
column19989: when power is cycled at low temperatures
column19990: the device will not contain the bitwise biasing caused by inconsistencies in manufacturing and will instead contain the data from previous boot. Should the PUF primitive be used in a cryptographic construction which does not account for full adversary control of PUF seed data
column19991: weakness would arise. This weakness does not cover \"Cold Boot Attacks\" wherein RAM or other external storage is super cooled and read externally by an attacker."

column20354: name:"Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value"
column20356: description:"The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or \"checksums\" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences."

column20650: or canonicalization preventing the input\/output from being directly provided by an attacker (e.g. \"indirect selection\" that maps externally-provided values to internally-controlled values) preventing the input\/output from being processed at all This weakness typically applies in cases where the product prepares a control message that another process must act on

column20680: name:"Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output"
column20688: description:"The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component
column20689: but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result
column20690: the intended structure of the message is not preserved. Improper encoding or escaping can allow attackers to change the commands that are sent to another component
column20691: inserting malicious commands instead. Most products follow a certain protocol that uses structured messages for communication between components
column20692: such as queries or commands. These structured messages can contain raw data interspersed with metadata or control information. For example
column20693: \"GET \/index.html HTTP\/1.1\" is a structured message containing a command (\"GET\") with a single argument (\"\/index.html\") and metadata about which protocol version is being used (\"HTTP\/1.1\"). If an application uses attacker-supplied inputs to construct a structured message without properly encoding or escaping
column20694: then the attacker could insert special characters that will cause the data to be interpreted as control information or metadata. Consequently
column20695: the component that receives the output will perform the wrong operations
column20696: or otherwise interpret the data incorrectly."

column21317: description:"The product receives input or data
column21318: but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly. Input validation is a frequently-used technique for checking potentially dangerous inputs in order to ensure that the inputs are safe for processing within the code
column21319: or when communicating with other components. When software does not validate input properly
column21320: an attacker is able to craft the input in a form that is not expected by the rest of the application. This will lead to parts of the system receiving unintended input
column21321: which may result in altered control flow
column21323: or arbitrary code execution. Input validation is not the only technique for processing input
column21324: however. Other techniques attempt to transform potentially-dangerous input into something safe
column21325: such as filtering (CWE-790) - which attempts to remove dangerous inputs - or encoding\/escaping (CWE-116)
column21326: which attempts to ensure that the input is not misinterpreted when it is included in output to another component. Other techniques exist as well (see CWE-138 for more examples.) Input validation can be applied to: raw data - strings
column21330: etc. metadata - information about the raw data
column21331: such as headers or size Data can be simple or structured. Structured data can be composed of many nested layers
column21332: composed of combinations of metadata and raw data
column21333: with other simple or structured data. Many properties of raw data or metadata may need to be validated upon entry into the code
column21334: such as: specified quantities such as size
column21342: such as the actual size of a file instead of a specified size indexes
column21344: or positions into more complex data structures symbolic keys or other elements into hash tables
column21347: i.e. syntactic correctness - compliance with expected syntax lexical token correctness - compliance with rules for what is treated as a token specified or derived type - the actual type of the input (or what the input appears to be) consistency - between individual data elements
column21351: e.g. business logic equivalence - ensuring that equivalent inputs are treated the same authenticity
column21353: or other attestations about the input
column21354: e.g. a cryptographic signature to prove the source of the data Implied or derived properties of data must often be calculated or inferred by the code itself. Errors in deriving properties may be considered a contributing factor to improper input validation. Note that \"input validation\" has very different meanings to different people
column21355: or within different classification schemes. Caution must be used when referencing this CWE entry or mapping to it. For example
column21356: some weaknesses might involve inadvertently giving control to an attacker over an input when they should not be able to provide an input at all
column21357: but sometimes this is referred to as input validation. Finally
column21358: it is important to emphasize that the distinctions between input validation and output escaping are often blurred
column21359: and developers must be careful to understand the difference
column21360: including how input validation is not always sufficient to prevent vulnerabilities
column21361: especially when less stringent data types must be supported
column21362: such as free-form text. Consider a SQL injection scenario in which a person's last name is inserted into a query. The name \"O'Reilly\" would likely pass the validation step since it is a common last name in the English language. However
column21363: this valid name cannot be directly inserted into the database because it contains the \"'\" apostrophe character
column21364: which would need to be escaped or otherwise transformed. In this case
column21365: removing the apostrophe might reduce the risk of SQL injection
column21366: but it would produce incorrect behavior because the wrong name would be recorded."
column21373: an input validation framework that is provided by the source language or an independent library. Many modern coding languages provide developers with input validation frameworks to make the task of input validation easier and less error-prone. These frameworks will automatically check all input against specified criteria and direct execution to error handlers when invalid input is received. The improper use (i.e.
column21374: an incorrect implementation or missing altogether) of these frameworks is not directly exploitable
column21375: but can lead to an exploitable condition if proper input validation is not performed later in the product. Not using provided input validation frameworks can also hurt the maintainability of code as future developers may not recognize the downstream input validation being used in the place of the validation framework."

column21513: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following example retrieves the sizes of messages for a pop3 mail server. The message sizes are retrieved from a socket that returns in a buffer the message number and the message size
column21514:
the message number (num) and size (size) are extracted from the buffer and the message size is placed into an array using the message number for the array index.
In this example the message number retrieved from the buffer could be a value that is outside the allowable range of indices for the array and could possibly be a negative number. Without proper validation of the value to be used for the array index an array overflow could occur and could potentially lead to unauthorized access to memory addresses and system crashes. The value of the array index should be validated to ensure that it is within the allowable range of indices for the array as in the following code.
Example 2
In the following example the method displayProductSummary is called from a Web service servlet to retrieve product summary information for display to the user. The servlet obtains the integer value of the product number from the user and passes it to the displayProductSummary method. The displayProductSummary method passes the integer value of the product number to the getProductSummary method which obtains the product summary from the array object containing the project summaries using the integer value of the product number as the array index.
In this example the integer value used as the array index that is provided by the user may be outside the allowable range of indices for the array which may provide unexpected results or cause the application to fail. The integer value used for the array index should be validated to ensure that it is within the allowable range of indices for the array as in the following code.
An alternative in Java would be to use one of the collection objects such as ArrayList that will automatically generate an exception if an attempt is made to access an array index that is out of bounds.

This example code intends to take the name of a user and list the contents of that user's home directory. It is subject to the first variant of OS command injection.
The $userName variable is not checked for malicious input. An attacker could set the $userName variable to an arbitrary OS command such as:
Which would result in $command being:
Since the semi-colon is a command separator in Unix
column21877: the OS would first execute the ls command
column21879:
deleting the entire file system.
Also note that this example code is vulnerable to Path Traversal (CWE-22) and Untrusted Search Path (CWE-426) attacks.
Example 2
Consider the following program. It intends to perform an "ls -l" on an input filename. The validate_name() subroutine performs validation on the input to make sure that only alphanumeric and "-" characters are allowed
column21880: which avoids path traversal (CWE-22) and OS command injection (CWE-78) weaknesses. Only filenames like \"abc\" or \"d-e-f\" are intended to be allowed.\n\nHowever
column21881: validate_name() alows filenames that begin with a \"-\". An adversary could supply a filename like \"-aR\"
column21883: thereby getting a full recursive listing of the entire directory and all of its sub-directories.\nThere are a couple possible mitigations for this weakness. One would be to refactor the code to avoid using system() altogether
column21884: instead relying on internal functions.\nAnother option could be to add a \"--\" argument to the ls command
column21886: so that any remaining arguments are treated as filenames
column21887: causing any leading \"-\" to be treated as part of a filename instead of another option.\nAnother fix might be to change the regular expression used in validate_name to force the first character of the filename to be a letter or number
column21889: name:"Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component ('Injection')"
column21895: description:"The product constructs all or part of a command
column21897: or record using externally-influenced input from an upstream component
column21898: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify how it is parsed or interpreted when it is sent to a downstream component. Software or other automated logic has certain assumptions about what constitutes data and control respectively. It is the lack of verification of these assumptions for user-controlled input that leads to injection problems. Injection problems encompass a wide variety of issues -- all mitigated in very different ways and usually attempted in order to alter the control flow of the process. For this reason
column21899: the most effective way to discuss these weaknesses is to note the distinct features that classify them as injection weaknesses. The most important issue to note is that all injection problems share one thing in common -- i.e.
column21900: they allow for the injection of control plane data into the user-controlled data plane. This means that the execution of the process may be altered by sending code in through legitimate data channels
column21901: using no other mechanism. While buffer overflows
column21903: involve the use of some further issue to gain execution
column21904: injection problems need only for the data to be parsed."

column21934: description:"The product correctly neutralizes certain special elements
column21935: but it improperly neutralizes equivalent special elements. The product may have a fixed list of special characters it believes is complete. However
column21937: or representations that also have the same meaning. For example
column21938: the product may filter out a leading slash (\/) to prevent absolute path names
column21939: but does not account for a tilde (~) followed by a user name
column21940: which on some *nix systems could be expanded to an absolute pathname. Alternately
column21941: the product might filter a dangerous \"-e\" command-line switch when calling an external program
column21942: but it might not account for \"--exec\" or other switches that have the same semantics."
column21944: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe following simple program accepts a filename as a command line argument and displays the contents of the file back to the user. The program is installed setuid root because it is intended for use as a learning tool to allow system administrators in-training to inspect privileged system files without giving them the ability to modify them or damage the system.\nBecause the program runs with root privileges
column21945: the call to system() also executes with root privileges. If a user specifies a standard filename
column21946: the call works as expected. However
column21947: if an attacker passes a string of the form \";rm -rf \/\"
column21948: then the call to system() fails to execute cat due to a lack of arguments and then plows on to recursively delete the contents of the root partition.\nNote that if argv[1] is a very long argument
column21949: then this issue might also be subject to a buffer overflow (CWE-120).\nExample 2\nThe following code is from an administrative web application designed to allow users to kick off a backup of an Oracle database using a batch-file wrapper around the rman utility and then run a cleanup.bat script to delete some temporary files. The script rmanDB.bat accepts a single command line parameter
column21950: which specifies what type of backup to perform. Because access to the database is restricted
column21951: the application runs the backup as a privileged user.\nThe problem here is that the program does not do any validation on the backuptype parameter read from the user. Typically the Runtime.exec() function will not execute multiple commands
column21952: but in this case the program first runs the cmd.exe shell in order to run multiple commands with a single call to Runtime.exec(). Once the shell is invoked
column21953: it will happily execute multiple commands separated by two ampersands. If an attacker passes a string of the form \"& del c:\\\\dbms\\\\*.*\"
column21954: then the application will execute this command along with the others specified by the program. Because of the nature of the application
column21955: it runs with the privileges necessary to interact with the database

which means whatever command the attacker injects will run with those privileges as well.
Example 3

The code above allows an attacker to execute arbitrary commands with the elevated privilege of the application by modifying the system property APPHOME to point to a different path containing a malicious version of INITCMD. Because the program does not validate the value read from the environment

then they can fool the application into running malicious code and take control of the system.

Used normally

column21963: name:"Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection')"
column21972: description:"The product constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component
column21973: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component. Command injection vulnerabilities typically occur when: 1. Data enters the application from an untrusted source. 2. The data is part of a string that is executed as a command by the application. 3. By executing the command
column21974: the application gives an attacker a privilege or capability that the attacker would not otherwise have. Many protocols and products have their own custom command language. While OS or shell command strings are frequently discovered and targeted
column21975: developers may not realize that these other command languages might also be vulnerable to attacks. Command injection is a common problem with wrapper programs."

column22000: name:"Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')"
column22014: description:"The product constructs all or part of an OS command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component
column22015: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended OS command when it is sent to a downstream component. This could allow attackers to execute unexpected
column22016: dangerous commands directly on the operating system. This weakness can lead to a vulnerability in environments in which the attacker does not have direct access to the operating system
column22017: such as in web applications. Alternately
column22018: if the weakness occurs in a privileged program
column22019: it could allow the attacker to specify commands that normally would not be accessible
column22020: or to call alternate commands with privileges that the attacker does not have. The problem is exacerbated if the compromised process does not follow the principle of least privilege
column22021: because the attacker-controlled commands may run with special system privileges that increases the amount of damage. There are at least two subtypes of OS command injection: The application intends to execute a single
column22022: fixed program that is under its own control. It intends to use externally-supplied inputs as arguments to that program. For example
column22023: the program might use system(\"nslookup [HOSTNAME]\") to run nslookup and allow the user to supply a HOSTNAME
column22024: which is used as an argument. Attackers cannot prevent nslookup from executing. However
column22025: if the program does not remove command separators from the HOSTNAME argument
column22026: attackers could place the separators into the arguments
column22027: which allows them to execute their own program after nslookup has finished executing. The application accepts an input that it uses to fully select which program to run
column22028: as well as which commands to use. The application simply redirects this entire command to the operating system. For example
column22029: the program might use \"exec([COMMAND])\" to execute the [COMMAND] that was supplied by the user. If the COMMAND is under attacker control
column22030: then the attacker can execute arbitrary commands or programs. If the command is being executed using functions like exec() and CreateProcess()
column22031: the attacker might not be able to combine multiple commands together in the same line. From a weakness standpoint
column22032: these variants represent distinct programmer errors. In the first variant
column22033: the programmer clearly intends that input from untrusted parties will be part of the arguments in the command to be executed. In the second variant
column22034: the programmer does not intend for the command to be accessible to any untrusted party
column22035: but the programmer probably has not accounted for alternate ways in which malicious attackers can provide input."
column22037: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider the following program. It intends to perform an \"ls -l\" on an input filename. The validate_name() subroutine performs validation on the input to make sure that only alphanumeric and \"-\" characters are allowed
column22038: which avoids path traversal (CWE-22) and OS command injection (CWE-78) weaknesses. Only filenames like \"abc\" or \"d-e-f\" are intended to be allowed.\n\nHowever
column22039: validate_name() allows filenames that begin with a \"-\". An adversary could supply a filename like \"-aR\"
column22041: thereby getting a full recursive listing of the entire directory and all of its sub-directories.\nThere are a couple possible mitigations for this weakness. One would be to refactor the code to avoid using system() altogether
column22042: instead relying on internal functions.\nAnother option could be to add a \"--\" argument to the ls command
column22044: so that any remaining arguments are treated as filenames
column22045: causing any leading \"-\" to be treated as part of a filename instead of another option.\nAnother fix might be to change the regular expression used in validate_name to force the first character of the filename to be a letter or number
column22046:
such as:

Example 2
CVE-2016-10033 / [REF-1249] provides a useful real-world example of this weakness within PHPMailer.
The program calls PHP's mail() function to compose and send mail. The fifth argument to mail() is a set of parameters. The program intends to provide a "-fSENDER" parameter
column22047: where SENDER is expected to be a well-formed email address. The program has already validated the e-mail address before invoking mail()
column22048: but there is a lot of flexibility in what constitutes a well-formed email address
column22049: including whitespace. With some additional allowed characters to perform some escaping
column22050: the adversary can specify an additional \"-o\" argument (listing an output file) and a \"-X\" argument (giving a program to execute). Additional details for this kind of exploit are in [REF-1250].\n"
column22051: name:"Improper Neutralization of Argument Delimiters in a Command ('Argument Injection')"
column22076: description:"The product constructs a string for a command to executed by a separate component in another control sphere
column22077: but it does not properly delimit the intended arguments
column22079: or switches within that command string. When creating commands using interpolation into a string
column22080: developers may assume that only the arguments\/options that they specify will be processed. This assumption may be even stronger when the programmer has encoded the command in a way that prevents separate commands from being provided maliciously
column22081: e.g. in the case of shell metacharacters. When constructing the command
column22082: the developer may use whitespace or other delimiters that are required to separate arguments when the command. However
column22083: if an attacker can provide an untrusted input that contains argument-separating delimiters
column22084: then the resulting command will have more arguments than intended by the developer. The attacker may then be able to change the behavior of the command. Depending on the functionality supported by the extraneous arguments
column22088: name:"Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an Expression Language Statement ('Expression Language Injection')"
column22090: description:"The product constructs all or part of an expression language (EL) statement in a framework such as a Java Server Page (JSP) using externally-influenced input from an upstream component
column22091: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended EL statement before it is executed. Frameworks such as Java Server Page (JSP) allow a developer to insert executable expressions within otherwise-static content. When the developer is not aware of the executable nature of these expressions and\/or does not disable them
column22092: then if an attacker can inject expressions
column22093: this could lead to code execution or other unexpected behaviors."
