column22119: name:"Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')"
column22138: description:"The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users. Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities occur when: Untrusted data enters a web application
column22139: typically from a web request. The web application dynamically generates a web page that contains this untrusted data. During page generation
column22140: the application does not prevent the data from containing content that is executable by a web browser
column22147: etc. A victim visits the generated web page through a web browser
column22148: which contains malicious script that was injected using the untrusted data. Since the script comes from a web page that was sent by the web server
column22149: the victim's web browser executes the malicious script in the context of the web server's domain. This effectively violates the intention of the web browser's same-origin policy
column22150: which states that scripts in one domain should not be able to access resources or run code in a different domain. There are three main kinds of XSS: Type 1: Reflected XSS (or Non-Persistent) - The server reads data directly from the HTTP request and reflects it back in the HTTP response. Reflected XSS exploits occur when an attacker causes a victim to supply dangerous content to a vulnerable web application
column22151: which is then reflected back to the victim and executed by the web browser. The most common mechanism for delivering malicious content is to include it as a parameter in a URL that is posted publicly or e-mailed directly to the victim. URLs constructed in this manner constitute the core of many phishing schemes
column22152: whereby an attacker convinces a victim to visit a URL that refers to a vulnerable site. After the site reflects the attacker's content back to the victim
column22153: the content is executed by the victim's browser. Type 2: Stored XSS (or Persistent) - The application stores dangerous data in a database
column22156: or other trusted data store. At a later time
column22157: the dangerous data is subsequently read back into the application and included in dynamic content. From an attacker's perspective
column22158: the optimal place to inject malicious content is in an area that is displayed to either many users or particularly interesting users. Interesting users typically have elevated privileges in the application or interact with sensitive data that is valuable to the attacker. If one of these users executes malicious content
column22159: the attacker may be able to perform privileged operations on behalf of the user or gain access to sensitive data belonging to the user. For example
column22160: the attacker might inject XSS into a log message
column22161: which might not be handled properly when an administrator views the logs. Type 0: DOM-Based XSS - In DOM-based XSS
column22162: the client performs the injection of XSS into the page; in the other types
column22163: the server performs the injection. DOM-based XSS generally involves server-controlled
column22164: trusted script that is sent to the client
column22165: such as Javascript that performs sanity checks on a form before the user submits it. If the server-supplied script processes user-supplied data and then injects it back into the web page (such as with dynamic HTML)
column22166: then DOM-based XSS is possible. Once the malicious script is injected
column22167: the attacker can perform a variety of malicious activities. The attacker could transfer private information
column22168: such as cookies that may include session information
column22169: from the victim's machine to the attacker. The attacker could send malicious requests to a web site on behalf of the victim
column22170: which could be especially dangerous to the site if the victim has administrator privileges to manage that site. Phishing attacks could be used to emulate trusted web sites and trick the victim into entering a password
column22171: allowing the attacker to compromise the victim's account on that web site. Finally
column22172: the script could exploit a vulnerability in the web browser itself possibly taking over the victim's machine
column22173: sometimes referred to as \"drive-by hacking.\" In many cases
column22174: the attack can be launched without the victim even being aware of it. Even with careful users
column22175: attackers frequently use a variety of methods to encode the malicious portion of the attack
column22176: such as URL encoding or Unicode
column22177: so the request looks less suspicious."
column22184: description:"The product uses a denylist-based protection mechanism to defend against XSS attacks
column22186: allowing XSS variants to succeed. While XSS might seem simple to prevent
column22187: web browsers vary so widely in how they parse web pages
column22188: that a denylist cannot keep track of all the variations. The \"XSS Cheat Sheet\" [REF-714] contains a large number of attacks that are intended to bypass incomplete denylists."

column22202: and \"&\" that could be interpreted as web-scripting elements when they are sent to a downstream component that processes web pages. This may allow such characters to be treated as control characters
column22203: which are executed client-side in the context of the user's session. Although this can be classified as an injection problem
column22204: the more pertinent issue is the improper conversion of such special characters to respective context-appropriate entities before displaying them to the user."

Example 2
An attacker can make a single request to a vulnerable server that will cause the server to create two responses
column22337: the second of which may be misinterpreted as a response to a different request
column22338: possibly one made by another user sharing the same TCP connection with the server.\n\nCross-User Defacement can be accomplished by convincing the user to submit the malicious request themselves
column22339: or remotely in situations where the attacker and the user share a common TCP connection to the server
column22340:
such as a shared proxy server.

Example 3
The impact of a maliciously constructed response can be magnified if it is cached
column22341: either by a web cache used by multiple users or even the browser cache of a single user.\n\nCache Poisoning: if a response is cached in a shared web cache
column22342: such as those commonly found in proxy servers
column22343: then all users of that cache will continue receive the malicious content until the cache entry is purged. Similarly
column22344: if the response is cached in the browser of an individual user
column22345: then that user will continue to receive the malicious content until the cache entry is purged

Example 4

they have a choice of a variety of malicious content to provide users.

The variety of attacks based on XSS is almost limitless
column22348: but they commonly include transmitting private data like cookies or other session information to the attacker

or performing other malicious operations on the user's machine under the guise of the vulnerable site.
The most common and dangerous attack vector against users of a vulnerable application uses JavaScript to transmit session and authentication information back to the attacker who can then take complete control of the victim's account.

In addition to using a vulnerable application to send malicious content to a user
column22351: the same weakness can also be leveraged to redirect sensitive content generated by the server to the attacker instead of the intended user.\n\nPage Hijacking: by submitting a request that results in two responses

This means that an attacker who is able to write 0X0F to register_address will not enable any undocumented \"features\" in the process.\n\n"
column23362: description:"The reserved bits in a hardware design are not disabled prior to production. Typically
column23363: reserved bits are used for future capabilities and should not support any functional logic in the design. However
column23364: designers might covertly use these bits to debug or further develop new capabilities in production hardware. Adversaries with access to these bits will write to them in hopes of compromising hardware state. Reserved bits are labeled as such so they can be allocated for a later purpose. They are not to do anything in the current design. However
column23365: designers might want to use these bits to debug or control\/configure a future capability to help minimize time to market (TTM). If the logic being controlled by these bits is still enabled in production
column23366: an adversary could use the logic to induce unwanted\/unsupported behavior in the hardware."
column23368: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA refrigerator has an Internet interface for the official purpose of alerting the manufacturer when that refrigerator detects a fault. Because the device is attached to the Internet
column23369:
the refrigerator is a target for hackers who may wish to use the device other potentially more nefarious purposes.
Example 2

A System-on-Chip (SOC) implements a Root-of-Trust (RoT) in ROM to boot secure code. However
column23370: at times this ROM code might have security vulnerabilities and need to be patched. Since ROM is immutable
column23371:
it can be impossible to patch.

ROM does not have built-in application-programming interfaces (APIs) to patch if the code is vulnerable. Implement mechanisms to patch the vulnerable ROM code.
"
column23372: name:"Reliance on Component That is Not Updateable"
column23374: description:"The product contains a component that cannot be updated or patched in order to remove vulnerabilities or significant bugs. If the component is discovered to contain a vulnerability or critical bug
column23375: but the issue cannot be fixed using an update or patch
column23376: then the product's owner will not be able to protect against the issue. The only option might be replacement of the product
column23377: which could be too financially or operationally expensive for the product owner. As a result
column23378: the inability to patch or update can leave the product open to attacker exploitation or critical operation failures. This weakness can be especially difficult to manage when using ROM
column23380: or similar components that traditionally have had limited or no update capabilities. In industries such as healthcare
column23381: \"legacy\" devices can be operated for decades. As a US task force report [REF-1197] notes
column23382: \"the inability to update or replace equipment has both large and small health care delivery organizations struggle with numerous unsupported legacy systems that cannot easily be replaced (hardware
column23384: and operating systems) with large numbers of vulnerabilities and few modern countermeasures.\" While hardware can be prone to this weakness
column23385: software systems can also be affected
column23386: such as when a third-party driver or library is no longer actively maintained or supported but is still critical for the required functionality."
column23388: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nA refrigerator has an Internet interface for the official purpose of alerting the manufacturer when that refrigerator detects a fault. Because the device is attached to the Internet
column23389: the refrigerator is a target for hackers who may wish to use the device other potentially more nefarious purposes.\n"
column23392: description:"The product does not provide its users with the ability to update or patch its firmware to address any vulnerabilities or weaknesses that may be present. Without the ability to patch or update firmware
column23393: consumers will be left vulnerable to exploitation of any known vulnerabilities
column23394: or any vulnerabilities that are discovered in the future. This can expose consumers to permanent risk throughout the entire lifetime of the device
column23395: which could be years or decades. Some external protective measures and mitigations might be employed to aid in preventing or reducing the risk of malicious attack
column23396: but the root weakness cannot be corrected."
column23398: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\n\nA System-on-Chip (SOC) implements a Root-of-Trust (RoT) in ROM to boot secure code. However
column23399: at times this ROM code might have security vulnerabilities and need to be patched. Since ROM is immutable
column23400:
it can be impossible to patch.

ROM does not have built-in application-programming interfaces (APIs) to patch if the code is vulnerable. Implement mechanisms to patch the vulnerable ROM code.
"
column23401: name:"Missing Ability to Patch ROM Code"
column23403: description:"Missing an ability to patch ROM code may leave a System or System-on-Chip (SoC) in a vulnerable state. A System or System-on-Chip (SoC) that implements a boot process utilizing security mechanisms such as Root-of-Trust (RoT) typically starts by executing code from a Read-only-Memory (ROM) component. The code in ROM is immutable
column23404: hence any security vulnerabilities discovered in the ROM code can never be fixed for the systems that are already in use. A common weakness is that the ROM does not have the ability to patch if security vulnerabilities are uncovered after the system gets shipped. This leaves the system in a vulnerable state where an adversary can compromise the SoC."

column23560: name:"Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust"
column23571: the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate
column23572: resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate. If a system does not follow the chain of trust of a certificate to a root server
column23573: the certificate loses all usefulness as a metric of trust. Essentially
column23574: the trust gained from a certificate is derived from a chain of trust -- with a reputable trusted entity at the end of that list. The end user must trust that reputable source
column23575: and this reputable source must vouch for the resource in question through the medium of the certificate. In some cases
column23576: this trust traverses several entities who vouch for one another. The entity trusted by the end user is at one end of this trust chain
column23577: while the certificate-wielding resource is at the other end of the chain. If the user receives a certificate at the end of one of these trust chains and then proceeds to check only that the first link in the chain
column23578: no real trust has been derived
column23579: since the entire chain must be traversed back to a trusted source to verify the certificate. There are several ways in which the chain of trust might be broken
column23580: including but not limited to: Any certificate in the chain is self-signed
column23581: unless it the root. Not every intermediate certificate is checked
column23582: starting from the original certificate all the way up to the root certificate. An intermediate
column23583: CA-signed certificate does not have the expected Basic Constraints or other important extensions. The root certificate has been compromised or authorized to the wrong party."

column23599: CBC mode is used when encrypting data:\nIn both of these examples
column23600: the initialization vector (IV) is always a block of zeros. This makes the resulting cipher text much more predictable and susceptible to a dictionary attack.\n"
column23601: name:"Generation of Predictable IV with CBC Mode"
column23607: description:"The product generates and uses a predictable initialization Vector (IV) with Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) Mode
column23608: which causes algorithms to be susceptible to dictionary attacks when they are encrypted under the same key. CBC mode eliminates a weakness of Electronic Code Book (ECB) mode by allowing identical plaintext blocks to be encrypted to different ciphertext blocks. This is possible by the XOR-ing of an IV with the initial plaintext block so that every plaintext block in the chain is XOR'd with a different value before encryption. If IVs are reused
column23609: then identical plaintexts would be encrypted to identical ciphertexts. However
column23610: even if IVs are not identical but are predictable
column23611: then they still break the security of CBC mode against Chosen Plaintext Attacks (CPA)."

column23640: name:"EJB Bad Practices: Use of Sockets"
column23642: description:"The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using sockets. The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case
column23643: the product violates the following EJB guideline: \"An enterprise bean must not attempt to listen on a socket
column23645: or use a socket for multicast.\" The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: \"The EJB architecture allows an enterprise bean instance to be a network socket client
column23646: but it does not allow it to be a network server. Allowing the instance to become a network server would conflict with the basic function of the enterprise bean-- to serve the EJB clients.\""

column23855: which does not check the length of its input.\nThe Sun Java(TM) Tutorial provides the following description of JNI [See Reference]: The JNI framework lets your native method utilize Java objects in the same way that Java code uses these objects. A native method can create Java objects
column23857: and then inspect and use these objects to perform its tasks. A native method can also inspect and use objects created by Java application code. A native method can even update Java objects that it created or that were passed to it
column23858: and these updated objects are available to the Java application. Thus

column23861: and access Java objects and then share these objects between them.\nThe vulnerability in the example above could easily be detected through a source code audit of the native method implementation. column23947: description:"The System-on-Chip (SoC) does not have unique
column23948: immutable identifiers for each of its components. A System-on-Chip (SoC) comprises several components (IP) with varied trust requirements. It is required that each IP is identified uniquely and should distinguish itself from other entities in the SoC without any ambiguity. The unique secured identity is required for various purposes. Most of the time the identity is used to route a transaction or perform certain actions
column23951: and acting upon or on behalf of something else. There are several variants of this weakness: A \"missing\" identifier is when the SoC does not define any mechanism to uniquely identify the IP. An \"insufficient\" identifier might provide some defenses - for example
column23952: against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. A \"misconfigured\" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available but not implemented correctly. An \"ignored\" identifier occurs when the SoC\/IP has not applied any policies or does not act upon the identifier securely."

column24109: name:"Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-a-Chip (SoC)"
column24111: description:"The System-On-a-Chip (SoC) does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents. A System-On-a-Chip (SoC) has a lot of functionality
column24112: but it may have a limited number of pins or pads. A pin can only perform one function at a time. However
column24113: it can be configured to perform multiple different functions. This technique is called pin multiplexing. Similarly
column24114: several resources on the chip may be shared to multiplex and support different features or functions. When such resources are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column24115: untrusted agents may be able to access the assets intended to be accessed only by the trusted agents."
column24117: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nOn some processors the hardware indirect branch predictor is shared between execution contexts
column24119: between sibling SMT threads. When SMT thread A executes an indirect branch to a target address X
column24120: this target may be temporarily stored by the indirect branch predictor. A subsequent indirect branch mis-prediction for SMT thread B could speculatively execute instructions at X (or at a location in B's address space that partially aliases X). Even though the processor rolls back the architectural effects of the mis-predicted indirect branch
column24121: the memory accesses alter data cache state
column24122: which is not rolled back after the indirect branch is resolved.\n"
column24125: description:"Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g.
column24126: caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts. Modern processors use techniques such as out-of-order execution
column24130: and caching to increase performance. Details about the implementation of these techniques are hidden from the programmer's view. This is problematic when the hardware implementation of these techniques results in resources being shared across supposedly isolated contexts. Contention for shared resources between different contexts opens covert channels that allow malicious programs executing in one context to recover information from another context. Some examples of shared micro-architectural resources that have been used to leak information between contexts are caches
column24132: and load or store buffers. Speculative and out-of-order execution provides an attacker with increased control over which data is leaked through the covert channel. If the extent of resource sharing between contexts in the design microarchitecture is undocumented
column24133: it is extremely difficult to ensure system assets are protected against disclosure."
column24135: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nConsider a NoC that implements a one-dimensional mesh network with four nodes. This supports two flows: Flow A from node 0 to node 3 (via node 1 and node 2) and Flow B from node 1 to node 2. Flows A and B share a common link between Node 1 and Node 2. Only one flow can use the link in each cycle.\nOne of the masters to this NoC implements a cryptographic algorithm (RSA)
column24136: and another master to the NoC is a core that can be exercised by an attacker. The RSA algorithm performs a modulo multiplication of two large numbers and depends on each bit of the secret key. The algorithm examines each bit in the secret key and only performs multiplication if the bit is 1. This algorithm is known to be prone to timing attacks. Whenever RSA performs multiplication
column24137: there is additional network traffic to the memory controller. One of the reasons for this is cache conflicts.\nSince this is a one-dimensional mesh
column24138: only one flow can use the link in each cycle. Also
column24139: packets from the attack program and the RSA program share the output port of the network-on-chip. This contention results in network interference
column24140: and the throughput and latency of one flow can be affected by the other flow's demand.\nThere may be different ways to fix this particular weakness.\n"
column24141: name:"Improper Isolation of Shared Resources in Network On Chip (NoC)"
column24143: description:"The Network On Chip (NoC) does not isolate or incorrectly isolates its on-chip-fabric and internal resources such that they are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column24145: network on chips (NoC) have many internal resources that are shared between packets from different trust domains. These resources include internal buffers
column24148: and channels. The sharing of resources causes contention and introduces interference between differently trusted domains
column24149: which poses a security threat via a timing channel
column24150: allowing attackers to infer data that belongs to a trusted agent. This may also result in introducing network interference
column24151: resulting in degraded throughput and latency."

Example 3
The following code examples attempt to verify a password using a hard-coded cryptographic key.
The cryptographic key is within a hard-coded string value that is compared to the password. It is likely that an attacker will be able to read the key and compromise the system.
Example 4
The following examples show a portion of properties and configuration files for Java and ASP.NET applications. The files include username and password information but they are stored in cleartext.
This Java example shows a properties file with a cleartext username / password pair.

column24250: the OT:ICEFALL study examined products by 10 different Operational Technology (OT) vendors. The researchers reported 56 vulnerabilities and said that the products were \"insecure by design\" [REF-1283]. If exploited
column24251: these vulnerabilities often allowed adversaries to change how the products operated
column24252: ranging from denial of service to changing the code that the products executed. Since these products were often used in industries such as power
column24256: there could even be safety implications.\nMultiple vendors used hard-coded credentials in their OT products.\n"
column24277: such as a password or cryptographic key
column24278: which it uses for its own inbound authentication
column24280: or encryption of internal data. Hard-coded credentials typically create a significant hole that allows an attacker to bypass the authentication that has been configured by the product administrator. This hole might be difficult for the system administrator to detect. Even if detected
column24281: it can be difficult to fix
column24282: so the administrator may be forced into disabling the product entirely. There are two main variations: Inbound: the product contains an authentication mechanism that checks the input credentials against a hard-coded set of credentials. Outbound: the product connects to another system or component
column24283: and it contains hard-coded credentials for connecting to that component. In the Inbound variant
column24284: a default administration account is created
column24285: and a simple password is hard-coded into the product and associated with that account. This hard-coded password is the same for each installation of the product
column24286: and it usually cannot be changed or disabled by system administrators without manually modifying the program
column24287: or otherwise patching the product. If the password is ever discovered or published (a common occurrence on the Internet)
column24288: then anybody with knowledge of this password can access the product. Finally
column24289: since all installations of the product will have the same password
column24291: this enables massive attacks such as worms to take place. The Outbound variant applies to front-end systems that authenticate with a back-end service. The back-end service may require a fixed password which can be easily discovered. The programmer may simply hard-code those back-end credentials into the front-end product. Any user of that program may be able to extract the password. Client-side systems with hard-coded passwords pose even more of a threat
column24292: since the extraction of a password from a binary is usually very simple."

column24345: description:"The code does not function according to its published specifications
column24346: potentially leading to incorrect usage. When providing functionality to an external party
column24347: it is important that the product behaves in accordance with the details specified. When requirements of nuances are not documented
column24348: the functionality may produce unintended behaviors for the caller
column24349: possibly leading to an exploitable state."
column24351: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nThe Finite State Machine (FSM) shown in the \"bad\" code snippet below assigns the output (\"out\") based on the value of state
column24352:
which is determined based on the user provided input ("user_input").

The case statement does not include a default to handle the scenario when the user provides inputs of 3'h6 and 3'h7. Those inputs push the system to an undefined state and might cause a crash (denial of service) or any other unanticipated outcome.
Adding a default statement to handle undefined inputs mitigates this issue. This is shown in the "Good" code snippet below. The default statement is in bold.

"
column24353: name:"Improper Finite State Machines (FSMs) in Hardware Logic"
column24355: description:"Faulty finite state machines (FSMs) in the hardware logic allow an attacker to put the system in an undefined state
column24356: to cause a denial of service (DoS) or gain privileges on the victim's system. The functionality and security of the system heavily depend on the implementation of FSMs. FSMs can be used to indicate the current security state of the system. Lots of secure data operations and data transfers rely on the state reported by the FSM. Faulty FSM designs that do not account for all states
column24357: either through undefined states (left as don't cares) or through incorrect implementation
column24358: might lead an attacker to drive the system into an unstable state from which the system cannot recover without a reset
column24359: thus causing a DoS. Depending on what the FSM is used for
column24360: an attacker might also gain additional privileges to launch further attacks and compromise the security guarantees."
column24362: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nIn the following snippet from a doPost() servlet method
column24363: the server returns \"200 OK\" (default) even if an error occurs.\n"
column24369: description:"The product encounters an error but does not provide a status code or return value to indicate that an error has occurred. "
column24372: an HTTP 404 status code is returned in the event of an IOException encountered in a Java servlet. A 404 code is typically meant to indicate a non-existent resource and would be somewhat misleading in this case.\n"
column24378: description:"A function or operation returns an incorrect return value or status code that does not indicate an error
column24379: but causes the product to modify its behavior based on the incorrect result. This can lead to unpredictable behavior. If the function is used to make security-critical decisions or provide security-critical information
column24380: then the wrong status code can cause the product to assume that an action is safe
column24390: or function does not perform according to its specification. "
column24395: description:"The user interface does not correctly enable or configure a security feature
column24396: but the interface provides feedback that causes the user to believe that the feature is in a secure state. When the user interface does not properly reflect what the user asks of it
column24397: then it can lead the user into a false sense of security. For example
column24398: the user might check a box to enable a security option to enable encrypted communications
column24399: but the product does not actually enable the encryption. Alternately
column24400: the user might provide a \"restrict ALL\" access control rule
column24401: but the product only implements \"restrict SOME\"."
column24404: name:"Unimplemented or Unsupported Feature in UI"
column24409: description:"A UI function for a security feature appears to be supported and gives feedback to the user that suggests that it is supported
column24410: but the underlying functionality is not implemented. "
column24415: description:"A UI function is obsolete and the product does not warn the user. "
column24418: name:"The UI Performs the Wrong Action"
column24422: description:"The UI performs the wrong action with respect to the user's request. "
column24425: name:"User Interface (UI) Misrepresentation of Critical Information"
column24452: description:"The user interface (UI) does not properly represent critical information to the user
column24453: allowing the information - or its source - to be obscured or spoofed. This is often a component in phishing attacks. If an attacker can cause the UI to display erroneous data
column24454: or to otherwise convince the user to display information that appears to come from a trusted source
column24455: then the attacker could trick the user into performing the wrong action. This is often a component in phishing attacks
column24456: but other kinds of problems exist. For example
column24457: if the UI is used to monitor the security state of a system or network
column24458: then omitting or obscuring an important indicator could prevent the user from detecting and reacting to a security-critical event. UI misrepresentation can take many forms: Incorrect indicator: incorrect information is displayed
column24459: which prevents the user from understanding the true state of the product or the environment the product is monitoring
column24460: especially of potentially-dangerous conditions or operations. This can be broken down into several different subtypes. Overlay: an area of the display is intended to give critical information
column24461: but another process can modify the display by overlaying another element on top of it. The user is not interacting with the expected portion of the user interface. This is the problem that enables clickjacking attacks
column24462: although many other types of attacks exist that involve overlay. Icon manipulation: the wrong icon
column24464: can be influenced (such as making a dangerous .EXE executable look like a harmless .GIF) Timing: the product is performing a state transition or context switch that is presented to the user with an indicator
column24465: but a race condition can cause the wrong indicator to be used before the product has fully switched context. The race window could be extended indefinitely if the attacker can trigger an error. Visual truncation: important information could be truncated from the display
column24466: such as a long filename with a dangerous extension that is not displayed in the GUI because the malicious portion is truncated. The use of excessive whitespace can also cause truncation
column24467: or place the potentially-dangerous indicator outside of the user's field of view (e.g. \"filename.txt .exe\"). A different type of truncation can occur when a portion of the information is removed due to reasons other than length
column24468: such as the accidental insertion of an end-of-input marker in the middle of an input
column24469: such as a NUL byte in a C-style string. Visual distinction: visual information might be presented in a way that makes it difficult for the user to quickly and correctly distinguish between critical and unimportant segments of the display. Homographs: letters from different character sets
column24471: or languages can appear very similar (i.e. may be visually equivalent) in a way that causes the human user to misread the text (for example
column24472: to conduct phishing attacks to trick a user into visiting a malicious web site with a visually-similar name as a trusted site). This can be regarded as a type of visual distinction issue."
column24475: trusted URL that a user may frequently access.\nHowever
column24476: the URL above is comprised of Cyrillic characters that look identical to the expected ASCII characters. This results in most users not being able to distinguish between the two and assuming that the above URL is trusted and safe. The \"e\" is actually the \"CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER IE\" which is represented in HTML as the character &#x435
column24477: while the \"a\" is actually the \"CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER A\" which is represented in HTML as the character &#x430. The \"p\"
column24479:
and "o" are also Cyrillic characters in this example. Viewing the source reveals a URL of "http://www.еxаmрlе.соm". An adversary can utilize this approach to perform an attack such as a phishing attack in order to drive traffic to a malicious website.
Example 2
The following displays an example of how creating usernames containing homoglyphs can lead to log forgery.
Assume an adversary visits a legitimate
column24480: trusted domain and creates an account named \"admin\"
column24481: except the 'a' and 'i' characters are Cyrillic characters instead of the expected ASCII. Any actions the adversary performs will be saved to the log file and look like they came from a legitimate administrator account.\nUpon closer inspection
column24482: the account that generated three of these log entries is \"аdmіn\". Only the third log entry is by the legitimate admin account. This makes it more difficult to determine which actions were performed by the adversary and which actions were executed by the legitimate \"admin\" account.\n"
column24483: name:"Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User"
column24491: description:"The product displays information or identifiers to a user
column24492: but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs)
column24493: which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended
column24496: or icons can be semantically distinct to a program
column24497: while appearing very similar or identical to a human user. These are referred to as homoglyphs. For example
column24498: the lowercase \"l\" (ell) and uppercase \"I\" (eye) have different character codes
column24499: but these characters can be displayed in exactly the same way to a user
column24500: depending on the font. This can also occur between different character sets. For example
column24501: the Latin capital letter \"A\" and the Greek capital letter \"\" (Alpha) are treated as distinct by programs
column24502: but may be displayed in exactly the same way to a user. Accent marks may also cause letters to appear very similar
column24503: such as the Latin capital letter grave mark \"?\" and its equivalent \"?\" with the acute accent. Adversaries can exploit this visual similarity for attacks such as phishing
column24504: e.g. by providing a link to an attacker-controlled hostname that looks like a hostname that the victim trusts. In a different use of homoglyphs
column24505: an adversary may create a back door username that is visually similar to the username of a regular user
column24506: which then makes it more difficult for a system administrator to detect the malicious username while reviewing logs."
column24509: a malicous developer has injected code to send credit card numbers to the developer's own email address.\n"
column24512: description:"The product contains code that appears to be malicious in nature. Malicious flaws have acquired colorful names
column24516: and logic-bomb. A developer might insert malicious code with the intent to subvert the security of a product or its host system at some time in the future. It generally refers to a program that performs a useful service but exploits rights of the program's user in a way the user does not intend."
column24521: description:"The product appears to contain benign or useful functionality
column24522: but it also contains code that is hidden from normal operation that violates the intended security policy of the user or the system administrator. "
column24527: description:"Non-replicating malicious code only resides on the target system or product that is attacked; it does not attempt to spread to other systems. "
column24534: will attempt to attack other systems once it has successfully compromised the target system or the product. "
column24539: description:"A trapdoor is a hidden piece of code that responds to a special input
column24540: allowing its user access to resources without passing through the normal security enforcement mechanism. "
column24542: {"exampleDescription":"Example 1\nTypical examples of triggers include system date or time mechanisms
column24544: and counters that wait for an opportunity to launch their payload. When triggered
column24545: a time-bomb may deny service by crashing the system
column24550: description:"The product contains code that is designed to disrupt the legitimate operation of the product (or its environment) when a certain time passes
column24551: or when a certain logical condition is met. When the time bomb or logic bomb is detonated
column24552: it may perform a denial of service such as crashing the system
column24554: or degrading system response time. This bomb might be placed within either a replicating or non-replicating Trojan horse."
column24559: description:"The product collects personally identifiable information about a human user or the user's activities
column24560: but the product accesses this information using other resources besides itself
column24561: and it does not require that user's explicit approval or direct input into the product. \"Spyware\" is a commonly used term with many definitions and interpretations. In general
column24562: it is meant to refer to products that collect information or install functionality that human users might not allow if they were fully aware of the actions being taken by the software. For example
column24563: a user might expect that tax software would collect a social security number and include it when filing a tax return
column24564: but that same user would not expect gaming software to obtain the social security number from that tax software's data."
column24571: description:"The product uses an API function
column24573: or other entity in a way that relies on properties that are not always guaranteed to hold for that entity. This can lead to resultant weaknesses when the required properties change
column24574: such as when the product is ported to a different platform or if an interaction error (CWE-435) occurs."
column24579: description:"The product uses a mechanism that automatically optimizes code
column24580: e.g. to improve a characteristic such as performance
column24581: but the optimizations can have an unintended side effect that might violate an intended security assumption. "
column24584: name:"Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code"
column24588: description:"The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software
column24589: but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified. "
column24594: description:"The code uses a data representation that relies on low-level data representation or constructs that may vary across different processors
column24597: or other physical components. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain and\/or port the product
column24598: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities."
column24601: name:"Use of Platform-Dependent Third Party Components"
column24603: description:"The product relies on third-party components that do not provide equivalent functionality across all desirable platforms. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column24604: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities."
column24609: description:"The product or code uses machine-dependent functionality
column24610: but it does not sufficiently encapsulate or isolate this functionality from the rest of the code. This issue makes it more difficult to port or maintain the product
column24611: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and\/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities."
column24616: description:"The product receives input from an upstream component
column24617: but it does not account for byte ordering (e.g. big-endian and little-endian) when processing the input
column24618: causing an incorrect number or value to be used. "
column24621: name:"Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations"
column24623: description:"The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions. The use of inconsistent implementations can cause changes in behavior when the code is ported or built under a different environment than the programmer expects
column24624: which can lead to security problems in some cases. The implementation of many functions varies by platform
column24626: even by different versions of the same platform. Implementation differences can include: Slight differences in the way parameters are interpreted leading to inconsistent results. Some implementations of the function carry significant security risks. The function might not be defined on all platforms. The function might change which return codes it can provide
column24627: or change the meaning of its return codes."
column24632: description:"The product uses an API function that does not exist on all versions of the target platform. This could cause portability problems or inconsistencies that allow denial of service or other consequences. Some functions that offer security features supported by the OS are not available on all versions of the OS in common use. Likewise
column24633: functions are often deprecated or made obsolete for security reasons and should not be used."
column24636: name:"Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer"
column24638: description:"Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption. "
